title: Mikell et. al. v. Mikell
description: In this zoning case, Appellants appeal the master-in-equity's decision to void a planned development.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				I. Jenkins
      Mikell, Jr. and Pinkney V. Mikell, Respondents,
				v.
				County of
      Charleston and Timothy E. Scott, A.D. Jordan, Curtis E. Bostic, Carolyn
      Condon, Ed Fava, Barrett Lawrimore, Francis J. Roberts, Leon E. Stavrinakis,
      and Charles T. Wallace in their capacity as Members of Charleston County
      Council, George Lee Mikell, Julia Mikell Flowers, Daisy Mikell Pedrick, Mary Mikell,
      John Mikell, and Peterâ€™s Point Associates, LP, Defendants, of whom George
      Lee Mikell, Julia Mikell Flowers, Daisy Mikell Pedrick, Mary Mikell, John
      Mikell, and Peterâ€™s Point Associates, LP, are the Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity
Opinion No. 4296 

Submitted May 9, 2007 â€“ Filed October 4,
  2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Morris A. Ellison, Perrin Quarles Dargan, III, Carolyn H. Blue, of
  Charleston, for Appellants.Â Â  
				Capers G. Barr, III and Frances Isaac Cantwell, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.:Â 
  In this appeal from the rezoning of the Peterâ€™s Point Planned Development, George
  Lee Mikell, Julia Mikell Flowers, Daisy Mikell Pedrick, Mary Mikell, John
  Mikell, and Peterâ€™s Point Associates, LP, (hereinafter â€œAppellantsâ€)[1] contend the master-in-equity erred in
  finding a conflict between the planned development and the Charleston County
  Zoning and Land Development Regulations (â€œZLDRâ€) and subsequently voiding the
  planned development.Â  We reverse.[2]Â   
FACTS
Appellants are the sole owners of 162 acres of land located on Edisto Island, South Carolina, also known as Peterâ€™s Point Plantation. Â The land in
  question is a peninsula-like tract formed by the confluence of two tidal
  creeks.Â  The land is divided into six parcels whose zoning is governed by the
  ZLDR.Â  Under the ZLDR, five of the parcels were zoned Agricultural Residential
  (AGR).Â  The ZLDR provides that base zoning district AGR parcels have a maximum
  recommended density for residential use of one dwelling unit per acre.Â  The
  last parcel was zoned Agricultural Preservation (AG-10), which provides for a
  recommended density of one dwelling unit per ten acres.Â  In order to achieve
  the highest allowed density of one dwelling unit per five acres, an application
  must be processed through the planned development process. Â Without
  application for maximum density, the original zoning plan allowed for the
  development of approximately sixty-four units.  
On December 17, 2003, Appellants filed a Zoning Change Application
  requesting the land in question be rezoned as a planned development that would
  include single family homes. Â The permitted uses of the planned
  development would include detached single family homes on lots having at least
  one acre; agriculture; horse or other animal production; commercial timber
  operations; and stables.Â  The application stated that the new planned
  development would shift the number of units within the tracts of Peterâ€™s Point
  and would allow more units in the previously zoned AG-10 tract.Â  The application
  proposed to reduce the total number of dwelling units from sixty-four to
  fifty-five and reduce the total number of waterfront lots to fifty-one.Â  
 
On June 22, 2004, the Charleston County Council (County Council) adopted
  Ordinance No. 1300, which rezoned the land in question pursuant to Article 3.5
  of the ZLDR from AGR/AG-10 districts to a planned development district.Â  This
  change reduced the overall number of units allowed, but reallocated them,
  increasing the number of dwelling units in the AG-10 area from ten to
  thirty-nine units.Â  On July 1, 2004, adjoining property owners and distant
  cousins of Appellants (hereinafter â€œRespondentsâ€) filed a Complaint against Appellants
  stating that the rezoning violated the ZLDR by increasing the density ratio of
  the previously zoned AG-10 area from a density ratio of one dwelling per ten
  acres to one dwelling per 2.73 acres.Â  Both parties filed motions for summary
  judgment.  
Although the parties raised several issues during the summary
  judgment hearing, the master limited his analysis by stating, â€œ[t]he issue in
  this case turns on the construction of various provisions of the ZLDR,
  particularly those of Article 4.5.3, the AG-10 regulations, and those of
  Article 3.5, the planned development regulations, in a manner that effectuates
  the intent of County Council.â€Â  After analyzing this issue, the master
  ultimately granted summary judgment in favor of Respondents.Â   
In reaching this decision, the master found Ordinance No. 1300
  conflicted with Article 4.5.3B of the ZLDR which limits the density in an AG-10
  district to no higher than one residential dwelling unit per five acres.Â  The
  master rejected Appellantsâ€™ contention that Article 3.5 of the ZLDR, which
  states that planned developments may provide for variations from other
  ordinances concerning the density of a parcel, was controlling.Â  The master
  reasoned that Article 4.5.3.B, the more specific ZLDR provision, took
  precedence over the more general provisions of Article 3.5.Â  In support of this
  reasoning, the master relied on what he believed was the intent of County Council
  in adopting the ZLDR.Â  Specifically, the master found that by enacting the
  AG-10 and AG-8 regulations, â€œCouncil evinced an intent to limit itself in
  increasing density in these districts, by requiring a planned development and
  then capping the number of units that could be achieved by way thereof.â€
Based on this analysis, the master held that because the planned
  development was adopted contrary to the ZLDR, it was arbitrary, capricious and
  exceeded the authority of the County Council.Â  The master also concluded there was
  insufficient evidence in the record to determine whether or not the planned
  development met the criteria for creating a planned development contained in
  the ZLDR.Â  As a result, the master remanded the matter to County Council to
  make specific findings and for the identification and designation of the open
  space and other criteria necessary for the establishment of a planned
  development.Â  The master subsequently denied Appellantsâ€™ motion for reconsideration.Â 
  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing
  the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same
  standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states
  that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â 
  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334,
  340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005); Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567
  S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities,
  conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most
  favorable to the non-moving party below. Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146,
  151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004); see Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C.
  310, 317, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be
  construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment
  is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is
  desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364
  S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005). Â â€œEven when there is no dispute as
  to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn
  from them, summary judgment should be denied.â€ Nelson
    v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605
  S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œHowever, when plain, palpable, and
  indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted.â€Â  Ellis v. Davidson,
  358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
DISCUSSION
Appellants contend
  the master erred in voiding the planned development by finding a conflict
  between Ordinance No. 1300 and the ZLDR.Â  We agree.Â   
â€œIt
  is well settled that when interpreting an ordinance, legislative intent must
  prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used.â€Â  Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C.
  65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).Â  â€œIn construing ordinances, the terms must
  be taken in their ordinary and popular meaning.â€Â  Id. at 68, 459 S.E.2d
  at 843.
â€œThe
  primary rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the
  intent of the legislature.â€Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v.
    Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  â€œThe first question
  of statutory interpretation is whether the statuteâ€™s meaning is clear on its
  face.â€Â  Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588
  (2002).Â  Â If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear
  meaning, then â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court
  has no right to impose another meaning.â€ Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79,
  85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  The words of the statute must be given their
  plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction
  to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation. Hitachi Data Sys. Corp.
    v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  A statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction
  consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.Â  Daisy
    Outdoor Adver. Co. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 352 S.C. 113, 120, 572 S.E.2d
  462, 466 (Ct. App. 2002).Â 
â€œRezoning is a
  legislative matter, and the court has no power to zone property.â€Â  Bear
    Enters. v. County of Greenville, 319 S.C. 137, 140, 459 S.E.2d 883, 885 (Ct.
  App. 1995). â€œThe decision of the legislative body is presumptively valid, and
  the property owner has the burden of proving otherwise.â€ Â Id.Â  Our
  supreme court has explained:

	The authority of a municipality to enact zoning ordinances,
  restricting the use of privately owned
  property is founded in the police power. The governing bodies of municipalities
  clothed with authority to determine residential and industrial districts are
  better qualified by their knowledge of the situation to act upon such matters than
  are the Courts, and they will not be interfered with in the exercise of their
  police power to accomplish desired end unless there is plain violation of the
  constitutional rights of citizens. Â There is a strong presumption in favor of
  the validity of municipal zoning ordinances, and in favor of the validity of
  their application, and where the Planning and Zoning Commission and the city
  council of a municipality have acted after considering all of the facts, the
  Court should not disturb the finding unless such action is arbitrary,
  unreasonable, or in obvious abuse of its discretion, or unless it has acted
  illegally and in excess of its lawfully delegated authority. Â Likewise, the
  power to declare an ordinance invalid because it is so unreasonable as to impair
  or destroy constitutional rights is one which will be exercised carefully and
  cautiously, as it is not the function of the Court to pass upon the wisdom or
  expediency of municipal ordinances or regulations. The burden of proving the
  invalidity of a zoning ordinance is on the party attacking it to establish that
  the acts of the city council were arbitrary, unreasonable and unjust. 
	

Rush v. City of Greenville, 246 S.C. 268, 276, 143
  S.E.2d 527, 530-31 (1965).Â  Accordingly, â€œ[t]he Court will not overturn the
  action of [county council] if the decision is fairly debateable because the
  [countyâ€™s] action is presumed to have been a valid exercise of power and it is
  not the prerogative of the Court to pass upon the wisdom of the decision.â€Â  Rushing
    v. City of Greenville, 265 S.C. 285, 288, 217 S.E.2d 797, 799 (1975); Lenardis
      v. City of Greenville, 316 S.C. 471, 472, 450 S.E.2d 597, 598 (Ct. App.
  1994).  
Turning
  to the facts of this case, we believe County Councilâ€™s decision to adopt Ordinance
  No. 1300 was â€œfairly debatableâ€ and did not constitute an action that was
  arbitrary, unreasonable, or unjust.Â  First, without question, County Council
  was authorized to adopt the planned development ordinance.Â  Section 6-29-740 of
  the South Carolina Code permits â€œthe local governing authority [to] provide for
  the establishment of planned development districts as amendments to a locally
  adopted zoning ordinance and official zoning map.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-740 (2004).Â 
  Moreover, Article 2.1.2 of the ZLDR states that County Council shall have final
  decision-making authority on matters concerning planned developments, including
  zoning map amendments.Â  Thus, these provisions provide County Council with final
  decision-making authority in rezoning actions pursuant to a planned development
  application such as in the instant case. Â Accordingly, we find the
  master erred in ruling that â€œ[i]n approving Ordinance 1300, the Council
  exceeded the authority devolved upon it by its own laws.â€Â   
County
  Councilâ€™s decision to adopt Ordinance No. 1300 was not only authorized, it was
  supported by the portion of the ZLDR pertaining to planned developments.Â  Planned
  developments are governed by Article 3.5 of the ZLDR, and Article 3.5.1 defines
  a planned development as a â€œtype of zoning district (PD) and a type of
  development plan.â€Â  As stated in Article 3.5.2A, the planned development
  regulations are â€œintended to encourage innovative land planning and site
  designâ€ by â€œ[r]educing or eliminating the inflexibility that sometimes results
  from strict application of zoning standards that were designated primarily for
  development on individual lots.â€Â  More importantly, Article 3.5.7 specifically
  provides for deviations from other zoning designations:Â   

	Planned
  Developments may provide for variations from other ordinances and the
  regulations of other established zoning districts concerning use, setbacks, lot
  area, density, bulk and other requirements to accommodate flexibility in
  the arrangement of uses for the general purpose of promoting and protecting the
  public health, safety, and general welfare.

(emphasis added); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-740 (2004) (outlining planned development districts).[3] Â Article 3.5.7 goes on to outline criteria that must be met for a proposed
  development that is applying for a higher density than allowed by the base
  zoning district.Â  As evidenced by the outlined ZLDR provisions and section
  6-29-740, planned developments are intended to provide flexibility for County
  Council to exercise its discretion in addressing requirements in base zoning
  districts, in this case a density requirement.Â   
Although
  Article 4.5.3B, the ZLDR section pertaining to AG-10 properties, states that
  â€œIn order to achieve the highest allowed density of 1 dwelling unit per 5
  acres, a request must be processed through the Planned Development process as
  designated in Art. 3.5 of this Ordinance,â€ the planned development section of
  the ZLDR, i.e., Article 3.5, allows for a greater maximum density than
  one dwelling unit per five acres by specifically providing for variations in
  density from other ordinances and the regulations of other established base zoning
  districts.Â  Accordingly, we do not agree with the master that a conflict exists
  between the two ZLDR provisions.
Furthermore,
  there is nothing to suggest that County Council cannot change an ordinance that
  it created. Â To the contrary, section 6-29-760 of the South Carolina Code
  allows for the enactment or amendment of any zoning regulation or map.Â  This
  section authorizes municipalities to amend such regulations, restrictions, and
  boundaries.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-760 (2004) (outlining procedure
  for enactment or amendment of zoning regulation or map).Â  Hence, a municipality
  has the legislative power to amend its general zoning ordinance and rezone small
  areas, so long as its action is not arbitrary or unreasonable.Â  See Bob
    Jones Univ., Inc. v. City of Greenville, 243 S.C. 351, 360, 133 S.E.2d 843,
  847 (1963) (â€œA municipal zoning ordinance is presumably valid.Â  Hence, the
  burden of proof is upon the party attacking the amendment to establish that the
  acts of the city council were arbitrary, unreasonable and unjust.â€)(citations
  omitted).Â  Because County Councilâ€™s actions were authorized and its decision to
  adopt Ordinance No. 1300, which rezoned the six-parcel, multiple zoning
  districts of Peterâ€™s Point Plantation, was at least â€œfairly debateable,â€ we
  hold the master erred in voiding the ordinance.Â  Â Accordingly, we reverse the
  masterâ€™s decision and reinstate Ordinance No. 1300.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the
  masterâ€™s decision is  
REVERSED.[4]
ANDERSON
  and HUFF, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  Â Â Although Charleston County and the members of its
  council are listed in the caption on appeal, we note they were dismissed as
  parties by order of this court pursuant to their motion to withdraw their
  appeal.
[2] Â This case was originally scheduled for oral
  argument.Â  The parties, however, consented to a request by this court to have
  the case submitted on the record.
[3]Â Â  Section 6-29-740 provides:

	In
  order to achieve the objectives of the comprehensive plan of the locality and
  to allow flexibility in development that will result in improved design,
  character, and quality of new mixed use developments and preserve natural and
  scenic features of open spaces, the local governing authority may provide for
  the establishment of planned development districts as amendments to a locally
  adopted zoning ordinance and official zoning map. Â The adopted planned
  development map is the zoning district map for the property. Â The planned
  development provisions must encourage innovative site planning for residential,
  commercial, institutional, and industrial developments within planned
  development districts. Â Planned development districts may provide for variations from other ordinances and the regulations of other
  established zoning districts concerning use, setbacks, lot size, density, bulk,
  and other requirements to accommodate flexibility in the arrangement of uses
  for the general purpose of promoting and protecting the public health, safety,
  and general welfare. Â Amendments to a planned development district may be
  authorized by ordinance of the governing authority after recommendation from
  the planning commission. Â These amendments constitute zoning ordinance
  amendments and must follow prescribed procedures for the amendments. Â The
  adopted plan may include a method for minor modifications to the site plan or
  development provisions.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  6-29-740 (2004).
[4] In light of our decision, we need not address
  Appellantsâ€™ remaining two issues. See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362
  S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (stating the appellate court need not address additional issues
  when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).

title: Brown v. State
description: In this PCR appeal, the court must decide the efficacy of Doyle v. Ohio as juxtaposed to the holding by the United States Supreme Court in Brecht v. Abrahamson.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Rafeal Brown, Petitioner,
				v.
				The State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marlboro County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge 

Opinion No. 4297
Heard September 11, 2007 â€“ Filed October 5,
  2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Wanda
  H. Carter, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General Karen Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  The post-conviction
  relief (PCR) judge denied Rafeal Brownâ€™s application for relief holding that,
  even if counsel was ineffective, Brown failed to establish prejudice.Â  This
  court granted certiorari to consider whether trial counsel erred in
  failing to object to a Doyle error at trial.Â  We affirm.  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of August 5, 1994, Brown was dancing with a girl
  inside the Castleblanca Club, a nightclub in Clio.Â  After a male patron passing
  the pair made what Brown considered to be a threatening gesture, the two began
  to fight.Â  The fight caused great commotion in the club and more patrons joined
  in.Â  The crowd moved outside into the parking lot.Â  The testimony of several
  eyewitnesses at trial revealed that Brown grabbed a gun from a friendâ€™s hand
  and shot multiple times into the crowd.Â  Two bystanders were struck by the
  bullets, and Brown ran on foot from the scene.Â  One victim, Louis Bostic, died
  the day of the shooting and the other, Ron Bostic, died five days later.Â  
 
At trial, Brown took the stand in his own defense.Â  He alleged, for
  the first time, that one of his friends was the shooter and that the eyewitnesses
  coordinated stories to frame him.Â  On cross examination, the solicitor asked
  Brown why he had not given a statement to police relating the version of events
  he now gave at trial.Â  Additionally, during his closing argument, the solicitor
  argued the lack of a statement indicated Brownâ€™s guilt.Â  Brownâ€™s counsel made
  no objections.
Following his conviction, Brown appealed under Anders v.
  California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  The appeal was dismissed by the South
  Carolina Supreme Court.Â  State v. Brown, Op. No. 96-MO-256 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Dec. 12, 1996).Â  Brown then filed for post-conviction relief in December 1996 and
  amended the application in June 2003.Â  An evidentiary hearing was held in
  September 2003 in Darlington County.
At the PCR hearing, Brown argued his counsel was ineffective for
  failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s questions about and references to his failure
  to provide a statement to police.Â  Specifically, Brown averred the solicitor
  made numerous comments that constituted Doyle violations.Â  During cross-examination,
  the solicitor stated:

	â€œEverybody else gave the police a statement the next morning at
  nine oâ€™clock.â€
	â€œAnd during all that time, some ten months, you havenâ€™t given [the
  police] a statement, have you?â€
	â€œAnd when you came in at 3:00 in the morning you didnâ€™t call the
  police and tell them Eric David had shot somebody, did you?â€
	â€œYou didnâ€™t call the police and tell them Eric David had a gun,
  did you?â€

Brown contended the solicitor committed a Doyle violation
  with the following comment made during closing argument:

	â€œHe hasnâ€™t given a statement.Â  He hasnâ€™t given a statement because
  he is guilty.â€

In response to Brown alleging ineffective assistance, trial
  counsel testified that it is fairly typical for solicitors to ask on
  cross-examination why the defendant didnâ€™t take particular actions if
  innocent.Â  Counsel opined Brownâ€™s failure to make a statement did not affect
  the outcome of the trial.Â  In light of the numerous eyewitnesses who gave
  statements to police and testified at trial, counsel explained his strategy was
  to draw the jurorsâ€™ attention to the discrepancies amongst the witnessesâ€™
  stories.Â  Counsel stated that he typically does not object during closing
  argument for fear of creating a negative impression with the jury.
In denying post-conviction relief, the PCR judge found there was
  â€œoverwhelming evidence in the case for conviction of [Brown].â€Â  Further, the
  judge held â€œthat even if there were a failure to object to certain testimony,
  that [Brown] has failed to establish prejudice in this matter.â€Â  The PCR judge
  found that trial counsel â€œarticulated valid strategic reasons for deciding not
  to object to portions of the solicitor[â€™]s examination and of his closing
  argument.Â  [Brown] has not shown that counsel was deficient in that choice of
  tactics.â€
ISSUE
Did the PCR judge err in not finding trial counsel ineffective for
  failing to object to a Doyle violation at trial?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Edwards v. State, 372 S.C. 493, 494, 642 S.E.2d
  738, 739 (2007); Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 525 S.E.2d 514 (2000).Â 
  â€œ[P]etitioner must meet the standard established in Strickland v. Washington,
  466 U.S. 668, 104 S. Ct. 2052, 80 L. Ed. 2d 674 (1984).â€Â  State v. Edmond, 341 S.C. 340, 346, 534 S.E.2d 682, 685 (2006).Â  To establish a claim
  of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove: (1) that counsel
  failed to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms;
  and (2) that the deficient performance prejudiced the applicant's case. Strickland
    v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).
â€œCounsel
  is strongly presumed to have rendered adequate assistance and made all
  significant decisions in the exercise of reasonable professional judgment.â€Â  Strickland,
  466 U.S. at 690; Morris v. State, 371 S.C. 278, 639 S.E.2d 53 (2006); Cherry
    v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989). Â The burden is on the
  applicant in a post-conviction proceeding to prove the allegations in his
  application.Â  Rule 71.1(e), SCRCP; Van Dohlen v. State, 360 S.C. 598,
  603, 602 S.E.2d 738, 741 (2004); Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441,
  334 S.E.2d 813 (1985). Â â€œTo
  establish a claim of ineffective assistance of trial counsel, a PCR applicant
  has the burden of proving counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective
  standard of reasonableness and, but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable
  probability that the result at trial would have been differentâ€¦.â€ Johnson v.
    State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997); Underwood v. State,
  309 S.C. 560, 425 S.E.2d 20 (1992); Simmons v. State, 308 S.C. 481, 419
  S.E.2d 225 (1992).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to
  undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694; Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 480 S.E.2d 733 (1997).Â  â€œFurthermore,
  when a defendantâ€™s conviction is challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is
  a reasonable probability that, absent the errors, the fact finder would have
  had a reasonable doubt respecting guilt.â€™â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E2d 590, 596 (2007) (citing Strickland, 466 U.S. at 695).
â€œThis
  court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€ Marlar v. State, 373 S.C. 275,
  279, 644 S.E.2d 769, 771 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing Dempsey v. State, 363
  S.C. 365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005)); McCray v. State, 317 S.C.
  557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995).Â  An appellate court must affirm the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision when its findings are supported by any evidence of probative value.Â  Custodio
    v. State, 373 S.C. 4, 9, 644 S.E.2d 36, 38 (2007); Cherry v. State,
  300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).Â  However, an appellate court will not
  affirm the decision when it is not supported by any probative evidence.Â  State
    v. Edmond, 341 S.C. 340, 347, 534 S.E.2d 682, 686 (2006); Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Brown argues the PCR judge erred in not finding trial counsel ineffective
  for failing to object to comments made by the solicitor that Brown never gave
  the police a statement.Â  Specifically, Brown contends the solicitorâ€™s line of
  questioning and comments on his silence violated his constitutional rights
  under Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 610 (1976).
I.  DOYLE v. OHIO
In Doyle, the Supreme Court held â€œthe use for impeachment
  purposes of [a defendantâ€™s] silence, at the time of arrest and after receiving Miranda warnings, violate[s] the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.â€ Doyle,
  426 U.S. at 619.Â  In that case, the defendants received Miranda warnings

  judge, the petitioner alleged his counsel was ineffective for not objecting to
  this hearsay testimony.Â  Although our supreme court disagreed that the
  testimony was hearsay, they concluded counsel offered a valid strategy in that
  he used the testimony to reinforce the notion that the identification was
  founded in rumor and innuendo.Â  Id. at 33, 561 S.E.2d at 610.
Counsel was found deficient in Gilchrist v. State, 350 S.C. 221, 565 S.E.2d 281 (2002), for the failure
  to object to the stateâ€™s vouching for the credibility of a key witness.Â  At the
  PCR hearing, counsel explained he â€œthought seriously about making a mistrial
  motion and objection to all of that at the time.Â  However, based upon the strategy
  of the case, [he] decided not to.â€Â  Id. at 226, 565 S.E.2d at 284.Â  No
  further explanation was given. Our supreme court noted â€œcounsel never
  articulated any strategy at all.Â  A blanket statement by counsel at a PCR
  hearing that he employed â€˜strategyâ€™ does not automatically insulate the lawyer
  from being found ineffective.â€Â  Id. at 228, 565 S.E.2d at 284 n.2.
In Sanchez v.
  State, 351 S.C. 270, 569 S.E.2d 363 (2002), the defendant appealed his
  criminal sexual conduct conviction.Â  Our supreme court held representation was
  ineffective because of counselâ€™s failure to object to a police officerâ€™s
  hearsay testimony about the six year old victimâ€™s demonstration of the assault
  using an anatomically correct doll.Â  Trial counsel felt the testimony would be useful
  to show the accusations were vague.Â  Id. at 274, 569 S.E.2d at 365.Â 
  However, this strategy was deemed unreasonable as the hearsay corroborated the
  victimâ€™s testimony at trial.Â  Id. at 276, 569 S.E.2dÂ  at 366.
Our supreme
  court affirmed a petitionerâ€™s convictions for trafficking cocaine and
  possession of cocaine in McLaughlin v. State, 352 S.C. 476, 575 S.E.2d
  841 (2003).Â  Defense counsel was not ineffective for failing to preserve for
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s refusal to allow cross-examination of the stateâ€™s
  chemist regarding his own drug arrest.Â  The trial judge decided defense counsel
  could inquire whether the chemist was under the influence of drugs while
  testing the cocaine evidence in this case, but he could not inquire into the
  chemistâ€™s arrest.Â  Defense counsel chose not to ask the permitted questions at
  all.Â  Counsel explained that, without being able to inquire about the chemistâ€™s
  arrest, asking only the permitted questions would not have advanced the
  petitionerâ€™s case.Â  In addition to finding defense counsel had proffered the
  questions, our supreme court held â€œcounsel gave a valid reason for consciously
  deciding not to ask those questions.â€Â  Id. at 483, 575 S.E.2d at 845.
In Ellenburg
  v. State, 367 S.C. 66, 625 S.E.2d 224 (2006), Ellenburg alleged his defense
  counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s comments made
  during closing argument.Â  At his trial for safecracking and second degree
  burglary, an accomplice testified to his version of events.Â  Defense counsel
  argued in closing that the story was a half truth told to avoid being subjected
  to a polygraph machine by the police.Â  The solicitor responded by asking why
  the accomplice would lie when faced with the prospect of taking a lie detector
  test.Â  Our supreme court held defense counselâ€™s mention of the polygraph test
  was â€œa reasonable way to cast doubt on [the accompliceâ€™s] testimony implicating
  [Ellenburg].â€Â  Id. at 69, 625 S.E.2d at 226.Â  Additionally, because the
  defense opened the door to the polygraph issue, the solicitorâ€™s statement in
  closing was not improper.Â  Id.
In Watson v.
  State, 370 S.C. 68, 634 S.E.2d 642 (2006), our supreme court disagreed with
  the PCR court that defense counsel was ineffective for failing to object to certain
  hearsay testimony introduced in a criminal sexual conduct trial.Â  Counsel had
  reasonable strategy because she felt an objection would likely lead to the more
  damaging introduction of a videotape of the child victim talking about the
  abuse. Id. at 73, 634 S.E.2d at 644.
Our supreme court
  in Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 642 S.E.2d 590 (2007), found defense
  counsel ineffective for not more fully investigating and challenging gunshot
  residue when such evidence was crucial to the outcome of the case.Â 
  Specifically, defense counselâ€™s decision to not cross-examine the Stateâ€™s
  gunshot residue expert and instead focusing on the manner in which evidence was
  collected was not an objectively reasonable strategy.Â   
In
  the case sub judice, the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that Brownâ€™s counsel
  did not render ineffective assistance was based on counselâ€™s articulation of
  valid trial strategies.Â  Testimony
  from Brownâ€™s counsel at the post-conviction relief hearing revealed it was not
  his strategy to object to all issues generated in a trial because he felt doing
  so creates a negative impression with the jury.Â  Additionally, counsel
  testified the Stateâ€™s evidence made this as strong a case as he had seen.Â Â Â  He
  believed the best strategy was to highlight for the jury the discrepancies
  between the eyewitnessesâ€™ testimony and hope they would find it dubious.
It is manifest and irrefutable that trial counsel was NOT ineffective.Â  Apodictically, there was no legal or factual basis for an
  objection bottomed and premised on Doyle.Â  Trial counsel conducted a
  salutary and salubrious representation of Brown.Â   
b. PREJUDICE
The
  PCR court found that even if there were a failure to object, Brown failed to
  establish prejudice.Â  We decline to address this issue because of our
  disposition of Issues I and II.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold that trial counsel was not ineffective for failing to make certain
  objections because the record does not show a Doyle violation occurred.Â 
  Furthermore, we do NOT address the issue of prejudice because of
  our ruling on the Doyle issue.Â  Accordingly, Brownâ€™s conviction and
  sentence are
AFFIRMED.
Kittredge,
  J., concurs.
Hearn,
  C.J., concurs in result only in a separate opinion. 
HEARN,
  C.J., concurring in a separate opinion: I
  concur in the result reached by the majority, but would simply dismiss the writ
  of certiorari as improvidently granted.

title: Stalk v. State
description: In this PCR case, the issue posited is whether the PCR court committed error in granting relief where allegedly no evidence of prejudice was presented and where the plea court conducted a thorough and encompassing guilty plea proceeding.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James Stalk, Respondent, 
				
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


Appeal from Lancaster County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Post Conviction Judge
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Plea Judge
Opinion No. 4298
Heard September 11, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  5, 2007
REVERSED

Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Joseph L.
  Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  The post-conviction
  relief (PCR) court granted James Stalkâ€™s (Stalk) application for relief after
  finding Stalkâ€™s guilty plea was involuntary due to counselâ€™s unreasonable
  conduct and failure to prepare.Â  This court granted the Stateâ€™s petition to
  review the PCR courtâ€™s decision. Â We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Stalk was indicted on one count of
  first-degree burglary and six counts of second degree burglary, four counts of
  grand larceny, and one count of aggravated resisting arrest.Â  The first-degree
  burglary was reduced to second-degree.Â  Stalk pled guilty to all charges.Â  He
  was sentenced to (1) fifteen years imprisonment for the seven burglary charges,
  with one count served consecutively to the other six; (2) ten years for the
  grand larceny indictments, served consecutively to the burglary sentences; and
  (3) ten years for aggravated resisting arrest, served consecutively to the
  larceny sentences.Â  In the aggregate, Stalk was sentenced to fifty years
  imprisonment.  
Stalk
  agreed with and affirmed the Stateâ€™s recitation of the facts at the guilty plea
  proceeding. Â The State reported that officers investigating the burglary and
  larceny crimes identified Stalk as a suspect and visited his residence to
  question him.Â  While there, the officers observed a number of items in Stalkâ€™s
  apartment that had been reported stolen.Â  When they attempted to arrest Stalk he
  resisted and injured the officers in the struggle that ensued.Â  Â Â 
At the
  plea proceeding Stalk testified that he was thirty-two years old and had an
  eleventh grade education.Â  He worked in construction and was not married.Â  He
  admitted to treatment for drug abuse that he did not complete.Â  Stalk denied any
  physical or emotional problems that might prevent him from understanding why he
  was in court.Â  The plea court asked Stalk:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you understand that each of these seven indictments
  allege that you did in Lancaster County on the dates specified in the
  indictments willfully and unlawfully entered [sic] the dwellings of the persons
  specified in the indictments without consent and with the intent to commit a
  crime therein?Â  Do you understand that? 
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir. 
	. . . 
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you understand that the court could sentence you up to
  fifteen years in regard to each indictment for burglary in the second degree? 
	
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  In the four indictments charging you with grand larceny it
  is alleged that you did in Lancaster County on the dates specified in each of
  the four different indictments feloniously take and carry away the personal
  property of the said individuals named in the indictments with the intent to deprive
  the owners permanently of the possession of said property and that the property
  was valued at more than five thousand dollars in each of the four indictments.Â 
  Do you fully understand the charge of grand larceny?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you understand the court could have sentenced you up to
  ten years in regard to each of the four different indictments on each offense?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  The last indictment alleges that you did in Lancaster County on or about August 11, 1998, knowingly and willfully beat, injure or wound
  Captain Rollings and Lt. Bailey, law enforcement officers of this State, while
  resisting the efforts of said officers to place you under lawful arrest.Â  Do
  you understand this charge of resisting arrest . . . ?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you understand the court could sentence you to up to
  ten years in prison for a violation of that law?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you fully understand that adding all of the maximum
  sentences that could be imposed you could receive a sentence of up to one
  hundred and fifty-five years in prison on all of these charges?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir. 
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Understanding the
  charges contained in all of the separate indictments against you, understanding
  the maximum sentences you could receive, how do you wish to plead, guilty or
  not guilty?
	A. Â Â Â Â  Guilty.

The
  plea court advised Stalk that by entering a guilty plea he waived or gave up his
  constitutional rights to (1) remain silent and not be compelled to testify against
  himself; (2) be tried by a jury of peers or equals to which the State would be
  required to prove his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt; and (3) confront and
  cross-examine any witnesses the State called to testify against him at a trial
  of his case.Â  The court asked Stalk:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do
  you wish to give up these rights and plead guilty today?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.

Stalk
  professed he was not threatened or forced to plead guilty or promised anything in
  exchange for pleading guilty.Â  He confirmed he entered the plea of his own free
  will and accord. Â Stalk then stated he was guilty and he did commit the seven
  burglaries, four grand larcenies, and one resisting arrest as indicated in the
  factual record and in the indictments.Â  The plea court questioned Stalkâ€™s
  counsel as follows:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Have you had a full opportunity to explain to [Stalk] the
  charges contained in each of these bills of indictment, advise him of all of
  his constitutional rights as well as the maximum sentences he could receive?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Does
  Mr. Stalk fully understand these matters?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  I
  believe he does, your honor. 
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Does
  he indicate how he wishes to plead?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Guilty. 
	Q:Â Â Â  From your investigation of his cases do you agree with his Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  decision?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  I
  do, your honor. 

Stalk
  declared he was satisfied with his counselâ€™s representation in the following
  colloquy:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Are
  you satisfied with the services of your lawyer, Mr. [Â  ]?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Has
  he done everything you have asked him to do for you in regards
  to your cases?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes,
  sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Has
  he refused to do anything you have asked him to do?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  No,
  sir.

          The
  court accepted Stalkâ€™s plea of guilty, finding it was voluntarily, knowingly
  and intelligently made, with the advice and counsel of a competent lawyer with
  whom Stalk said he was satisfied.Â  Prior to sentencing, Stalkâ€™s counsel
  addressed the court:
[I]t is rare that anybody with near this number of pending charges
  would sit down with me and then later sit down with me and the solicitor and
  this is what I did.Â  While Mr. Stalk certainly is a burglar, he is an honest burglar,
  he told them exactly what happened and has not tried to hide from the
  consequences of his actions.Â  He had done some time in jail, got out, he was
  engaged, she was pregnant, he was unable to find work, and he resorted back to
  bad habits.Â  He has been in jail a while now, he understands that he could have
  been facing as you indicated a hundred and fifty-five years, he could have been
  facing a potential life sentence on the original charges, and I indicated to
  him that any sort of negotiations less than that would certainly be to his
  advantage.Â  He left it in my and the solicitorâ€™s hands to come up with this
  negotiation and he has cooperated in basically leaving it up to us and the
  State to come up with something less than the worse case scenario.Â  We ask for
  mercy.Â  
Stalk filed an application for post-conviction relief, which the
  PCR court granted.[1]Â 
  The State appealed and filed a petition for writ of certiorari in the Supreme Court.Â 
  The matter was transferred to this court and the Stateâ€™s petition granted.
ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
			 Did the PCR court err in finding Stalkâ€™s guilty plea was
  			rendered involuntary by the ineffective assistance of his counsel?Â  
			
		
		
			II.  
			 Did the PCR court err in granting relief when Stalk presented
  no evidence of prejudice?Â   
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
This court
  gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of
  law. Â Porter v. State, 368 S.C. 378, 383, 629 S.E.2d 353, 356 (2006). Â On
  review, a PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of
  probative value sufficient to support them. Â Id. (citing Cherry v.
    State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989)). Â However, where
  there is no evidence of probative value to support the findings of the PCR
  court, the appellate court will reverse. Â Bright v. State, 365 S.C. 355,
  358, 618 S.E.2d 296, 298 (2005); Magazine v. State, 361 S.C. 610, 615,
  606 S.E.2d 761, 763 (2004) (citing Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144,
  526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000)).Â Â Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The essential allegation raised by Stalk
  involves the involuntary nature of his guilty plea due to the alleged lack of
  preparation and unreasonable conduct of his appointed counsel.Â   
In the
  order granting Stalkâ€™s application for relief, the PCR court reasoned:

	[Stalk] testified that he was coerced by his counsel who seemingly
  was unprepared.Â  The applicant testified that his first meeting with his
  counsel, [ ], was in the presence of the prosecuting attorney, [ ]. Â The applicant
  further testified that his counsel never met with him to discuss his case,
  never discussed the pending charges, and never discussed possible defenses.Â 
  Despite having pleaded guilty and answering the Court in the affirmative at
  this guilty plea, the applicant testified that he understood that the sentences
  would all run concurrently.Â  The applicant further testified that he was
  coerced into pleading guilty because he had no confidence in his lawyer.Â  He
  stated that he would probably not have pled guilty had his lawyer been
  prepared.Â Â  
	Upon cross-examination, Mr. Stalk insisted that [his attorney]
  failed to call the co-defendant.Â  He also confirmed previous testimony that [his
  attorney] had only met with him once prior to entering the plea and that the
  meeting took place in the presence of the prosecuting attorney.Â  As such [Stalk]
  was unduly coerced into the plea agreement and would have otherwise insisted on
  going to trial. 

The PCR court
  concluded:

	[Stalk] has established that he did not receive effective
  assistance from his court appointed attorney.Â  This Court further finds that
  the State has offered no evidence to refute the allegations of [Stalk].Â 
  Furthermore, this Court finds that due to the conduct of [Stalk]â€™s attorney,
  [Stalk] was prejudiced in not having the opportunity to go forward with trial.Â 
  Based on [Stalk]â€™s unrefuted testimony, this Court finds that there is a
  reasonable probability that [Stalk] would have insisted on going to trial.Â  Â Â Â Â 
	

The State
  contends that the PCR court erred in granting Stalk relief. Â We agree.Â   
In a PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief. Â Suber v. State, 371 S.C. 554, 558, 640 S.E.2d 884,
  886 (2007) (citing Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514,
  517 (2000)); Bannister v. State, 333 S.C. 298, 302, 509 S.E.2d 807, 809
  (1998).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered adequate
  assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all
  significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Morris v. State, 371 S.C. 278, 282,
  639 S.E.2d 53, 55 (2006); Magazine v. State, 361 S.C. 610, 617, 606
  S.E.2d 761, 764 (2004).  
Strickland
  v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984), established a two-prong test for
  evaluating claims of ineffective assistance of counsel. Â The first prong of the
  test requires that a defendant prove his counselâ€™s deficiency by demonstrating
  counselâ€™s performance fell below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  Bennett
    v. State, 371 S.C. 198, 203, 638 S.E.2d 673, 675 (2006) (citing Strickland).
  Â The second part of the test requires a defendant to show there is a reasonable
  probability that, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the
  proceeding would have been different.Â  Id.Â   
An
  applicant may attack the voluntary, knowing, and intelligent character of a
  guilty plea entered on the advice of counsel by demonstrating that counselâ€™s
  representation was below an objective standard of reasonableness. Â Porter v.
    State, 368 S.C. 378, 383-84, 629 S.E.2d 353, 356 (2006); Roscoe v. State,
  345 S.C. 16, 20, 546 S.E.2d 417, 419 (2001).Â  The â€œprejudice,â€ requirement
  focuses on whether counselâ€™s constitutionally ineffective performance affected
  the outcome of the plea process.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 59 (1985).Â  In other words, the applicant must prove prejudice by showing that,
  but for counselâ€™s inadequacy, there is a reasonable probability he would not
  have pleaded guilty and, instead, would have insisted on going to trial.Â  Suber,
  371 S.C. at 558, 640 S.E.2d at 886.Â   
To find
  a guilty plea is voluntarily and knowingly entered into, the record must establish
  the defendant had a full understanding of the consequences of his plea and the
  charges against him. Â Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 242 (1969); Roddy
    v. State, 339 S.C. 29, 33-34, 528 S.E.2d 418, 421 (2000).Â  â€œA defendantâ€™s
  knowing and voluntary waiver of the constitutional rights which accompany a
  guilty plea may be accomplished by colloquy between the Court and the
  defendant, between the Court and defendantâ€™s counsel, or both.â€Â  Pittman v.
    State, 337 S.C. 597, 625, 524 S.E.2d 623, 659 (1999).Â   
â€œ[T]he
  voluntariness of a guilty plea is not determined by an examination of the
  specific inquiry made by the sentencing judge alone, but is determined from
  both the record made at the time of the entry of the guilty plea and the record
  of the post-conviction hearing.â€Â  Harres v. Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 133,
  318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984).Â  â€œWhen determining issues relating to guilty pleas,
  this Court will consider the entire record, including the transcript of the
  guilty pleas and the evidence presented at the PCR hearing.â€Â  Roddy, 339
  S.C. at 33, 528 S.E.2d at 420. Â In considering an allegation on PCR that a
  guilty plea was based on inaccurate advice of counsel, the transcript of the
  guilty plea hearing will be considered to determine whether any possible error by
  counsel was cured by the information conveyed at the plea hearing. Â Wolfe v.
    State, 326 S.C. 158, 165, 485 S.E.2d 367, 370 (1997).Â   
1. Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
Stalk claimed
  his attorney met with him only one time prior to the plea hearing and was
  inadequately prepared.Â  He asserted counsel did not go over the warrants, did
  not ask him about potential defenses or witnesses, did not inform him of his
  right to a jury trial, and did not ask about Stalkâ€™s sentencing expectations.Â  Stalk
  admitted his attorney told him that he faced a potential one hundred fifty-five
  year aggregate sentence if convicted at trial.Â  Additionally, Stalk averred he
  only had ten or fifteen minutes to make up his mind about whether to plead
  guilty.Â  He stated he felt coerced to plead guilty because he lacked confidence
  in his attorney.  
Testimony
  from Stalkâ€™s counsel at the plea hearing indicated he first sat down with Stalk
  alone and then â€œlaterâ€ sat down with Stalk and the Solicitor.Â  Counsel believed
  Stalk understood he could face one hundred fifty-five yearsâ€”a potential life
  sentenceâ€”if found guilty at trial.Â  Consequently, he advised Stalk that any
  negotiation resulting in less time would be to his advantage.Â   
On
  cross-examination at the PCR hearing, Stalk initially stated he met with his
  attorney one time, in the presence of the Solicitor.Â  However, on redirect,
  Stalkâ€™s testimony suggests he met with counsel earlier in the day before
  meeting with counsel and the Solicitor:Â   

	
		
			Q:  
			[Your attorney] indicates in his 
			statement to the court that he had met with you prior toâ€”how soon 
			prior to that guilty plea did he meet with you?  He said he met 
			with you before meeting with you and [the Solicitor].  How much 
			time elapsed from that first meeting and your meeting withâ€”
 
		
		
			Stalk: 
			 On the same day.
 
		
		
			Q:  
			Was it the same day?
 
		
		
			Stalk:  
			The same day it was a bond 
			hearing and I met with him about a bond hearing.  
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Prior to meeting with him and 
			[the Solicitor] did you met with [your attorney] also that same day 
			before meeting with [the Solicitor]?
 
		
		
			Stalk:   
			I met with him here, back here.
			
 
		
	

In our
  view, Stalkâ€™s conflicting testimony provides little reliable evidence that he
  met only once with his attorney.
We do
  not agree with the PCR court that Stalk established ineffective assistance of
  his court appointed attorney.Â  In basing his finding on Stalkâ€™s â€œunrefuted
  testimony,â€ the PCR court apparently disregarded Stalkâ€™s testimony at the plea
  hearing.Â  Stalkâ€™s PCR testimony blatantly and completely contradicted his
  earlier attestations at the plea hearing concerning the voluntariness of his guilty
  plea.Â  At the PCR proceeding Stalk averred:

	
		
			Stalk:
			When I went up there, mostly I 
			was talking to the Judge.  He asked me did I understand what 
			was going on and I said, â€œYes.â€  He asked me did I know what I 
			was pleading to and I said, â€œYes.â€
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Why did you say that?  When 
			he was asking you these questions, did you really understand what he 
			was asking?
 
		
		
			Stalk: 
			No, I was still mixed up.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Why didnâ€™t you stop him and tell 
			him you didnâ€™t understand?
 
		
		
			Stalk:
			I donâ€™t know, I donâ€™t know.   
			
 
		
	

The
  transcript of the guilty plea clearly refutes Stalkâ€™s assertion that he did not
  understand the terms of the guilty plea.Â  See Rayford v. State,
  314 S.C. 46, 48-49, 443 S.E.2d 805, 806 (1994) (where transcript of guilty plea
  proceeding refuted applicantâ€™s claim that he did not understand the terms of a
  plea bargain, grant of PCR was inappropriate notwithstanding applicantâ€™s claim
  lawyer misadvised him); see also Moorehead v. State, 329 S.C.
  329, 333, 496 S.E.2d 415, 417 (1998) (â€œRespondentâ€™s explanation that he
  answered the trial court affirmatively on counselâ€™s alleged advice that the
  questions were meaningless does not support the grant of PCR.â€).Â   
The
  plea colloquy record indicates Stalk was fully informed of his constitutional
  rights, understood the crimes with which he was charged, and was cognizant of
  the maximum sentences he might receive.Â  Any possible misconceptions concerning
  his constitutional rights, the charges, or potential sentences on Stalkâ€™s part
  were cured by the colloquy during the essentially perfect plea proceeding
  conducted by the learned judge.Â  See Pittman, 337 S.C. at 625,
  524 S.E.2d at 659; Wolfe, 326 S.C. at 165, 485 S.E.2d at 370.Â Â   
2.Â Â Prejudice
Stalk maintained
  that he â€œprobably would have requested a jury trialâ€ had his attorney spent
  time with him, properly prepared his case, and informed him of the charges and
  penalties he faced.Â  Although Stalk claimed his attorney did not â€œdo what he
  was supposed to do,â€ he was unable to tell the court what his attorney could
  have done to help his case.Â   

	
		
			Stalk:    
			I would have advised him to bring 
			my co-defendant, my co-defendant on the same charges I got. 
 
		
		
			Q:  
			Iâ€™m not sure if I am following 
			you.  You are saying that you would have wanted your 
			co-defendant indicted for the same charges?
 
		
		
			Stalk:   
			Yes, sir. 
 
		
		
			Q. 
			Well, how would that have helped 
			your case?
 
		
		
			Stalk:
			I donâ€™t know, but it would 
			probably be more than it did.
		
	

If, in
  fact, Stalk meant to suggest his attorney should have called the co-defendant
  as a witness, he still failed to show how he was prejudiced by the lack of that
  testimony.Â  â€œThis Court has repeatedly held a PCR applicant must produce the
  testimony of a favorable witness or otherwise offer the testimony in accordance
  with the rules of evidence at the PCR hearing in order to establish prejudice
  from the witnessâ€™ failure to testify at trial.â€Â  Bannister v. State, 333
  S.C. 298, 303, 509 S.E.2d 807, 809 (1998); see, e.g., Pauling v.
    State, 331 S.C. 606, 503 S.E.2d 468 (1998); Glover v. State, 318
  S.C. 496, 458 S.E.2d 538 (1995); Underwood v. State, 309 S.C. 560, 425
  S.E.2d 20 (1992); Jackson v. State, 329 S.C. 345, 495 S.E.2d 768
  (1998).Â  Mere speculation of what a witnessâ€™ testimony may be is insufficient
  to satisfy the burden of showing prejudice in a petition for PCR. Â Porter v.
    State, 368 S.C. 378, 386-87, 629 S.E.2d 353, 358 (2006) (holding no
  evidence showedÂ  counselâ€™s failure to interview a potential witness would have
  yielded a result different from that which defendantâ€™s counsel believed at the
  time of the plea; defendant pled guilty in light of the complete information
  that was available at that time).  
In addition, Stalk testified he believed his sentences would run
  concurrently rather than consecutively, suggesting he would not have pled
  guilty had he known otherwise.Â  There is no evidence, whatsoever, in the
  record, prior to Stalkâ€™s PCR testimony, that he was induced to plead guilty
  based his understanding the sentences would run concurrently.Â  â€œWishful thinking
  regarding sentencing does not equal a misapprehension concerning the possible
  range of sentences, especially where one acknowledges on the record that one
  knows the range of sentences and that no promises have been made.â€Â  Wolfe,
  326 S.C. at 165, 485 S.E.2d at 371.Â  Moreover, counselâ€™s plea negotiations for Stalk
  proved advantageous.Â  The first degree burglary count was reduced to second
  degree, and Stalk received a sentence considerably less than the one hundred
  fifty-five years he might have received if convicted by a jury.Â  See Bright
    v. State, 365 S.C. 355, 360, 618 S.E.2d 296, 298 (2005) (reversing PCR
  courtâ€™s grant of relief when defense counsel negotiated favorable plea on
  respondentâ€™s behalf).
CONCLUSION
Although
  this court generally affords great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings, in
  this case we conclude the record is devoid of any probative evidence to support
  granting Stalk post-conviction relief.Â  Accordingly, we REVERSE the
  decision of the PCR court and REINSTATE Stalkâ€™s guilty plea and
  sentences.  
HEARN, C.J. and KITTREDGE, J. concur.

[1] Stalkâ€™s attorney was not available to testify at
  the PCR hearing.Â  The PCR court held the record open for the submission of his
  testimony by deposition.Â  However, Stalkâ€™s counsel remained unavailable and
  attempts to depose him were unsuccessful.Â  The record on appeal includes
  Stalkâ€™s PCR testimony, the transcript of the plea hearing, and other records of
  the Clerk of Court.Â
