title: Miller v. Miller
description: In this family court case, the appellate entity addresses several issues; (1) criminal contempt as juxtaposed to civil contempt in the family court arena and (2) an award of attorneyâ€™s fees bottomed and premised upon a contempt order by the family court.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mary E. Miller, Respondent,
				v.
				Burl E. Miller, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4299
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October 5, 2007

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Burl E.
  Miller, Jr., of Savannah, Georgia, Appellant Pro Se .
				Mary E.
  Miller of Greenville, Respondent Pro Se.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.: Â Burl E. Miller, Jr. (Husband) contends the family court erred
  by: (1) holding him in contempt for barring Respondentâ€™s (Wifeâ€™s) entry into
  the marital home to retrieve property, removing property from the marital home,
  and secreting the property in another location; (2) requiring the return of certain
  property to Wife; (3) failing to find Wife in contempt; and (4) ordering him to
  pay a portion of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Wife initiated an action
  for separate support and maintenance, equitable division of marital property,
  and other related relief in August of 2004.Â  Husband and Wife reached an
  agreement resolving all issues on a temporary basis.Â  The family court approved
  the partiesâ€™ agreement as the Temporary Order of the Court, finding â€œ[b]oth
  parties expressed their opinion that they believed the [temporary] agreement to
  be in their best interests . . . .Â  The parties further affirmed their
  understanding that their agreement will be set forth in a Temporary Order of
  this Court, and as such, that the agreement is enforceable by the contempt
  powers of this Court.â€Â   
The Temporary Order provided,
  in pertinent part, that:

	1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The
  former marital home will be placed on the market for sale, with the [Husband]
  making necessary repairs to the master bathroom, the kitchen ceiling, and the
  fountain in the front yard.Â  [Husband] will replace the original locks on the
  doors and replace the doorknobs.
	2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  [Husband]
  will make the monthly mortgage payment on the home, in the approximate amount
  of $2,200.00 and [Wife] will pay for the lawn maintenance.Â  The parties will
  split the utility bills for the home while it is on the market . . . .
	3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Each
  party will keep the vehicle in his or her respective possession and pay the
  expenses of said vehicles. Â The parties will each obtain insurance on the
  vehicles in his or her possession, and neither will list the other as a driver
  on the othersâ€™ automobile insurance policy.
	. . .
	8.Â Â Â Â Â Â  [Wife]
  will remove all remaining property from the former residence, to prepare it for
  sale, and she will store such property at her residence. 
	9. Â Â Â Â Â  The
  parties will be mutually restrained from liquidating or transferring any
  marital assets or property of any type to other parties, hiding or secreting
  said property and/or assets and/or removing money from any bank accounts other
  than those necessary to pay the monthly household bills and expenses.Â  Â 

Wife vacated the marital
  home shortly after the parties separated in order to prepare the home for sale.Â 
  Husband lived with his parents when the parties separated but moved back into
  the home in October, 2004, and remained there until the end of November, 2004.
On several occasions
  Wife attempted to gain access to the marital home to retrieve remaining property
  as directed by the Temporary Order.Â  Wife testified Husband prevented her from
  entering the marital home.Â  Witnesses Sandy Weaver and Genie Shealy generally corroborated
  Wifeâ€™s testimony that Husband had not allowed her entry into the home after
  several attempts.Â  Wife averred Husband changed the locks on the doors without
  her knowledge or consent, making entry impossible.Â   
On one occasion Wife pre-arranged
  a time with Husband to remove the remaining items from the home.Â  She rented a
  U-Haul truck and enlisted the help of several family members.Â  Wife claimed
  Husband had one weekâ€™s notice of this scheduled removal.Â  However, on the day
  Wife and her family planned to secure the property, Husbandâ€™s friend,
  apparently acting on Husbandâ€™s behalf, barred them from entering the home.Â  When
  wife eventually entered the home on a later date, she found the remaining property
  she was to retrieve pursuant to the Temporary Order, including a vintage Ford
  Mustang, had been removed.Â   
On cross-examination
  Wife admitted she had alternative access to the home through the garage door.Â 
  However, Wifeâ€™s attorney had advised her not to enter the home on her own while
  Husband was living there.Â   
Husband denied he
  hindered Wifeâ€™s entry into the home, maintaining he prevented her entry at the
  originally appointed time only because he had to go out of town and needed to
  reschedule.Â  He claimed she could have arranged to enter at a later time.Â 
  Husband acknowledged, however, that he had removed items, including the Ford
  Mustang, from the marital home and was currently storing property in a another
  location.
Wife filed an initial
  Rule to Show Cause motion on or about December 7, 2004, charging, inter alia,
  that Husband had refused to allow Wife access to the marital home to retrieve
  remaining property as ordered by the Court.Â  Wife filed an Amended Contempt
  Complaint on January 27, 2005, for additional violations of the Temporary
  Order, alleging Husband (1) refused to cooperate in the preparation and sale of
  the marital home, (2) changed the locks on the doors of the marital home, (3) prevented
  her from retrieving her personal belongings, and (4) moved the majority of her
  belongings to another state without Wifeâ€™s knowledge or consent.  
Husband filed a Rule to
  Show Cause, Answer and Counterclaim against Wife on February 9, 2005,
  complaining that Wife violated the Temporary Order by failing to (1) return
  business records and computer accessories, (2) pay for lawn maintenance, and (3)
  remove and store at her residence the remaining property in the marital home.Â 
 
The family court found Husband
  in contempt for barring Wife from entering the marital home to retrieve
  remaining property and ordered him to return the Ford Mustang and all its parts
  to Wife within thirty (30) days of the hearing.[2] Â Wife was ordered to return business records and computer accessories to
  Husband within thirty (30) days.  
Husband filed a Motion
  for Reconsideration.Â  In an Amended Order dated March 31, 2005, noting that neither
  party proved all the allegations set forth in his or her Contempt Complaint, the
  family court held:

	6.Â Â Â Â Â Â  It is explicit and unequivocal
  that [Husband] is in willful contempt of this Court for refusing to allow [Wife]
  to retrieve her personal belongings from the marital home, for removing the
  belongings from the marital home, and from South Carolina, and for secreting
  the belongings in or near Savannah, Georgia, without [Wife]â€™s knowledge or
  consent which he no right to do.Â  This has been proven to a clear and
  convincing standard of proof.Â  The [temporary] order clearly allows and
  required the [Wife] to remove all marital property from the marital home. Â [Husband]
  should, and hereby shall, return [Wife]â€™s property to her, at his own expense,
  within thirty (30) days of this Order.Â  This includes the Ford Mustang
  automobile and all parts, at an agreed upon location and time and in the
  condition as when removed.Â  Should [Husband] not return the property within
  that time, he shall immediately begin serving a sentence of twelve (12) months
  incarceration in the Greenville County Detention Center. Â [Husband] to be
  released by the return of such property.Â  The act of removal and the act of
  barring the wife is criminal contempt.Â  These acts have been proven beyond a
  reasonable doubt.Â  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . .  

	8.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The [Husband] did change the
  locks on the doors and occupy the marital home, thereby making it impossible
  for the wife to enter the home.Â  He or his friend actually barred the [Wife].Â 
  The Court further finds that [Wife] did not enter the marital home to retrieve
  her personal belongings, as set forth in the Temporary Order, due to the [Husband]â€™s
  preventing [Wife] from doing so.Â  Therefore, the Court finds that [Wife] is not
  in contempt on such charges. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

ISSUES

	I. Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err and abuse its discretion in
  finding Â Husband in contempt for refusing to allow Wife to retrieve remaining
  property from the marital home, removing the property from the marital home,
  and secreting the property in or near Savannah, Georgia? 
	II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err in finding Husband in
  criminal contempt?
	III.Â Â Â  Did the family court err in ordering Husband to return
  the Ford Mustang and all parts to Wife?
	IV.Â Â Â  Did the family court err in finding Wife was not in
  contempt for failure to remove and store remaining property from the marital
  home because Husband prevented her from entering the home to retrieve the
  property? 
	V.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err and abuse its discretion in
  ordering Husband to pay two-thirds (2/3) of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in
  the amount of $5,321.63?

Husband contends
  the family court erred in not finding Wife in contempt for failure to pay for
  lawn maintenance.Â  The family court did not rule on this issue at the hearing
  or in the Amended Order, and Husband neglected to raise it in his Motion for
  Reconsideration.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved and we decline to
  address it on review.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  appellate court should reverse a decision regarding contempt â€œonly if it is
  without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused his discretion.â€ Â Durlach
    v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 70, 596 S.E.2d 908, 912 (2004) (quoting Stone
      v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840 (1988)); see also Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989)
  (â€œA finding of contempt rests within the sound discretion of the trial
  judge.â€).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is
  controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of
  fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Â Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70,
  73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
â€œA determination of contempt
  is a serious matter and should be imposed sparingly; whether it is or is not
  imposed is within the discretion of the trial judge, which will not be
  disturbed on appeal unless it is without evidentiary support.â€ Â Floyd v.
    Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 72, 615 S.E.2d 465, 473 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Haselwood
      v. Sullivan, 283 S.C. 29, 32-33, 320 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1984)). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â CONTEMPT
â€œThe power to punish for
  contempt is inherent in all courts. Â Its existence is essential to the
  preservation of order in judicial proceedings, and to the enforcement of the
  judgments, orders and writs of the courts, and consequently to the due
  administration of justice.â€ Â Floyd, 365 S.C. at 73, 615 S.E.2d at 474 (quoting Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1982)); State
    v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 38, 615 S.E.2d 455, 462 (Ct. App. 2005); see
      also In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998) (â€œThe
  power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to
  preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€); State ex rel. McLeod v.
    Hite, 272 S.C. 303, 306, 251 S.E.2d 746, 748 (1979) (instructing that a
  court has the inherent authority to punish offenses calculated to obstruct,
  degrade, and undermine the administration of justice, and such power cannot be
  abridged).
The United States
  Supreme Court discussed the courtâ€™s contempt power in an 1888 case, In re
    Terry:

	[C]ourts of
  justice are universally acknowledged to be vested, by their very creation, with
  power to impose silence, respect, and decorum in their presence, and submission
  to their lawful mandates. . . . Â â€œThe power to punish for contempts is inherent
  in all courts. Â Its existence is essential to the preservation of order in
  judicial proceedings, and to the enforcement of the judgments, orders, and
  writs of the courts; and consequently to the due administration of justice. Â The
  moment the courts of the United States were called into existence and invested
  with jurisdiction over any subject, they became possessed of this power.â€ Â And
  such is the recognized doctrine in reference to the powers of the courts of the
  several states. . . . Â â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in the
  nature and constitution of a court. Â It is a power not derived from any
  statute, but arising from necessity; implied, because it is necessary to the
  exercise of all other powers.â€Â  Without such power . . . the administration of
  the law would be in continual danger of being thwarted by the lawless. Â 

128 U.S. 289, 303 (1888) (internal
  citations omitted) (quoted with approval in State v. Goff, 228 S.C. 17,
  22-23, 88 S.E.2d 788, 790-91 (1955)).  
â€œContempt results from the willful
  disobedience of an order of the court.â€ Â Bigham v. Bigham, 264 S.C. 101,
  104, 212 S.E.2d 594, 596 (1975); Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396,
  597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2004) (A
  party may be found in contempt of court for the willful violation of a lawful
  court order.).Â  â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and
  intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with
  the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that
  is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™ â€ Widman
    v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79,
  82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)). Â â€œWhere a
  contemnor is unable, without fault on his part, to obey an order of the court,
  he is not to be held in contempt.â€ Â Smith-Cooper v. Cooper, 344 S.C.
  289, 301, 543 S.E.2d 271, 277 (Ct. App. 2001).
The determination of contempt
  ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the trial judge. Â State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447
  S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation
  of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and
  the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€ Â Hawkins
    v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004); Eaddy
      v. Oliver, 345 S.C. 39, 42, 545 S.E.2d 830, 832 (Ct. App. 2001). Â â€œ[B]efore
  a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically
  reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Â Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d
  at 705. Â â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden
  then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to
  comply with the order.â€Â  Id. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIt is within the trial courtâ€™s
  discretion to punish by fine or imprisonment all contempts of authority before
  the court.â€ Brandt v. Gooding, 368 S.C. 618, 628, 630 S.E.2d 259, 264
  (2006) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-5-320 (1976)). Â â€œIn addition, courts have
  the inherent power to punish for offenses that are calculated to obstruct,
  degrade, and undermine the administration of justice.â€ Id. (citing State
    ex rel. McLeod v. Hite, 272 S.C. 303, 305, 251 S.E.2d 746, 747 (1979)).Â  
 
A.Â Direct v. Constructive Contempt
â€œDirect contempt is defined as contemptuous
  conduct occurring in the presence of the court.â€Â  State v. Kennerly, 331
  S.C. 442, 450, 503 S.E.2d 214, 219 (Ct. App. 1998) affâ€™d by 337 S.C.
  617, 524 S.E.2d 837 (1999) (citing Â State v. Goff, 228 S.C. 17, 88
  S.E.2d 788 (1955)). Â â€œSouth Carolina courts have always taken a liberal and
  expansive view of the â€˜presenceâ€™ and â€˜courtâ€™ requirements.Â  This Stateâ€™s courts
  have held the â€˜presence of the courtâ€™ extends beyond the mere physical presence
  of the judge or the courtroom to encompass all elements of the system.â€ Â Kennerly,
  337 S.C. at 620, 524 S.E.2d at 838.Â  â€œ[T]he court consists not of the judge,
  the jury, or the jury room individually, but all of these combined. Â The court
  is present wherever any of its constituent parts is engaged in the prosecution
  of the business of the court according to the law.â€Â  Id. at 620-21, 524
  S.E.2d at 838 (citing Goff, 228 S.C. at 23, 88 S.E.2d at 791).Â  Â 
â€œConstructive contempt is contemptuous conduct
  occurring outside the presence of the court.â€ Â Kennerly, 331 S.C. at
  451, 503 S.E.2d at 219 (citing Toyota of Florence, Inc. v. Lynch, 314
  S.C. 257, 442 S.E.2d 611 (1994)).  
â€œThe distinction between direct and constructive
  contempt is important because it determines how the contempt proceedings must
  be brought.â€Â  Id. â€œA rule to show cause for direct contempt may be
  issued without a supporting affidavit or verified petition.â€Â  Id.Â 
  However, a charge of constructive contempt brought by a rule to show cause must
  be based on an affidavit or verified petition.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe failure to
  support the rule to show cause by an affidavit or verified petition is a fatal
  defect.â€Â  Lynch, 314 S.C. at 267, 442 S.E.2d at 617.Â   
In Kennerly, the pivotal question was
  whether the contemnorâ€™s conduct constituted direct or constructive contempt. Â Kennerly
  was a juror in a capital murder trial in which the defendant was found guilty
  and received a sentence of life imprisonment rather than the death penalty.Â  Kennerly,
  331 S.C. at 446-49, 503 S.E.2d at 216-18. Â The solicitor filed a petition
  alleging Kennerly was in contempt of court for failing to disclose her
  relationship with the defendant during voir dire and for
  initiating premature discussions with other jurors in violation of the judgeâ€™s
  instructions.Â  Id.Â  The trial court found Kennerly guilty of contempt
  and she appealed, arguing the solicitorâ€™s rule to show cause was not based upon
  a sworn affidavit or a verified pleading. Â Id. at 449-50, 503 S.E.2d at
  18.Â  She maintained the contemptuous conduct was not direct contempt because it
  occurred outside the presence of the court.Â  Likewise, she averred the
  solicitorâ€™s unverified petition was fatal to a charge of constructive contempt.
  Â Id. Â 
The court found Kennerlyâ€™s conduct occurred where
  the jury was required to be, in the jury room and hotel where sequestered, and
  while the jurors were performing their legal duties.Â  â€œBecause Kennerlyâ€™s
  conduct occurred within the sight and hearing of an integral and constituent
  part of the court, her conduct was â€˜in the presence of the courtâ€™ and
  constituted direct contempt.â€Â  Kennerly, 337 S.C. at 622, 524 S.E.2d at
  839.Â  Kennerlyâ€™s behavior was not constructive contempt, and, therefore, the
  absence of an affidavit or verified petition was not fatal to the solicitorâ€™s
  action.
B. Â Civil v. Criminal Contempt
The determination of whether
  contempt is civil or criminal depends on the underlying purpose of the contempt
  ruling.Â  In Floyd v. Floyd, we provided
  a comprehensive review of the differences between civil and criminal contempt:

	The major factor in determining whether
  a contempt is civil or criminal is the purpose for which the power is
  exercised, including the nature of the relief and the purpose for which the
  sentence is imposed. Â The purpose of civil contempt is to coerce the defendant
  to do the thing required by the order for the benefit of the complainant.
	The primary purposes of criminal contempt
  are to preserve the courtâ€™s authority and to punish for disobedience of its
  orders. Â If it is for civil contempt the punishment is remedial, and for the
  benefit of the complainant. Â But if it is for criminal contempt the sentence is
  punitive, to vindicate the authority of the court.
	An unconditional penalty is criminal in
  nature because it is solely and exclusively punitive in nature.Â  The relief cannot
  undo or remedy what has been done nor afford any compensation and the contemnor
  cannot shorten the term by promising not to repeat his offense. Â If the relief
  provided is a sentence of imprisonment,Â  . . . it is punitive if the sentence
  is limited to imprisonment for a definite period. Â If the sanction is a fine,
  it is punitive when it is paid to the court. Â However, a fine that is payable
  to the court may be remedial when the contemnor can avoid paying the fine
  simply by performing the affirmative act required by the courtâ€™s order.
	In civil contempt cases, the sanctions
  are conditioned on compliance with the courtâ€™s order. Â The conditional nature
  of the punishment renders the relief civil in nature because the contemnor can
  end the sentence and discharge himself at any moment by doing what he had
  previously refused to do. Â If the relief provided is a sentence of
  imprisonment, it is remedial if the defendant stands committed unless and until
  he performs the affirmative act required by the courtâ€™s order . . . . Â Those
  who are imprisoned until they obey the order, carry the keys of their prison in
  their own pockets.Â  If the sanction is a fine, it is remedial and civil if paid
  to the complainant even though the contemnor has no opportunity to purge
  himself of the fine or if the contemnor can avoid the fine by complying with
  the courtâ€™s order.

365 S.C. 56, 75-76, 615 S.E.2d 465,
  475-76 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Â Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 111-12,
  502 S.E.2d 86, 88-89 (1998)).
The distinction between civil and criminal
  contempt is critical, because criminal contempt triggers additional constitutional
  safeguards.Â  Civil contempt must be proved by clear
  and convincing evidence.Â  Durlach v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 71, 596
  S.E.2d 908, 912 (2004).Â  In a criminal contempt proceeding, the burden
  of proof is beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Floyd, 365 S.C. at 76, 615 S.E.2d at 76. Â Intent for purposes of criminal contempt is subjective, not
  objective, and must necessarily be ascertained from all the acts, words, and
  circumstances surrounding the occurrence.Â  State v. Passmore, 363 S.C.
  568, 572, 611 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v.
    Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994)).
In Bloom v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 194 (1968)
  the Supreme Court held prosecutions for serious criminal contempts are subject
  to the jury trial protections of the Sixth Amendment.Â  Subsequently, in Codispoti
    v. Pennsylvania, 418 U.S. 506, (1974), the Supreme Court held criminal
  defendants sentence to imprisonment of more than six (6) months are entitled to
  a jury trial. Â See Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 383, 287 S.E.2d
  915, 918 (1982); Passmore, 363 S.C. at 572,
  611 S.E.2d at 275.  
â€œIncarceration
  under certain factual circumstances may be included as a component of civil
  contempt.â€Â  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd, 350 S.C. 596, 609, 567
  S.E.2d 514, 521 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, unlike the constitutional protection
  afforded a criminal contemnor, the United States Supreme Court has held that a
  civil contempt proceeding resulting in incarceration does not require a jury
  trial. Â Shillitani v. U.S., 384 U.S. 364 (1966). Â In Shillitani,
  two witnesses refused to testify before a grand jury after being given
  immunity. Â 384 U.S. at 365.Â  They were sentenced to two years imprisonment for
  contempt of court with the provision for release if they answered the grand
  juryâ€™s questions.Â  Id.Â  The court reasoned the character and purpose of
  the contempt rendered it civil rather than criminal.Â  Id. at 368. Â The
  sentence of imprisonment was conditional, imposed for the obvious purpose of
  compelling the two grand jury witnesses to obey the courtâ€™s orders to testify.Â  Id. at 370.Â  â€œWhile any imprisonment has punitive and deterrent
  effects, it must be viewed as remedial if the court conditions the release upon
  the contemnorâ€™s willingness to [obey a courtâ€™s order].â€Â  Id. â€œThe
  conditional nature of the imprisonment, based entirely upon the contemnorâ€™s
  continued defiance, justified holding civil contempt proceedings absent the
  safeguards of indictment and a jury.â€Â  Id. at 370-71.
In Curlee v. Howle our supreme court followed
  the Shillitani test to determine whether a jury trial was warranted in a
  contempt proceeding.Â  277 S.C. at 382, 287 S.E.2d at 917.Â  A father who willfully
  disregarded a family court order was sentenced to one year of confinement,
  suspended upon paying the mother $14,960.43. Â Id. Â The court first asked
  whether the contempt was civil or criminal.Â  Looking to the purpose of the
  contempt finding, it was obviously to compel the contemnor to pay the expenses,
  not punishment.Â  The court concluded â€œthe conditional nature of the
  imprisonment, based entirely upon [the father]â€™s refusal to pay [the mother]â€™s
  expenses, justified holding the civil contempt proceeding without a jury
  trial.â€Â Â  Â 
C.Â Â The Case Sub Judice
Husband argues the family courtâ€™s findings are
  without evidentiary support.Â  Specifically, Husband contends there is no
  evidence that he willfully violated the terms of the Temporary Order by barring
  Wife from entering the marital home, preventing her from retrieving her
  belongings, and secreting her belongings in another location.Â  Moreover,
  Husband alleges the family court erred in ordering Husband to return the Ford
  Mustang and all its parts to Wife.Â  We disagree.

	1.Â Â Marital Property

The record clearly reflects Husbandâ€™s contemptuous
  conduct.Â  The Temporary Order allowed and required Wife to remove all marital property from the marital home.Â  The Order unequivocally stated: â€œ[Wife] will remove all remaining property from the former
  residence, to prepare it for sale, and she will store such property at her
  residence.â€ Â 
Wife and two witnesses attested to the fact
  Husband willfully interfered with Wifeâ€™s attempts to effectuate the Temporary
  Order.Â  Evidence showed the Husband had moved back into the marital home,
  changed locks, and thwarted Wifeâ€™s scheduled entry to remove remaining property
  as ordered.Â  When Wife eventually gained access to the marital home, she
  discovered the remaining property, including the vintage Ford Mustang, had been
  removed.Â   
Husband does not dispute the existence of a valid
  court order requiring Wife to remove remaining property.Â  He claims, instead,
  that the Temporary Order is unclear, ambiguous, and did not specifically
  prohibit him from removing property from the marital home.Â  Referring to the
  relevant provisions of the Temporary Order, the family court reasoned â€œitâ€™s
  obvious that property was to be there and all other property other than whatâ€™s
  set forth here was to be at that house and sheâ€™s to take possession of it.â€Â 
  â€œAs to the personal property, it is explicit and unequivocal that the wife was
  to be allowed to retrieve it, she was to get it all.â€Â   
Husband denied he took any of Wifeâ€™s property to Savannah, Georgia.Â  He attributed the removal of Wifeâ€™s property to people helping him move
  out of the marital home at the end of November.Â  However, Husband did
  intentionally relocate the Ford Mustang to another location.Â  He insisted the
  provision in the Temporary Order requiring that â€œ[e]ach
  party will keep the vehicle in his or her respective possession and pay the
  expenses of said vehiclesâ€ permitted his moving the automobile.  
The 1970 Mach I Ford
  Mustang was basically a chassis, without the engine parts, in the process of
  being restored.Â  Though at the time of the Temporary Order Husband was not
  living in the marital home where the automobile was stored, he, nevertheless,
  claimed possession of all body and interior parts.Â  Wife, on the other hand,
  maintained the vehicle was part of the â€œremaining propertyâ€ that she was
  ordered to retrieve and store.Â   
Husband
  urges the language of the Temporary Order does not accurately reflect the
  record of the temporary hearing.Â  He claims the agreement at the hearing was
  that Wife would remove remaining â€œfurnishings,â€ not â€œremaining property.â€Â 
  Husband relies on this discrepancy to argue the Ford Mustang was not part of
  the property Wife was required to retrieve.Â  However, this argument is not
  preserved.Â  Husband failed to address the discrepancy between the language at
  the temporary hearing and in the Order in a post-trial motion.Â  A party must
  make a post-trial motion where there are inaccuracies in the order or
  inconsistencies between an oral ruling and a written order.Â  Grant v. South
    Carolina Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 355, 461 S.E.2d 388, 392 (1995); Pelican
      Bldg. Ctrs. of Horry-Georgetown, Inc. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 60, 427
  S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993) (appellant waived issue of nonconformity between oral
  order and subsequent written order by failing to raise issue below, which could
  have been raised through motion to alter or amend judgment after receipt of
  allegedly nonconforming written order).
The
  family court ruled the Ford Mustang was included in the remaining property Wife
  was to remove and ordered Husband to return the Ford Mustang and all its parts
  to Wife.Â  It is without dispute that the Ford Mustang was stored in the garage
  of the marital home at the time of the Temporary Order and neither party was in
  possession of it.Â  Nor was the Ford Mustang the type of operating vehicle
  described in the Temporary Order that was to be maintained and insured by each
  party.Â   
Our sole purpose in reviewing the
  family courtâ€™s contempt finding here is to ascertain whether evidentiary
  support existed for the ruling.Â  Accordingly, after a thorough study of the
  record, we determine evidentiary support existed for finding Husband in
  contempt and for ordering him to return the Ford Mustang to Wife. The family
  court was entirely within its discretion in determining the creditability of
  the witnesses and in assigning weight to their testimony. Â 
Moreover, because the family court
  determined Husband prevented Wife from retrieving the remaining property, the
  family court did not err in failing to find Wife in contempt for her
  non-compliance with the Temporary Order.Â  When a party is unable through no
  fault of her own to obey an order of the court, she is not to be held in
  contempt.

	2.Â Criminal Contempt
  Finding

Husband next complains the family
  court erred in finding him in criminal contempt.Â  In the Amended Order the
  family court ruled Husbandâ€™s â€œact of removalâ€ and â€œact of barringâ€ Wife
  constituted criminal contempt that was proven beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  The
  family court ordered Husband to return Wifeâ€™s property.Â  His failure to do so
  would result in a sentence of twelve (12) months incarceration, with the
  provision that he would be â€œreleased by the return of such property.â€Â   
The family court committed an error
  in nomenclature by designating the contempt criminal rather than civil. The precedent
  emanating from the South Carolina and United States Supreme Courts
  differentiating civil and criminal contempt is controlling.Â  See Curlee v. Howle, 277
  S.C. 377, 287 S.E.2d 915 (1982); Shillitani v. U.S., 384 U.S. 364 (1966). 
 
Without doubt, this is a civil
  contempt proceeding.Â  The family courtâ€™s Amended Order does not subject Husband
  to an unconditional, fixed term of imprisonment.[3]Â 
  Husband, if imprisoned, could obtain his release by complying with the courtâ€™s
  directive; he held the keys to his prison.Â  The contempt ruling was obviously
  intended to compel Husbandâ€™s compliance with the requirements of the Temporary
  Order.Â  Although mistakenly referred to as criminal contempt, substantively,
  the family courtâ€™s finding of contempt was civil in nature.Â   
II.Â ATTORNEYâ€™S FEES
Husband asserts the family court erred in ordering him to
  pay two-thirds (2/3) of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees because Wife did not prevail in
  the majority of issues.Â  Additionally, Husband contends the family court erred
  in failing to consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the
  beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial
  conditions, and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of
  living.Â  We disagree.
In advancing his
  argument, Husband incorrectly applies the standard for award of attorneyâ€™s fees
  in a domestic action.Â  In this contempt action, however, a different standard
  controls the courtâ€™s analysis.Â   
Courts, by exercising
  their contempt power, can award attorneyâ€™s fees under a compensatory contempt
  theory. Â Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C. 171, 178-79,
  557 S.E.2d 708, 711-12 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Compensatory contempt seeks to
  reimburse the party for the costs it incurs in forcing the non-complying party
  to obey the courtâ€™s orders. Â â€œIn a civil contempt proceeding, a contemnor may
  be required to reimburse a complainant for the costs he incurred in enforcing
  the courtâ€™s prior order, including reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees is not a punishment but an indemnification to the party who
  instituted the contempt proceeding.â€Â  Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106,
  114, 502 S.E.2d 86, 90 (1998); Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 345,
  491 S.E.2d 583, 592 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œA compensatory contempt award may include
  attorney fees.â€); Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 386-87, 287 S.E.2d 915,
  919-20 (1982) (â€œCompensatory contempt is a money award for the [Wife] when the
  [Husband]Â  has injured the [Wife] by violating a previous court order . . . . Â Included
  in the actual loss are the costs of defending and enforcing the courtâ€™s order,
  including litigation costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.â€). Â The court is not required
  to provide the contemnor with an opportunity to purge himself of these
  attorneyâ€™s fees in order to hold him in civil contempt.Â  Floyd v. Floyd,
  365 S.C. 56, 76, 615 S.E.2d 465, 476 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Poston, 331
  S.C. at 111-15, 502 S.E.2d at 88-91).Â  â€œ[T]he award of attorneyâ€™s fees
  is not part of the punishment; instead, this award is made to indemnify the
  party for expenses incurred in seeking enforcement of the court's order.â€Â  Id. at 77, 615 S.E. 2d at 476 (quoting Poston, 33 S.C. at 111-15, 502 S.E.2d
  at 88-91).
The family court found
  Wife necessarily incurred attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in securing Husbandâ€™s
  compliance with the Temporary Order.Â  We discern no abuse of discretion in
  ordering Husband to pay a portion of those fees and costs. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION  
We hold the evidentiary
  record supported the family courtâ€™s finding Husband in civil contempt.Â  The
  family court did not abuse its discretion by ordering Husband to return the
  Ford Mustang and all parts to Wife.Â  Nor did the family court err in failing to
  find Wife in civil contempt when she, through no fault of her own, failed to
  comply with the Temporary Order. Â The family court considered the proper
  standard for awarding attorneyâ€™s fees in a contempt action and was within its
  discretion in awarding fees and costs to Wife.
Accordingly, the Amended
  Order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
THOMAS, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.




[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The family court addressed other issues not
  relevant to this appeal, including the Temporary Orderâ€™s requirement that
  Husband and Wife split the utility bills while the home was on the market. 
 
[3] Although the family court issued several
  contempt rulings and imposed somewhat confusing sentences at the conclusion of
  the contempt hearing, the final ruling in the Amended Order controls.Â  â€œIt is
  well settled that a judge is not bound by a prior oral ruling and may issue a
  written order which is in conflict with the oral ruling.â€ Â Corbin v. Kohler
    Co., 351 S.C. 613, 621, 571 S.E.2d 92, 97 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Badeaux
      v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 204, 522 S.E.2d 835, 839 (Ct. App. 1999)). Â See
        also Owens v. Magill, 308 S.C. 556, 419 S.E.2d 786 (1992) (ruling
  judge was not bound by prior oral ruling and could issue written order which
  conflicted with prior oral ruling).Â  â€œTo the extent the written order may
  conflict with the prior oral ruling, the written order controls.â€ Â Parag v.
    Baby Boy Lovin, 333 S.C. 221, 226, 508 S.E.2d 590, 592 (Ct. App. 1998). Â â€œThe
  written order is the trial judgeâ€™s final order and as such constitutes the
  final judgment of the court. Â The final written order contains the binding
  instructions which are to be followed by the parties.â€ Â Ford v. State Ethics
    Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 821, 823 (2001) (citing Rule 58,
  SCRCP). Â

South Carolina; (2) Did the trial court correctly allow the testimony of an officer where the testimony was offered to rebut Appellantâ€™s attempt to persuade the jury she was anxious to aid the investigation or was it rank hearsay; (3) Did the testimony of the prosecutionâ€™s witness, Heidi Feagin, meet the test of identification evidence under the factual scenario of the record; (4) Did the trial court correctly allow admission of records from the Appellantâ€™s former employer within the business records exception of Rule 803(6), SCRE; and (5) Did the trial court commit error in refusing to give the jury a curative instruction when the Solicitor asked the jury to give the victimâ€™s widow â€œpeaceâ€ and â€œjustice as well?â€
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina,  Respondent,
				v.
				Carmen L.
      Rice, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4300
Heard September 11, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  5, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Solicitor
  Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  Carmen L. Rice
  (Rice) was convicted of murder and armed robbery and sentenced to life plus
  thirty years, concurrent.Â  Rice challenges her conviction, claiming the trial
  court erred by (1) ruling the portion of a prior inconsistent statement
  concerning third-party guilt inadmissible; (2) admitting alleged hearsay
  testimony; (3) permitting an in-court identification; (4) admitting business
  records under Rule 803(6), SCRE; and (5) failing to issue a curative
  instruction following the Stateâ€™s closing argument.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the
  evening of October 25, 2001, Carmen Rice and Iris Bryant (Bryant) joined Bernard
  Brennan (Brennan) at the Varsity in Columbia, where Brennan was playing pool
  with his friend, Alton Page.Â  Brennan told Page one of the women was his cousin
  from New York and the other was her friend from Beaufort.Â  Eventually, Brennan,
  Rice, and Bryant went to Callowayâ€™s to eat.Â   
After
  their meal, Brennan and the two women left Callowayâ€™s together.Â  They drove in
  his Mercedes to an isolated section of Richland County, near the intersection
  of Fairfield Road and Interstate 20.Â   
Later
  that night, Deputy Tom Lyons found Brennanâ€™s Mercedes in a ditch on Crawford Road.Â  Brennan was still buckled in his seatbelt, the engine was running, and the
  vehicle was in gear.Â  Brennan had been shot five times in the back and died as
  a result of the shooting.Â  His wallet was missing.
The
  police learned Bryant was involved in the murder and robbery after receiving
  information from one of Bryantâ€™s friends. Â Bryant subsequently implicated
  Rice in the murder and robbery.Â   
In her
  testimony at Riceâ€™s trial, Bryant confirmed she and Rice had planned to rob
  Brennan but denied any complicity in a plan to murder him.Â  Bryant claimed Rice
  unexpectedly shot Brennan from the backseat with the weapon Rice was issued by
  her employer. Â After the shooting, Rice removed Brennanâ€™s wallet and wiped down
  the car.Â  Then the two women fled.
Prior
  to trial, Bryant had given investigators multiple statements implicating other
  individuals in the robbery and murder. Â At Riceâ€™s trial, she confessed she lied
  in those previous interviews because she was afraid she would be charged with
  murder if she admitted being at the crime scene.Â  Rice attempted to impeach
  Bryantâ€™s testimony with a prior inconsistent statement Bryant made to Alana Quattlebaum, a fellow prisoner.Â  The import of Bryantâ€™s statement to Quattlebaum
  was that a woman named Nikki, rather than Rice, actually killed Brennan. [1]Â Â  
 
Brennanâ€™s friend, Alton Page, testified he could not identify
  either of the individuals he saw with Brennan on the night of the murder, but
  he recalled that one of them wore a â€œbright orange top.â€Â   
Heidi Feagin was a waitress at Callowayâ€™s in October of 2001.Â 
  Feagin served Brennan and the two women on October 25, and recognized Brennan
  as a â€œregular customer.â€Â  She described one of the women as having a stocky or
  medium build and wearing a bright orange top.Â  The other woman was thinner and
  younger.Â  Before trial, Feagin was shown a photographic lineup of six women.Â 
  The array included only Bryantâ€™s photograph.Â  Feagin did not identify Bryant,
  but instead selected two other women as Brennanâ€™s companions.Â  
The
  investigation ultimately led to Riceâ€™s indictment and trial for the armed
  robbery and murder of Bernard Brennan.Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty
  and Rice was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder and thirty years,
  concurrent, for armed robbery.Â  At the time of Riceâ€™s trial, Bryant had been
  charged with murder and armed robbery.
ISSUES

	1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err by ruling a prior inconsistent Â  statement
  concerning third-party guilt inadmissible?
	2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err by
  admitting hearsay testimony?
	3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err by permitting an
  in-court identification that was
  allegedly unreliable?
	4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err by admitting business
  records under Rule 803(6), SCRE, that were untrustworthy?
	5.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err by failing to give the
  jury an instruction curing the prosecutorâ€™s
  improper comment in closing? 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Wilson,
  345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525,
  608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004). Â We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual
  findings unless they are clearly erroneous. Â State v. Quattlebaum, 338
  S.C. 441, 454, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000); State v. Williams, 326 S.C.
  130, 135, 485 S.E.2d 99, 102 (1997); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 224, 625 S.E.2d 239, 241 (Ct. App. 2006) cert.
    pending; State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct.
  App. 2004). Â This court does not reevaluate the facts based on its own view of
  the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial
  courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence. Â Wilson, 345 S.C. at 1, 545
  S.E.2d at 827; State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 583, 575 S.E.2d 852, 855
  (Ct. App. 2003).
I.Â  Admission of Evidence
The
  admissibility of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge. Â State
    v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000); State
      v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 228, 522 S.E.2d 845, 851 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Evidentiary
  rulings of the trial court will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of
  discretion or the commission of legal error which results in prejudice to the
  defendant. Â Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 77, 538 S.E.2d at 263.
On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial court
  abused its discretion. Â State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 506, 626 S.E.2d
  59, 63 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending; State v. Walker, 366 S.C.
  643, 653, 623 S.E.2d 122, 127 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs
  when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is
  without evidentiary support. Â Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg,
  363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005); see also Simon v.
    Flowers, 231 S.C. 545, 550, 99 S.E.2d 391, 393-94 (1957) (â€œ â€˜[E]rror at
  lawâ€™ exists: (1) when the circuit judge, in issuing [the order], was controlled
  by some error of lawÂ  . . . or (2) where the order, based upon factual, as
  distinguished from legal, considerations, is without adequate evidentiary
  support.â€); McSween v. Windham, 77 S.C. 223, 226, 57 S.E. 847, 848
  (1907) (â€œ[T]he determination of the [trial] court will not be interfered with,
  unless there is an abuse of discretion, or unless the exercise of discretion
  was controlled by some error of law.â€).Â   
II. Closing Arguments
A trial court is
  vested with broad discretion in dealing with the range of propriety of closing
  argument, and ordinarily its rulings on such matters will not be disturbed.Â  State
    v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 195-96, 562 S.E.2d 320, 325-26 (Ct. App.
  2002).Â  This court will not disturb a trial courtâ€™s
  ruling regarding closing argument unless the trial court commits an abuse of
  discretion. Â State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624
  (1996); State v. Jernigan, 156 S.C. 509, 524, 153 S.E. 480, 486 (1930). Â An
  appellate court must review the argument in the context of the entire record.Â  State
    v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997).Â   
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The relevant
  question is whether the prosecutorâ€™s comments so infected the trial with
  unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  Id. Â Once the trial court has allowed the argument to
  stand, the defendant has the burden of proving the argument denied him a fair
  determination of guilt or innocence. Â State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 580,
  300 S.E.2d 63, 68 (1982).Â  Improper comments on closing do not require reversal if the
  appellant fails to prove he did not receive a fair trial because of the alleged
  improper argument.Â  Randall v. State, 356 S.C. 639, 642, 591 S.E.2d 608,
  610 (2004).Â  To
  warrant reversal, the appellant must prove both abuse of discretion and
  resulting prejudice.Â  State v.
    Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 231, 589 S.E.2d
  1, 3 (2003); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 232, 625 S.E.2d 245, 239
  (Ct. App. 2006) cert pending; State v. Harrison, 343 S.C. 165,
  172, 539 S.E.2d 71, 74 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing State v. Hughey, 339 S.C.
  439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000)); State v. Sierra, 337 S.C. 368, 373, 523
  S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1999).
III.Â Â Â  Harmless
  Error
The
  commission of legal error is harmless if it does not result in prejudice to the
  defendant.Â  For the error to be harmless,
  we must determine â€œbeyond a reasonable doubt the error complained of did not
  contribute to the verdict obtained.â€Â  Taylor v State, 312 S.C. 179, 181,
  439 S.E.2d 820, 821 (1993) (citing Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992)); State v. Buckner, 341 S.C. 241, 247, 534
  S.E.2d 15, 18 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing State v. Andrews, 324 S.C. 516,
  479 S.E.2d 808, 812 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  â€œ[A]n insubstantial error not affecting
  the result of the trial is harmless where â€˜guilt has been conclusively proven
  by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.â€™ â€ State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 212, 631 S.E.2d 262, 267 (2006) (quoting State
    v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989)); State v. Adams,
  354 S.C. 361, 381, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 179, 460 S.E.2d 368, 371
  (1995) (noting this court will not set aside a conviction for insubstantial
  errors not affecting the result when guilt is conclusively proven by competent
  evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached).  
â€œError is harmless
  beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the verdict obtained.â€Â  Pagan, 369 S.C. at 212, 631 S.E.2d at 267 (citing Arnold, 309 S.C. at 172, 420
  S.E.2d at 842); State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 333, 563 S.E.2d 315, 318-19
  (2002); State v. Sherard, 303 S.C.
  172, 175, 399 S.E.2d 595, 596 (1991) (â€œError in a criminal prosecution is

Furthermore,
  an appellant cannot complain of prejudice resulting from admission of evidence
  to which she opened the door.Â  See State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614,
  623, 582 S.E.2d 426, 431 (2003) (noting one who opens the door to evidence
  cannot complain of its admission); State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 474,
  409 S.E.2d 404, 408 (1991) (â€œSince appellant opened the door to this evidence,
  he cannot complain of prejudice from its admission.â€); State v. Beam,
  336 S.C. 45, 53, 518 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct.App.1999) (â€œBeam cannot complain about
  the admission of evidence where he opened the door to the evidence.â€).
In the
  present case, during recross, defense counsel asked Feagin why she was able to
  assist in preparing composite sketches, â€œbut now say you canâ€™t identify them
  because you didnâ€™t get a good look at them.Â  How could you say all of those
  things if you didnâ€™t get a good look at them?â€Â  Feagin responded, â€œI didnâ€™t say
  I couldnâ€™t identify them because I couldnâ€™t get a good look at them.Â  Itâ€™s been
  a long time, Iâ€™m sure I can still identify them, itâ€™s just been a long time
  since I had a look at them.â€Â   
In an in camera hearing, the State asked the court to allow Feaginâ€™s in-court identification
  of Rice on redirect in â€œresponse to new matter brought up by the defense
  attorney during his recross.â€Â  The prosecutor emphasized â€œ[I] never asked her
  if she could identify them.Â  [Defense counsel] asked her about that.Â  And she
  responded that she could.Â  The jury heard it. . . .â€Â Â   
Rice countered
  that the State laid the foundation for Feaginâ€™s in-court identification on
  direct examination, but stopped short of extracting it.Â  The trial court
  reviewed direct, cross, redirect and recross testimony and ultimately determined:

	There was no discussion at all that Iâ€™m seeing that touched on the
  issue of whether or not she [Feagin] could make an identification here and
  now.Â  Iâ€™m not seeing that at all in direct or redirect. . . . 
	I thought that was where they [the State] were going, they never
  did. . . . Â Nobody ever brought up, an any point, until your [defense
  counselâ€™s] last question to her, whether or not she could make an
  identification of the person if she saw them.Â  It just never got brought up. .
  . . Â Â Â 

Based
  on the review of the transcript, the trial court concluded defense counsel opened
  the door allowing the State to elicit Feaginâ€™s in-court identification.Â  Rice
  cannot complain about the admission of identification evidence when she opened
  the door to that evidence.Â   
IV.Â Â Â  Business
  Records
Rice
  asserts the trial court admitted her former employerâ€™s business records in
  error.Â  Specifically, Rice claims the records constituted inadmissible hearsay
  because they lacked the level of trustworthiness required under Rule 803(6), SCRE. Â We disagree.
South Carolina adopted section 19-5-510 of the South Carolina Code, the Uniform Business
  Record as Evidence Act, prior to the promulgation of the South Carolina Rules
  of Evidence.Â  The statute provides:  

	A record of an act, condition or event shall, insofar as relevant,
  be competent evidence if the custodian or other qualified witness testifies to
  its identity and the mode of its preparation, and if it was made in the regular
  course of business, at or near the time of the act, condition or event and if,
  in the opinion of the court, the sources of information, method and time of
  preparation were such as to justify its admission.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-5-510 (1985).
This section
  gives the trial court control to exclude or require additional proof if the
  authenticity or trustworthiness of the business record is suspect.Â  SeeÂ  Kershaw County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. McCaskill, 276
  S.C. 360, 362, 278 S.E.2d 771, 773 (1981).Â   
Patterned
  after the South Carolina Act and the Federal Rules, Rule 803(6), SCRE, excepts
  records of regularly conducted activity from the hearsay exclusion.[3]Â  Excepted records include:

	A memorandum, report, record, or data compilation, in any form, of
  acts, events, conditions, or diagnoses, made at or near the time by, or from
  information transmitted by, a person with knowledge, if kept in the course of a
  regularly conducted business activity, and if it was the regular practice of
  that business activity to make the memorandum, report, record, or data
  compilation, all as shown by the testimony of the custodian or other qualified
  witness, unless the source of information or the method or circumstances of
  preparation indicate lack of trustworthiness; provided, however, that subjective
  opinions and judgments found in business records are not admissible. The term
  â€œbusinessâ€ as used in this subsection includes business, institution,
  association, profession, occupation, and calling of every kind, whether or not
  conducted for profit.

Rule 803(6), SCRE.
A
  business record without evidence about the manner in which it is prepared or
  the source of its information does not meet the requirements in either section
  19-5-510 or Rule 803(6), SCRE. Â See State v. Sarvis, 317
  S.C. 102, 107, 450 S.E.2d 606, 609 (Ct. App. 1994); see also Connelly
    v. Wometco Enterprises, Inc., 314 S.C. 188, 191, 442 S.E.2d 204, 206 (Ct.
  App. 1994) (holding employment file, although relevant and otherwise
  admissible, was properly excluded from evidence where the employer failed to
  offer the file through its custodian or another qualified witness); State v.
    McFarlane 279 S.C. 327, 330, 306 S.E.2d 611, 613 (1983) (finding trial
  court properly refused to admit medical report when no one could testify to the
  identity, mode of preparation, or whether report was made in the regular course
  of business at or near the time of the accident). Â Â Business record entries
  must have been made at or near the time of the act to which they relate; the
  purpose of this mandate is to aid in establishing that the record was honestly
  and fairly kept.Â  South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank v. Jones, 302 S.C.
  154, 155, 394 S.E.2d 323, 324 (1990).Â   
Americaâ€™s Best Security (ABS) business records tracked weapons and other equipment issued
  to employees.Â  The records custodian for the company identified the admitted documents.Â 
  She confirmed the records were kept in the normal course of the companyâ€™s
  business and prepared according to the requirements of the law.Â  The record indicating
  Riceâ€™s assigned equipment had not been returned was submitted on November 29,
  2001, approximately one month after Brennanâ€™s murder and Riceâ€™s termination
  from ABS.  
The
  admitted documents contained the following information: Â Rice was issued a
  weapon and qualified by SLED to shoot a .357 Magnum-type gun; her last working
  day was October 30, 2001; SLED was notified of Riceâ€™s termination from ABS;
  Rice was listed among employees terminated in the last ninety days on November
  29, 2001; and Rice had not returned equipment assigned to her, including her
  weapon, as of November 29, 2001.Â  Two ABS employees with supervisory authority over
  Rice corroborated this evidence.Â  Furthermore, the testimony of the records
  custodian and corroborating witnesses underwent vigorous cross-examination.Â 
 
The
  essence of Riceâ€™s challenge is that ABS is now bankrupt and some records were stored
  and possibly misplaced, rendering the entire record keeping process
  untrustworthy.Â  However, Rule 803(6), SCRE, focuses on the source of the
  information or the method and circumstances of preparation as indicia of
  trustworthiness.Â  No probative evidence suggests the sources of the information
  recorded in the ABS documents were not credible or the methods and
  circumstances of preparation were unreliable.Â  The evidence Rice relies on simply
  identified problems in accessing the business records after the company stored them
  and does not cast suspicion on the recordsâ€™ trustworthiness.
Moreover,
  any error in admitting the ABS business records was harmless.Â  The records were
  merely cumulative to the testimony of Riceâ€™s supervisors, who confirmed that
  Rice had not returned her weapon as of November 29, 2001.Â  State v. Douglas,
  367 S.C. 498, 520, 626 S.E.2d 59, 71 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œThe admission of
  improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other
  evidence.â€) cert. granted June, 2007.  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Curative
  Instruction 
In closing
  argument, the prosecutor asked the jury to give the victimâ€™s wife peace and the
  victim justice.Â  Rice contends the trial court erred by failing to give the
  jury an instruction curing the prosecutorâ€™s comment.Â  We disagree.
The
  State urges that Rice failed to preserve this issue for appellate review by
  raising the issue in an off-the-record conference.Â  An objection made during an
  off-the-record conference which is not made part of the record does not
  preserve the question for review.Â  York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 325
  S.C. 170, 173, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997).Â  However, in State v. Hamilton,
  we held York was inapplicable when the initial off-the-record bench
  conference was later made a part of the record.Â  344 S.C. 344, 361, 543 S.E.2d
  586, 595 (Ct. App. 2001) overruled on other grounds by State v.
    Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â   
In Hamilton , defense counsel requested a jury instruction on the prosecutorâ€™s comments
  during an off-the-record bench conference.Â  Id. at 360, 543 S.E.2d at
  595.Â  The trial court denied the request and defense counsel moved for a
  mistrial.Â  Id. at 361, 543 S.E.2d at 595.Â  The State alleged any errors
  raised by Hamilton in the bench conference were off-the-record and not
  preserved.Â  Id. at 360, 543 S.E.2d at 595. Â We held the initial off-the-record
  conference had subsequently been made part of the record by the acquiescence of
  the judge, prosecution, and defense counsel.Â  The issue appellant raised
  concerning the prosecutorâ€™s comment was preserved for review.Â  Id.
As in Hamilton , defense counsel in the case at bar put his objection to the prosecutorâ€™s
  comment on the record when the jury began its deliberation.Â  Counsel
  specifically stated his requested reliefâ€”a curative instructionâ€”and the basis
  for his objectionâ€”that the comment improperly injected passion or sympathy into
  the trial.Â  Neither the trial court nor the State objected to defense counsel
  putting his exception on the record.Â  Therefore, Riceâ€™s objection to the trial
  courtâ€™s failure to give a curative instruction is preserved.
It is
  well settled that the prosecutionâ€™s closing argument must not appeal to the personal
  biases of the jurors or be calculated to arouse the jurorsâ€™ passions or
  prejudices.Â  Humphries
    v. State, 351 S.C. 362, 373, 570
  S.E.2d 160, 166 (2002); Simmons v. State, 331 S.C. 333, 338, 503 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1998) (citing State
    v.Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 (1996)).Â  The
  prosecutionâ€™s closing argument should be confined to evidence in the record and
  the reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the evidence.Â  Vaughn v.
    State, 362 S.C. 163, 169, 607 S.E.2d 72, 75 (2004).Â   
An argument
  asking the jurors to place themselves in the victimâ€™s shoes tends to destroy completely
  all sense of impartiality of the jurors, and its effect is to arouse passion
  and prejudice.Â  State v. Reese, 370 S.C. 31, 38, 633 S.E.2d 898, 901 (2006).Â  
 

	The â€˜Golden Ruleâ€™ argument, suggesting to jurors as it does that they
  put themselves in the shoes of one of the parties, is generally impermissible
  because it encourages the jurors to depart from neutrality and to decide the
  case on the basis of personal interest and bias rather than on the evidence. Â Regardless
  of the nomenclature used, any argument that importunes the jurors to places
  themselves in the victimâ€™s shoes is disallowed Golden Rule Argument. 
	

State
  v. Reese, 359
  S.C. 260, 271, 597 S.E.2d 169, 175 (Ct. App. 2004), revâ€™d on other grounds
    by 370 S.C. at 38, 633 S.E.2d at 901.Â   
Prosecutors
  are bound to rules of fairness in their closing arguments. Â State v. Linder,
  276 S.C. 304, 312, 278 S.E.2d 335, 339 (1981).Â  â€œWhile the solicitor should
  prosecute vigorously, his duty is not to convict a defendant but to see justice
  done.Â  The solicitorâ€™s closing argument must, of course, be based upon this
  principle.â€Â  State v. Northcutt, 372 S.C. 207, 222, 641 S.E.2d 873, 880
  (2007).
When
  objection is timely made to improper remarks of counsel, the judge should rule
  on the objection, give a curative charge to the jury, and instruct offending
  counsel to desist from improper remarks. Â Mishoe v. QHG of Lake City, Inc.,
  366 S.C. 195, 202, 621 S.E.2d 363, 367 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing McElveen v.
    Ferre, 299 S.C. 377, 381, 385 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 1989)).Â  Failure to give a requested jury instruction is not
  prejudicial error when the instructions given afford the proper test for
  determining the issues.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 263, 565
  S.E.2d 298, 304 (2002) (citation omitted).Â  â€œAn error not shown to be
  prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal.â€Â  Brown v. Pearson,
  326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997); see also State
    v. Williams, 367 S.C. 192, 195-96, 624 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
 
Here, the prosecutor, while explaining
  demeanor evidence to the jury, made the following comment concerning witness Bryant:

	As an example of demeanor how you can tell when somebodyâ€™s telling
  the truth, you saw her when she was telling you, begging for forgiveness for
  being too much of a coward to do something or to come forward and how she
  begged forgiveness and said she wanted Hilda to have peace.Â  You saw that.Â  You
  know that was raw truth.Â  She want Hildaâ€”she wanted to give Hilda peace.Â 
  Ladies and gentlemen, I would ask you to give Hilda and Bernard justice as
  well.[4] 

Defense
  counsel approached the bench and the trial court held an off-the-record
  conference.Â  Defense counsel proceeded with closing argument.Â  When the jury
  moved into deliberation, defense counsel reiterated the objection to the
  prosecutorâ€™s comment he had previously made off-the record:Â   

	I objected to him making statements that the jury owed Hilda
  Brennan justice.Â  I would ask that the jury be given a curative instruction on
  that.Â  I believe that that comment improperly injected passion or sympathy into
  the trial of this case.Â  And it was improper statement or comment during the
  opening on the law by the prosecution in this case.

The trial court responded:

	I told you I think his actual words
  wereâ€”you asked him to bringâ€”he didnâ€™t say that they owed them justice, but I
  did not think it was an improper comment at the time and certainly nothing
  thatâ€™s not cured by the overall instruction to them.

A
  priori, we observe the trial court properly clarified that the prosecutor asked
  the jury to give the victimâ€™s wife peace and the victim justice.Â  The court
  emphasized the prosecutor did not say â€œthey owed them justice.â€Â  Arguably, the prosecutorâ€™s
  comment was consistent with his duty, not to convict a defendant, but to see justice done.Â  Viewed from
  that perspective, the prosecutor merely asked the jury to do the duty that was
  already required of them.Â  The prosecutorâ€™s comment did not call for the jurors
  to put themselves in the victimâ€™s place and did not rise to the level of a
  Golden Rule argument. Â 
If the prosecutorâ€™s request had reached that level of
  impropriety, the trial courtâ€™s overall instructions to the jury effectively cured
  any potential prejudice.Â  The judge stressed the State had the burden of
  proving Rice guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  He instructed the jury to
  consider only the competent evidence before them, based on the witnesses, exhibits
  made part of the record, and stipulations between counsel.Â  The judge explained
  that, as jurors, they were sworn to accept and apply the law exactly as he
  stated it to them.Â  It was their duty to decide the effect, the value, weight,
  and truth of the evidence presented during the course of the trial.Â  He charged
  them to assess the credibility of witnesses who testified during trial and to evaluate
  the evidence to determine its truthfulness.Â Â  Â 
We conclude the trial court adequately set forth the proper test for determining the issues.Â  Any error in
  failing to give a specific curative instruction was harmless.  
CONCLUSION
We
  hold:

	
		
			(1)
			 the
  alleged prior inconsistent statement concerning third-party guilt
  was inadmissible under a State v. Gregory and Holmes v. South Carolina analysis;
		
		
			(2)
			the
  investigating officerâ€™s testimony was NOT hearsay under Rule
  801(c), SCRE, and was admissible as a conclusion based on the
  officerâ€™s investigation;
		
		
			(3)
			the
  in-court identification of Rice by Heidi Feagin was admissible
  based on State v. Lewis because there was no pre-trial identification
  procedure;
		
		
			(4)
			the
  evidence of the former employerâ€™s business records met the test
  of section 19-5-510 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, Uniform Business 
			Records as Evidence Act, and Rule 803(6), SCRE;
  and 
		
		
			(5)
			the
  prosecutorâ€™s statement to give the victimâ€™s wife peace and the victim
  justice did NOT violateÂ  State v. Reese, or the Golden Rule
  argument.
		
	

Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
 
AFFIRMED.
THOMAS, J. and GOOLSBY, A.J. concur.

[1]Â Â  Rice sought to introduce testimony that Bryantâ€™s
  cousin, Tiki, committed the crimes.Â  However, Bryantâ€™s initial statements to
  police did not mention Tiki, but instead named Nikki as the person involved. Â Trial
  counsel referred to her as â€œsome other girlâ€ and â€œsome other personâ€ in
  questioning Bryant about her prior statements to police. Â Whether Tiki and
  Nikki were the same person remains unresolved.Â   
[2] Rice was tried and convicted prior to the United
  States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Holmes v. South Carolina, 547 U.S.
  319, 126 S. Ct. 1727 (2006).Â   
[3] Section 19-5-510 has been construed to preclude
  admission of subjective opinions or judgments within a business record.Â  SeeÂ  McCaskill, 276 S.C. at 362,Â  278 S.E.2d at 773; State v. Key, 277
  S.C. 214, 215, 284 S.E.2d 781, 783 (1981); State v. Patterson, 290 S.C.
  523, 527-28, 351 S.E.2d 853, 855 (1986).Â  The Federal Rules of Evidence do not
  contain this restriction.Â  Consequently, Rule 803(6), SCRE, differs from the
  federal rule in that the word â€œopinionsâ€ in the first sentence is deleted and
  the phrase, â€œprovided, however, that subjective opinions and judgments found in
  business records are not admissibleâ€ is added to the federal rule to make it
  consistent with state law.  
[4] Â Â Hilda is Bernard Brennanâ€™s widow.
