title: Blackwell v. Fulgum
description: In this contempt action seeking past due child support, the Court of Appeals affirmed the family court's award of child support arrearage and attorney's fees to Father.  The court held that despite the emancipation of one of the two supported minor children, Mother was not entitled to unilaterally reduce her support payments without an order of the family court.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Anita
      Blackwell, Appellant,
				v.
				Kasper F.
      Fulgum, Jr., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4301
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 9, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert Scott Dover, of Pickens, for Appellant
				Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:Â  Anita
  Blackwell appeals the family courtâ€™s decision to award Kasper Fulgum, Jr. $9,411.00
  in past due child support and $3,368.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS
Anita Blackwell
  (Mother) and Kasper Fulgum, Jr. (Father) were formerly husband and wife, and
  during their marriage, they had two children.Â  The two children (Daughter and
  Son) were born on April 8, 1985 and November 14, 1986, respectively.Â  In a
  February 28, 2001 order (the Original Support Order), the family court awarded,
  by agreement of the parties, custody to Father and ordered Mother to pay Father
  $760.00 per month for child support.Â   
Mother paid the
  required child support until June 15, 2003, whereupon she then reduced her
  child support payment to $386.00 per month.Â  Mother believed she was justified
  in reducing her child support by one-half because Daughter had reached eighteen
  years of age and graduated from high school at the end of May.[2]Â 
  Father immediately responded by sending a letter to Mother indicating that she
  was in default of the child support order, and informing her that she needed to
  submit current financial information to either his attorney, her attorney, or
  the Greenville County Family Court to seek a reduction in child support.Â  After
  receiving no response from Mother, Father had his attorney send Mother a second
  letter.Â  This letter again informed Mother that it was not proper for her to
  reduce the child support without a court order and offered to work with Mother
  on establishing a proper reduction in child support.Â  Motherâ€™s current husband
  responded with a letter informing Father any order amending the Original
  Support Order must reflect a $386.00 per month child support obligation on the
  part of Mother or else Father would have to send his financial information to
  Mother.Â Â   
Mother continued paying $386.00 (or the corrected
  $380.00) per month to Father until March 15, 2005.Â  However, beginning in
  September 2004 and continuing through January 2005, Mother ceased making
  support payments to Father and paid directly to Son because she believed Son
  was no longer living with Father.Â  Mother ceased payments to Father again in
  April 2005 because she again believed Son was living elsewhere.Â   
In
  January 2005, Father filed a rule to show cause motion, and the family court,
  on January 24, 2005, issued an order for Mother to appear on February 11, 2005
  to show cause why she should not be held in contempt.Â  This order specifically
  and separate from the issue of contempt additionally ordered Mother to show
  cause why she should not pay a reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â 
  Mother failed to appear at the rule to show cause hearing, and Father was
  awarded $14,668.00 in child support and $865.00 for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â 
  Mother was held in contempt and sentenced to one year incarceration which could
  be purged upon payment of the child support and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  On April 18,
  2005, the family court vacated this contempt order in response to Motherâ€™s
  motions to alter and amend and for relief from the judgment.Â  The family court
  found Motherâ€™s notice of the proceedings was defective and ordered a new trial de novo on the rule to show cause action.Â  
 
As a
  result of the second proceeding concerning Fatherâ€™s rule to show cause motion,
  the family court did not find Mother in contempt, but did order her to pay
  $9,411.00 in child support and $3,368.60 for Fatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The
  family court found that Mother was not entitled to unilaterally reduce her
  child support payments by one-half and was responsible for the full amount of
  support until March 11, 2005, which was the date she filed her motion for
  temporary relief seeking a reduction in her support obligation due to a substantial
  change in circumstances.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate court
  has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of
  the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Abercrombie v. Abercrombie, 372
  S.C. 643, 646, 643 S.E.2d 697, 698 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Despite this broad scope
  of review, we remain mindful that the family court saw and heard the witnesses
  and generally is in a better position to determine credibility.Â  Id.Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Child Support
  Arrearage
It appears Mother
  contends because the family court failed to find her in contempt, it was error to
  enforce the Original Support Order against her.Â  Because Mother failed to
  separate her arguments into individual issues on appeal, it is somewhat unclear
  exactly which arguments she has put forth.Â  However, we will endeavor to
  address each issue raised.Â   
We first note section
  20-7-420 (17) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides the family court
  with jurisdiction to continue orders for support until the eighteenth birthday
  of the supported child.Â  At which point, under South Carolina law, a parentâ€™s
  obligation to pay child support generally ends by operation of law.Â  Purdy v. Purdy,
  353 S.C. 400, 403, 578 S.E.2d 30, 31 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, the above
  statute further provides a means for the family court to extend support beyond
  the childâ€™s eighteenth birthday if the child is still in high school â€œand is
  making satisfactory progress toward completion of high school, not to exceed
  the nineteenth birthday unless exceptional circumstances are found to exist or
  unless there is a preexisting agreement or order to provide for child support
  past the age of eighteen years . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-420 (17) (Supp.
  2006).Â  The statute continues on to provide the court with authority to extend
  support beyond the childâ€™s eighteenth birthday if there are physical or mental
  disabilities of the child or upon a showing of other exceptional circumstances.
In light of the
  above statute, it would appear at first blush that the now appealed from family
  court order erred in requiring Mother to pay the full amount of support as
  noted in the Original Support Order until Daughter was almost twenty years of
  age.[3]Â 
  However, where one of multiple children reaches majority, a parentâ€™s child
  support obligation will not be affected absent a family court order modifying
  the amount of support owed.Â  Bull v. Smith, 299 S.C. 123, 126, 382
  S.E.2d 905, 907 (1989).Â  See also Stroman v. Williams, 291
  S.C. 376, 380, 353 S.E.2d 704, 706 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding that â€œ[w]here a
  support order â€˜provides for payments for the benefit of two or more children,
  the marriage or emancipation of one minor child does not automatically affect
  the liability of the father for the full sum prescribed in the order.â€™â€).Â 
  Where one of multiple children becomes emancipated, the family court does not
  extend the parentâ€™s support obligation on behalf of the emancipated child. Â The
  court simply continues the existing support agreement for the benefit of the
  other minor child[ren] until such time as the court, upon request of the
  supporting parent, can calculate a proper reduction in the support obligation
  based on a showing of changed circumstances.Â  Â Â 
When a party is
  found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose
  sanctions remains a matter for the
  courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 263, 621 S.E.2d
  389, 392-93 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Perhaps in its discretion, the family court found
  that mother had a good faith belief that she was entitled to a reduction based
  upon the emancipation of Daughter, and therefore, decided against finding her
  in contempt.Â  Regardless of the contempt, Mother owed Father support under the
  unmodified terms of the Original Support Order.Â  We find no error by the family
  court in failing to find Mother in contempt and ordering her to pay the child
  support arrearage.Â   
Mother next appears
  to raise an estoppel argument.Â  Mother claims Father should not be permitted to
  collect the child support arrearage because she was prejudiced by Fatherâ€™s
  eighteen month delay in filing his rule to show cause action.Â  Mother claims
  she was prevented from seeking a modification because it was not until Father
  filed his motion to show cause that she was put on notice that he was refusing
  to accept her one-half child support payments.Â  We find this argument unpersuasive
  and untenable.Â  We first note that Mother was free to petition the court for a
  change in her support obligation at any time, but she instead opted to
  unilaterally reduce her support payments in violation of the family court
  order.Â  Further, in both a letter from Father and a letter from Fatherâ€™s
  attorney, Mother was informed that her actions were in violation of the family
  court order and the means by which she could remedy this problem.Â  In light of
  these facts, we find any argument made by Mother based on estoppel or unconscionability to be without merit.
 
Mother next argues
  the family court erred in its award of child support arrearage because it
  failed to credit her for the support she paid directly to Son.Â  The Original
  Support Order stated: â€œThe Mother shall make semi-monthly child support
  payments to the Father in the amount of $380.00.â€Â  The general rule is that it
  is the obligation of the divorced spouse to pay the specified amounts according
  to the terms of the decree and said spouse should not be permitted to vary
  these terms as a matter of convenience.Â  Foster v. Foster, 294 S.C. 373,
  375, 364 S.E.2d 753, 754 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The family court correctly noted
  â€œ[t]he Mother was required to send the support to the custodian parent regardless
  of where the child was residing unless an order was entered, either by consent
  or otherwise.â€Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s failure to credit Mother
  for payments made directly to Son.
Lastly,
  Mother contends equity and fairness dictates we hold the child support
  arrearage in abeyance pursuant to section 20-7-933 of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2006).Â  She goes on to suggest the legislative intent of this abeyance
  provision is for conditions such as those encountered in this case.Â  We disagree.Â 
  Mother requests that this court hold her support arrearage in abeyance
  permanently; however, the very definition of â€œabeyanceâ€ is that of â€œtemporary
  inactivityâ€ or â€œsuspension.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 4 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Further,
  we are not persuaded by Motherâ€™s assertion that the legislatureâ€™s intent in
  enacting the abeyance provision of the statute was to protect parents who
  unilaterally reduce their support payments in violation of a family court
  order.Â  We deduce no support for holding the arrearage in abeyance.
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Mother contends the
  family court erred in awarding Father attorneyâ€™s fees and in failing to award
  attorneyâ€™s fees to her.Â  We disagree.Â   
â€œSuit money,
  including attorneyâ€™s fees, may be
  assessed for or against a party to an action brought in or subject to the
  jurisdiction of the family court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(38) (Supp.
  2006).Â  An attorneyâ€™s fees award is
  within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Davis v. Davis, 372 S.C.
  64, 88, 641 S.E.2d 446, 458 (Ct. App. 2006).Â   
Generally,
  we would be inclined to determine an award of attorneyâ€™s fees in accordance
  with the factors outlined in the case of E.D.M. v. T.A.M..[4]Â 
  However, if the case before us presents an added dimension of an uncooperative
  spouse who hampers a final resolution of the issues in dispute, we will not
  reward an adversary spouse for such conduct.Â  Anderson v. Tolbert,
  322 S.C. 543, 549, 473 S.E.2d 456, 459 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Of particular concern
  are those occasions which force one parent to seek sanctions against the other
  parent for violating court orders.Â  Id. at 550, 473 S.E.2d at 459.Â  
 
In
  the instant case, it was Motherâ€™s conduct in unilaterally reducing her child support
  obligation which violated the court order and precipitated Fatherâ€™s rule to
  show cause motion.Â  Motherâ€™s refusal to cooperate with Fatherâ€™s offer to
  negotiate a proper reduction in child support necessitated the filing of his
  motion and ultimately, Motherâ€™s need to hire an attorney.Â  Further, the initial
  ruling on the rule to show cause motion was vacated because the family court found Motherâ€™s notice of
  the proceedings was defective, not because of any misstatements by Father.Â  Therefore,
  contrary to Motherâ€™s assertions that Fatherâ€™s misstatements prolonged the case,
  even had Father not misspoken during the initial hearing, a second hearing
  would have been required.Â  Because the family court vacated the initial order
  and ordered a new trial de novo, the misstatements by Father had
  no bearing upon the second hearing.Â  The court would have been required to
  address any discrepancies between Father and Motherâ€™s accounts of the support
  arrearage to determine the amount owed regardless of any misstatements made by
  Father in the first hearing.Â   
Lastly, we note that since the initial order regarding the rule to
  show cause was vacated, Mother did not, as she contends, receive a reduction in
  child support arrears from $14,668.00 to $9,411.00.Â  This second hearing, which
  was a new trial de novo, resulted in her having to pay $9,411.00
  in child support arrearage.Â  We fail to discern a manner in which she could
  entitle this a beneficial result.Â  We find no error with the family courtâ€™s
  finding that â€œMother required the bringing of this action and her actions
  weighed heavily in the attorneyâ€™s fees award.â€Â   
III.Â  Time
  Allotted to Pay Support Arrearage and Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Mother contends the
  family court erred in requiring her to pay the child support arrearage on or
  before March 1, 2006 and the attorneyâ€™s fees on or before January 15, 2006.Â 
  She contends this amount of time was improper and constituted an abuse of
  discretion.Â  We disagree.
â€œQuestions
  concerning child support are ordinarily committed to the discretion
  of the family court, whose
  conclusions will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing of an abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  South Carolina Dept. of Social Services, County of Siskiyou v. Martin, 371 S.C. 21, 24, 637 S.E.2d 310, 312 (2006).Â  With the
  record before us, we cannot find an abuse of discretion on the part of the
  family court.Â  The family court was in a position superior to this court from
  which to evaluate the appropriate time frame allotted for payment and was free
  to impute income to Mother who was voluntarily unemployed.Â  See Patel
    v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 532, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004) (â€œIt is proper to
  impute income to a party who is voluntarily unemployed or underemployed.â€).Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We find the family court
  did not err in its award of child support arrearage and attorneyâ€™s fees and
  that the time allotted for payment was not an abuse of discretion.Â  Based on the foregoing, the family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  J., and WILLIAMS, J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] It appears Mother was mistakenly paying $772.00 per
  month in support and not the required $760.00 per month.Â  Therefore, $386.00
  per month represents a one-half reduction in support.Â  This is likely due to
  the fact that the Original Support Order dictated that Mother pay $772.00 per
  month from August of 2001 through November of 2001 and then pay $760.00 per
  month thereafter.Â  The parties agree Mother overpaid father in the amount of
  $180.00.Â   
[3] The appealed from order requires Mother to pay the
  full $760.00 per month in child support until March 11, 2005 and then one-half
  of that through Sonâ€™s June 2005 graduation.Â  On March 11, 2005, Daughter would
  have attained the age of nineteen years and eleven months.Â Â   
[4] In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider each partyâ€™s
  ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the
  partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™
  standards of living. Â Â E.D.M. v. T.A.M.,
307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).

title: Hiott v. State
description: In this case we hold the PCR court has authority to issue Rule 11 sanctions against a PCR applicant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Milton Hiott, Appellant
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent
			
		
	


Appeal From Bamberg County
Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4302
Heard September 12, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  11, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  In this case, we hold the PCR court has authority to issue Rule 11
  sanctions against a post-conviction applicant pursuant to the South Carolina
  Rules of Civil Procedure.
FACTS
Milton
  Daniel Hiott (Hiott) was convicted of incest and sentenced to ten years
  imprisonment.Â  Hiott did not appeal his conviction or sentence.Â   
Hiott
  filed an application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  Hiott alleged trial counsel was ineffective for failing to prepare for
  trial, failing to request a Blair[1] hearing, and failing to file a direct appeal.Â  Additionally,
  Hiott argued he was entitled to relief based on vindictive prosecution, a Brady[2] violation, prosecutorial elicitation of false testimony,
  prosecutorial misstatement of a crucial fact, violation of Rules 3(c) and (d),
  SCRCrimP, the Stateâ€™s presentation of direct indictments at trial, and
  unconstitutional vagueness of indictments.Â  Â 
Hiott
  presented testimony regarding most of these assertions.Â  However, he failed to
  present testimony supporting his claims for counselâ€™s failure to request a Blair hearing, violation of Rules
  3(c) and (d), the presentation of indictments, or vagueness of indictments.Â  
 
The
  PCR judge denied Hiottâ€™s application and pursuant to Rule 11 of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure[3] fined Hiott $3,000 for
  presenting frivolous claims and testimony.Â  Subsequently, Hiott filed a Rule
  59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment, which was denied.Â  Â Â 
Hiott
  filed a petition for writ of certiorari.Â  We granted the petition and ordered
  the parties to brief the issue of whether the PCR judge had authority to issue
  Rule 11 sanctions.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Any
  evidence of probative value is sufficient to uphold a PCR judgeâ€™s finding.Â  Pierce
    v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144-45, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).Â Â  A PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision will be reversed if it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â  If the case raises a novel question of law, this Court is free to decide the
  question without deference to the lower court.Â  State v. McClinton, 369
  S.C. 167, 169, 631 S.E.2d 895, 896 (2006).Â   
The
  issue of whether a PCR court has authority to sanction a PCR applicant under
  Rule 11 is one of first impression.Â  Thus, we are free to make our
  determination without deference to the PCR court.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  Uniform Post-Conviction Procedure Act[4] (the Act) contemplates the applicability of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure in PCR actions.Â  Section 17-27-80 of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2006) states, â€œAll rules and statutes applicable in civil
  proceedings are available to the parties.â€ (emphasis added).Â   
The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to determine and
  give effect to the intent of the legislature.Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist.
    v. State Budget & Control Bd., 313 S.C. 1, 5, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993).Â 
  The best evidence of legislative intent is the text of the statute.Â  Wade
    v. State, 348 S.C. 255, 259, 559 S.E.2d
  843, 844 (2002) (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  If
  the
  terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to
  their literal meaning.Â  City of Columbia v. Am. Civil
    Liberties Union of S.C., Inc., 323 S.C. 384, 387, 475 S.E.2d 2d 747, 749
  (1996).Â   
The
  plain language of section 17-27-10 requires all rules that apply in a civil
  case apply to PCR actions.Â  A PCR action is a civil action.Â  Council v.
    Catoe, 359 S.C. 120, 125, 597 S.E.2d 782, 784 (2004).Â Â  Consequently, Rule
  11 would apply to PCR proceedings because PCR actions are civil.Â   
Moreover,
  section 17-27-150(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) states, â€œA party
  in a noncapital [PCR] proceeding shall be entitled to invoke the processes of
  discovery available under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure if, and
  to the extent that, the judge . . . grants leave to do so . . . .â€Â  Section
  17-27-150(B) states, â€œA party in a capital [PCR] proceeding shall be entitled
  to invoke the processes of discovery available under the South Carolina Rules
  of Civil Procedure.â€Â   
Section
  17-27-150 indicates the legislatureâ€™s express intent to afford PCR applicants
  limited use of the discovery process as stated in the South Carolina Rules of
  Civil Procedure.Â  If the legislature sought to limit the applicability of Rule
  11 to PCR proceedings as it sought to limit the discovery process, the legislature
  would have inserted constricting language to that effect in the Act.Â 
  Additionally, the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure support the
  conclusion that Rule 11 is applicable to PCR actions.Â   
The South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure â€œgovern the procedure in all South Carolina courts in all suits of a civil nature . . . .â€ Rule 1, SCRCP
  (emphasis added).Â  Furthermore, the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  apply to PCR actions â€œto the extent that they are not inconsistent with the
  Act.â€Â  Rule 71.1(a), SCRCP.  
When
  interpreting language of a court rule, the same rules of construction employed
  in interpreting statutes apply.Â  State v. Brown, 344 S.C. 302, 307, 543 S.E.2d
  568, 571 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œTherefore, the words of [the
  rule] must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle
  or forced construction to limit or expand the rule.â€Â  Id. (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).Â  Given the plain language of
  Rules 1 and 71.1 and that Rule 11 is consistent with the Act, ample
  justification exists to conclude Rule 11 applies to PCR actions.[5]Â  See Leamon
    v. State, 363 S.C. 432, 434, 611 S.E.2d 494, 495 (2005) (holding
  PCR actions are governed by the usual rules of civil procedure); Sutton v.
    State, 361 S.C. 644, 647, 606 S.E.2d 779, 780 (2004) (â€œA PCR action is a
  civil action generally subject to rules and statutes that apply in civil
  proceedings.â€) overruled on other grounds by Â Bray v. State, 366
  S.C. 137, 620 S.E.2d 743 (2005); Gamble v. State, 298 S.C. 176, 177, 379
  S.E.2d 118, 118 (1989) (holding the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  apply to all civil actions, a petition for PCR is a civil action, the Act
  specifically incorporates the applicable rules of civil practice, and Rule
  41(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure applies to PCR petitions).
We
  are cognizant that â€œ[c]ourts treat PCR differently than traditional civil
  cases.â€Â  Wade, 348 S.C.
  at 263, 559 S.E.2d at 847.Â 
  However, given the plain language of the Act and the South Carolina Rules of
  Civil Procedure, we conclude the PCR court has authority to issue Rule 11
  sanctions against a PCR applicant.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.Â  
CURETON
  and GOOLSBY, AJJ., concur.

[1] 
State v. Blair, 275 S.C. 529, 273 S.E.2d 536 (1981). 
 
[2] 
Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963). 
 
[3] Rule 11 provides: â€œThe signature of an attorney or party [on a pleading, motion, or
  other paper] constitutes a certificate by him that he has read the pleading,
  motion or other paper; that to the best of his knowledge, information and
  belief there is good ground to support it; and that it is not interposed for delay.Â 
  If a pleading, motion or other paper is signed in violation of this Rule, the
  court . . . may impose upon the person who signed it, a represented party, or
  both, an appropriate sanction, which may include an order to pay to the other
  party . . . the amount of the reasonable expenses incurred because of the
  filing of the pleading, motion or other paper, including a reasonable
  attorneyâ€™s fee.â€  
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-10
  et seq. (Supp. 2006).
[5] Hiott does not argue the
  PCR judge abused his discretion by imposing sanctions.Â  The sole issue on
  appeal is whether the PCR judge had authority to issue Rule 11 sanctions.Â 
  Thus, we do not address whether the PCR judge abused his discretion in
  sanctioning Hiott.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 344, 585 S.E.2d
  281, 283 (2003) (stating issues not argued in a partyâ€™s brief are deemed
  abandoned).

title: Bartlett v. Rachels
description: Kathleen M. Bartlett appeals the family court's order finding her former husband, James P. Rachels, was not in contempt of court for allegedly violating a provision of the parties' 1996 divorce decree and denying her request for attorney's fees.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Kathleen M. Bartlett, Appellant,
				v.
				James P.
      Rachels, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Kellum W. Allen, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4303
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 11, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James W. Corley, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				James P. Rachels, of Ridgecrest, CA, pro se.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Kathleen
  M. Bartlett (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding her former husband,
  James P. Rachels (Husband), was not in contempt of court for allegedly violating
  a provision of the partiesâ€™ 1996 divorce decree and denying her request for
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The parties married on June 28, 1986, and were
  divorced on January 30, 1996.Â  In 2006, Wife sought to hold Husband in contempt
  for his â€œdeliberate and willful failure to pay a percentage of his military
  pension to [Wife],â€ as ordered in the divorce decree.Â   

	The provisions of the decree at issue provide: 
	
	
		
			
				a.  
				
				[Wife] . . . shall be 
				entitled to receive military retired pay upon the retirement 
				from the United States Navy of [Husband] . . . .
 
			
			
				b. 
				[Wife] is entitled to 
				Twenty-two and one-half percent (22Â½%) of the military retired 
				pay of an E-7 rank as a distribution of marital property and 
				directs the Defense Finance and Accounting Center [DFAC] . . . to pay Twenty-two and one-half percent (22Â½%) of
  an E-7 retired pay directly to [Wife] upon [Husbandâ€™s] retirement from the
  Navy.
 
			
			
				c.  
				
				This Order may be served on 
				the Secretary of the Defense, Secretary of the Navy, or designee 
				as authorized under 10 U.S.C. Section 1408[.]
			
		
	

At the hearing, Wife testified regarding her understanding of the
  retirement provision: â€œMy lawyer at the time told me that all I would have to
  do is write into [DFAC].â€Â  However, she also acknowledged that Husband had
  written a letter to her lawyer a few months after the divorce, stating he would
  receive a pension only if he completed twenty years of active duty, and
  notifying her DFAC â€œwill not garnish my pension [as stated in the decree] due
  to the amount of time of our marriage.Â  However, I can request an allotment be
  sent directly to [Wife] at the time of my retirement.â€Â   
Following the partiesâ€™ divorce, Husband remained on active duty until
  retiring in 2005 with twenty years of service. Â On October 2, 2005, one month
  before his retirement, Husband again sent Wife a letter concerning the
  retirement provision: â€œOur divorce decree has a section dealing with my
  retirement pension that is very ambiguous.Â  I think it is important that we
  clear up this ambiguity before I retire. . . .Â  Please call me ASAP so we can
  discuss this issue.â€Â  Husband stated that Wifeâ€™s counsel responded: â€œNeither
  Mrs. Bartlett nor I see any reason to compromise.â€Â   
Wife nonetheless applied to DFAC for garnishment.Â  But on December
  15, 2005, DFAC denied Wifeâ€™s application, stating: â€œUnder the USFSPA [Uniformed
  Services Former Spousesâ€™ Protection Act, 10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408] we can honor a
  request for payments from retired/retainer pay as property only in those cases
  where the parties were married for at least 10 years during which the member
  performed at least 10 years of creditable military service.â€Â   
In regard to Husbandâ€™s failure to pay Wife her portion of the
  pension, the family court held that the divorce decree â€œappears ambiguous and
  imprecise and this court cannot hold [Husband] in deliberate willful contempt
  for that reason.â€Â Â  Wife now appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an appeal from the
  family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364
  S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  However, this broad scope of review
  does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings or to ignore the
  fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Contempt
â€œAn
  adult who willfully violates, neglects, or refuses to obey or perform a lawful
  order of the court . . . may be proceeded against for contempt of court.â€ S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2006).Â  For
  purposes of contempt, an act is willful if â€œdone voluntarily and intentionally
  with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific
  intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say,
  with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€Â  Spartanburg County Dept. of Social Services v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83,
  370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988).Â   
â€œBefore
  a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically
  reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Â Henderson v. Henderson, 298
  S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  â€œThe moving party must show the
  existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance
  with the order.â€Â  Eaddy v. Oliver, 345 S.C. 39, 42, 545 S.E.2d 830, 832
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Â 
On
  appeal, a decision regarding contempt should be reversed only if no evidence
  supports it or the trial court has abused its discretion.Â  Brandt v. Gooding,
  368 S.C. 618, 627, 630 S.E.2d 259, 263 (2006). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either
  when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based
  upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€Â  Browning v. Browning,
  366 S.C. 255, 263, 621 S.E.2d 389, 393 (Ct. App. 2005).
Wife
  contends the family court abused its discretion because the record lacks evidence
  supporting the courtâ€™s conclusion.Â  However, there is no language in the agreement requiring Husband to specifically request a voluntary allotment
  on behalf of Wife.Â  The agreement clearly instructed DFAC, not Husband, to
  submit a portion of Husbandâ€™s pension
  to Wife.Â  In addition, Husband made
  attempts to contact Wife, to address DFACâ€™s refusal to garnish his pension on
  behalf of Wife, and to resolve ambiguities in the order.Â  Because Husbandâ€™s failure to request a voluntary
  allotment or submit a portion of his pension to Wife was not in direct
  contravention to any specific requirement in the order, the family court did
  not abuse its discretion in failing to
  hold Husband in contempt.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
II.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
  and Costs
Wife also argues
  the family court erred by failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  However,
  â€œ[a]n award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned
  absent abuse by the trial court.â€Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353,
  365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  In awarding attorneyâ€™s fees the family court
  should consider the following factors: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or
  her own attorneyâ€™s fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the attorney;
  (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s
  fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living. Â E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471,
  476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â   
Considering the
  aforementioned factors, the family court did not abuse its discretion by
  refusing to award attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  First, Wifeâ€™s attorney did not
  obtain a beneficial result.Â  Second, Wife fails to present any compelling
  evidence in regard to the other factors indicating that she should have been
  awarded attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, we find no error.
CONCLUSION
The order
  of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, J. and
  THOMAS, J. concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

description: In this criminal case, the appellate court considers whether the circuit court erred by: (1) refusing to suppress Appellantâ€™s statement because allegedly the police in South Carolina agreed to drop North Carolina charges; and (2) whether Appellantâ€™s statement to police was freely and voluntarily given under the totality of circumstances test where Appellant contends the statement was given because of a promise by police to â€œhelp him.â€
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Tim Wayne Arrowood, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4304
  Heard October 10, 2007 â€“ Filed October 17,
2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission of
          Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
          and Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold
          W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Â Tim Wayne Arrowood appeals his convictions for first-degree
  burglary and larceny, arguing the trial
  judge erred by refusing to suppress Arrowoodâ€™s statements to police.Â 
  Specifically, Arrowood contends his statements to police were involuntary and
  inadmissible because they were induced by promises of leniency.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 28, 2004, Dayle Walker reported
  a toolbox missing from his residence in Campobello, South Carolina.Â  Walker explained he
  always kept the toolbox in an enclosed porch at the back of his home, and, upon
  returning from work, he noticed it was missing.Â  
Officer Tim Tucker of
  the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Department was assigned to investigate the
  burglary of Walkerâ€™s toolbox.Â  On February 16, 2004, Tucker met with Arrowood
  in Rutherford County, North Carolina, where Arrowood was in police custody on unrelated
  charges.Â  Tucker questioned Arrowood concerning several â€œtrailer thefts and the
  theft of a Corvetteâ€ in Spartanburg County. 
A
  few days later, Tucker and Officer David Oglesby met with Arrowood, who had
  been transported to the Spartanburg County Jail.[1] Â Oglesby, an investigator for Cherokee County Sheriffâ€™s Department, became
  involved because Arrowood was under investigation for charges in Cherokee County.Â  On February 18, 2004, Arrowood agreed to accompany Tucker and Oglesby to
  the scenes in Spartanburg County where Arrowood committed various criminal
  acts.Â  Tucker had previously advised Arrowood of his Miranda rights and
  Arrowood understood, waived those rights, and signed a pre-interrogation waiver
  form.Â  
While
  riding with the officers, Arrowood dictated the following statement to Oglesby:

  A few
    weeks ago me and Curtis Mason were riding around in Curtis Masonâ€™s truck. Â He
    pulled into a drive off highway â€“ just drive off highway just across I-26. Â Curtis
    pulled up to the side of the house and we got out and got a big red toolbox off
    the back porch and we put it in Curtisâ€™ truck and left. Â Curtis took me back
    home.Â  Curtis left the toolbox at my house on Sandy Clay Road. Â Curtis came
    back and later got the toolbox.Â  

In addition, Arrowood read
  and signed the following statement:

  I have
    read this statement consisting of one page and I swear or affirm the statement
    that I [have] just given is the truth and nothing but the truth, so help me
    God.Â  I also swear this statement was given freely and voluntarily, and I have
    received a copy of this statement. 

A grand jury
  indicted Arrowood for burglary in the
  first degree and larceny.Â  
Despite attesting
  that his first statement â€œwas given freely and voluntarily,â€ Arrowood contends
  his statements were induced by promises of leniency made by Officer Tucker.Â  The
  trial judge conducted a hearing pursuant to Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964), to determine the voluntariness of Arrowoodâ€™s statements.Â  Arrowood
  testified that in Rutherford County, Tucker â€œsaid I got you for the Corvette
  but if youâ€™ll give me the Corvette up, I will get these charges up here dropped
  and have you brought back to South Carolina.â€Â  Arrowood alleged that in Spartanburg County, â€œ[Officer Tucker] told
  [Arrowood] if [Arrowood] would help him, he would help [Arrowood]â€ by getting
  â€œall of [Arrowoodâ€™s] charges [to] run concurrentâ€ and having â€œthe charges in North Carolina [dropped].â€Â  Arrowood claimed Oglesby told him the officers would â€œput all
  of [Arrowoodâ€™s] bonds together and put it in one capâ€ if Arrowood â€œhelpedâ€ in
  the investigation.Â  Purportedly, Oglesby related this same information to
  Arrowoodâ€™s sister a day or two later. 
Contrary
  to Arrowoodâ€™s contentions, Tucker and Oglesby professed neither officer
  promised Arrowood anything for his statements. Â Indeed, in the Denno hearing Tucker indicated:

  Q: Now, during this time at jail, did yâ€™all make promises
    Â Â Â Â Â to [Arrowood]?
  A:
    Â No, sir.
  Q:
    Â Did you threaten [Arrowood] in any way?
  A: Â No, sir. 

On direct examination Oglesby
  averred: 

  Q:
    Â Were any promises made to [Arrowood]?
  A:
    Â No, sir.
  Q:
    Either about Spartanburg charges or Cherokee charges?
  A:
    No, sir. Â I can assure you not from Cherokee County.
  Q:
    Okay.Â  Did you hear Detective Tucker make any promises?
  A:
    Â No, Sir.

Additionally, Tucker declared
  neither he nor Oglesby coerced Arrowood into giving a statement.Â  Oglesbyâ€™s testimony corroborated Tuckerâ€™s:

  Q:
    Did either one of you coerce [Arrowood] in any way?
  A:
    No, Sir.
  Q:
    Did [Arrowood] ultimately give a written statement?
  A:
    Yes, sir, [Arrowood] did. 

Tucker explained he
  may have made the following statement to Arrowood during a portion of the
  interrogation and prior to the challenged statements: Â 

  If I
    told him I could help him that would mean that I told him it would be in the
    courtroom if he cooperated. Â That would be the only thing, that if I ever told
    him anything that that would be what I would tell him that I would say Timothy
    Wayne Arrowood cooperated with police in his cases.

On cross-examination, Oglesby maintained he
  did not discuss bonds with Arrowood: 

  Q:
    Do you remember any discussion with Mr. Arrowood about a bond?
  A:
    I donâ€™t discuss bonds.
  Q:
    Never?
  A:
    Thatâ€™s up to the magistrateâ€™s office and the solicitorâ€™s office.

Under
  cross-examination before the jury, both Tucker and Oglesby avowed they did not
  promise Arrowood leniency.Â  The officers acknowledged they only offered to
  speak on Arrowoodâ€™s behalf to confirm that Arrowood cooperated with their
  investigation.Â  
Arrowood moved to have his statements to police suppressed,
  alleging they were induced by promises of leniency. Â The trial judge denied
  Arrowoodâ€™s motion, leaving the determination of the statementsâ€™ voluntariness
  to the jury. Â Specifically, the trial judge ruled: 

  Based on
    everything that I heard, the totality of the manner in which the statements
    were made and they were given, Iâ€™m going to find that the statements were
    freely and voluntarily made. Â Iâ€™m going to allow the statements to be admitted.
    Now, whether or not, you know, the jury can still consider the statements and
    find that they do not - - and give them very little weight, but I will allow it
    to be admitted.Â  

The jury returned a verdict of guilty, and the trial judge
  sentenced Arrowood to life imprisonment for burglary and five years of
  imprisonment for larceny.[2] Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  trial judge determines the admissibility of a statement upon proof of its
  voluntariness by a preponderance of the evidence. Â State v. Washington, 296 S.C. 54, 55, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988); State v. Smith,
  268 S.C. 349, 354, 234 S.E.2d 19, 21 (1977).Â  If admitted, the jury determines
  whether the statement was freely and voluntarily given beyond a reasonable
  doubt.Â  Washington, 296 S.C. at 55-56, 370 S.E.2d at 612.Â  
Factual
  conclusions as to the voluntariness of a statement will not be disturbed on
  appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse of discretion.Â  State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 242, 471 S.E.2d 689, 695 (1996); Reed
      v. Becka, 333 S.C. 676, 685, 511
  S.E.2d 396, 401 (Ct. App. 1999). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  Id.; State v.
    Douglas,367 S.C. 498, 626
  S.E.2d 59 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted June 7, 2007; State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d
  381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Accordingly, the appellate courts are â€œbound by fact
  findings in response to motions preliminary to trial when the findings are
  supported by the evidence and not clearly wrong or controlled by error of
  law.â€Â  Reed, 333 S.C. at 685, 511 S.E.2d at 401 (citing State v.
    Amerson, 311 S.C. 316, 320, 428 S.E.2d 871, 873 (1993)).Â  When reviewing a
  trial judgeâ€™s ruling concerning voluntariness, the appellate court does not re-evaluate
  the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but
  simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Arrowood
  argues the trial judge erred in refusing to
  suppress his statements to police because the statements were induced by promises
  of leniency, rendering them involuntary and inadmissible. Â We disagree.
 The
  process for determining whether a statement is voluntary, and thus admissible,
  is bifurcated; it involves determinations by both the judge and the jury.Â 
  First, the trial judge must conduct an evidentiary hearing, outside the
  presence of the jury, where the State must show the statement was made
  voluntarily by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 376 (1964).Â  If the statement is found to have been given
  voluntarily, it is then submitted to the jury, where its voluntariness must be
  established beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Washington, 296 S.C.
  54, 56, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988).
A
  statement obtained as a result of custodial interrogation is inadmissible
  unless the suspect was advised of and voluntarily waived his or her rights
  under Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 498-99 (1966). Â See also State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001).Â  If a
  suspect is advised of his Miranda rights, but chooses to make a
  statement, the burden is on the State to prove by a preponderance of the
  evidence that his rights were voluntarily waived. Â Saltz, 346 S.C. at
  136, 551 S.E.2d at 252; State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391
  S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990); Washington, 296 S.C. at 54, 370 S.E.2d at 611.Â  
Where
  â€œthe evidence conflicts as to whether a defendantâ€™s statement is voluntary, it
  is, in the first instance, the province of the trial court to determine this
  factual issue by the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  State v. Howard,
  296 S.C. 481, 492-93, 374 S.E.2d 284, 290 (1988); Washington, 296 S.C. at 54, 370
  S.E.2d at 611; State v. Adams, 279 S.C. 228, 235, 306 S.E.2d 208, 212 (1983).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s determination of the voluntariness
  of the statement must be made on the totality of the circumstances, including
  the background, experience, and conduct of the accused.Â  Saltz, 346 S.C. at 136, 551 S.E.2d at
  252; Rochester, 301 S.C. at 200, 391 S.E.2d at 247; Howard, 296
  S.C. at 488, 374 S.E.2d at 288; State v. Linnen, 278 S.C. 175, 179, 293
  S.E.2d 851, 853-54 (1982); State
    v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 462, 272 S.E.2d
  634, 636 (1980). Â â€œIn order to secure the admission of a
  defendantâ€™s statement, the State must affirmatively show the statement was
  voluntary and taken in compliance with Miranda.â€Â  State v.
    Middleton,
  288 S.C. 21, 25, 339 S.E.2d 692, 694 (1986).
Once the trial
  judge determines the statement is admissible, it is up to the jury to
  ultimately find, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the statement was voluntarily
  made.Â  State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 243, 471 S.E.2d 689, 695
  (1996); State v. Callahan, 263 S.C. 35, 41, 208 S.E.2d 284, 286 (1974).Â  
A
  statement â€œmay not be extracted by any sort of threats or violence, [or]
  obtained by any direct or implied promises, however slight, [or] by the
  exertion of improper influence.â€Â  Rochester, 301 S.C. at 200, 391 S.E.2d at 247 (citing Hutto v. Ross, 429 U.S. 28, 30 (1976) (brackets in original)).Â  Moreover, â€œa statement induced
  by a promise of leniency is involuntary only if so connected with the
  inducement as to be a consequence of the promise.â€Â  Saltz, 346 S.C. at
  136, 551 S.E.2d at 252.Â  See also State v. Peake, 291 S.C.
  138, 139, 352 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1987); State v. Broome, 268 S.C. 99, 232
  S.E.2d 324 (1977). Â The pertinent inquiry is, as always, whether the defendantâ€™s
  will was â€œoverborne.â€Â  Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. at 244, 471 S.E.2d at 695.
In State v. Peake, the defendant was convicted of murder and sentenced to
  life imprisonment.Â  291 S.C. at 138, 352 S.E.2d at 488.Â  Peake appealed,
  arguing the trial judge erred in admitting a statement Peake made while in
  police custody.Â  The Court found an investigating officer induced Peakeâ€™s
  statement by promising the State would not seek the death penalty.Â  Id.Â  At the suppression hearing, the investigating officer admitted that he did, in
  fact, guarantee the State would not seek the death penalty if Peake surrendered
  his statement.Â  Id.Â  The Court ruled the promise of leniency, tendered
  by an officer in a position of apparent authority, rendered Peakeâ€™s statement
  involuntary and inadmissible.Â  Id.Â  
Contrastively,
  in Rochester, the defendant argued his confession was improperly induced
  by a polygraph examinerâ€™s comment that it would be in Rochesterâ€™s best interest
  to tell the truth. Â 301 S.C. at 199, 391 S.E.2d at 246.Â  The Court found the
  examinerâ€™s statement â€œ[s]tanding alone . . . did not constitute the kind of
  hope of reward or benefit condemned by this Court in Peake.â€ 301 S.C. at
  200-01, 391 S.E.2d at 247.â€).Â  Â Â 
Arrowood asserts his statements
  were not freely and voluntarily given because they were induced by the officersâ€™
  promises to â€œhelpâ€ as long as he cooperated with the investigation. Â Arrowood
  claims the â€œhelpâ€ promised was to have the North Carolina charges dropped,
  secure a low bond, and have other charges run concurrently.Â  Tucker and Oglesby
  categorically denied making those promises.Â  Instead, the officers insist the
  only â€œhelpâ€ they offered Arrowood
  was to testify in court that he cooperated with the investigation.Â  Under precedent emanating from South Carolina
  jurisprudence, the officersâ€™ offer to attest to Arrowoodâ€™s cooperation did not
  constitute promises of leniency. Â See Saltz, 346 S.C. at 136, 551
  S.E.2d at 252; Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. at 244, 471 S.E.2d at 695; Rochester, 301 S.C. at 200-01, 391 S.E.2d at
  247; Howard, 296 S.C. at 492-93, 374 S.E.2d at 290; Peake, 291
  S.C. at 139, 352 S.E.2d at 488; Broome, 268 S.C. at 99, 232 S.E.2d at 325.Â  Consequently,
  Arrowood produced his statements in the mere â€œhopeâ€ of leniency based on his
  cooperation, rather than as the consequence of promises.Â  
Unlike
  the uncontroverted evidence in Peake, at the Denno hearing Arrowoodâ€™s
  testimony challenged the officersâ€™ denial that they promised him leniency.Â  The
  Court encountered similarly conflicting testimony in State v. Howard.Â 
  296 S.C. at 492, 374 S.E.2d at 289. Â Howard asserted his statement was involuntary
  because it was induced by a promise to consolidate all his offenses into one
  life sentence.Â  296 S.C. at 492, 374 S.E.2d at 289.Â  At the suppression
  hearing, the agent allegedly promising consolidation testified he discussed
  with Howard the possibility of â€œwrapping up all the charges, but never made any
  promises.â€ Â Id. at 492, 374 S.E.2d at 290.Â  The agent insisted he told
  Howard he would explore the possibility of consolidation, â€œbut [could] not
  promise one thing.â€Â  Id.Â  In holding Howardâ€™s statement was properly
  admitted, the Court emphasized that when evidence of voluntariness is
  conflicting, the trial judge determines the factual issue by the preponderance
  of evidence.Â  Id.Â  
Here,
  although Arrowoodâ€™s testimony completely contradicted the officerâ€™s testimony,
  it was within the trial judgeâ€™s province to determine the admissibility of the statements
  by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s determination is not in
  error if there is any evidence in the record to support it.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We hold the record
  contains evidence sufficient to support the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion that
  Arrowoodâ€™s statements were freely and voluntarily given under the totality of
  the circumstances.Â  Accordingly, the admission of Arrowoodâ€™s statements was not
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Arrowoodâ€™s conviction and sentence are 
AFFIRMED.
THOMAS, J., and
  CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] The record on appeal does not fully explain the
  circumstances of Arrowoodâ€™s transfer from Rutherford County, North Carolina to Spartanburg County or the disposition of the charges in North Carolina.Â  
[2] Prior to trial, the State served a notice of a life
  sentence pursuant to section 17-25-45 of the South Carolina Code (1976) because
  of Arrowoodâ€™s prior burglary convictions.Â

title: State v. Gault
description: Herbert Gault appeals the circuit court's affirmance of his conviction of disorderly conduct.  He argues the magistrate court erred in refusing to direct a verdict in his favor and in improperly excluding relevant evidence.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Herbert Edward Gault, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4305
  Heard September 9, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  19, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        J. Faulkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, Senior
          Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of the Office of the
          Attorney General of Columbia; and Â Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of
          Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  Herbert
  Gault appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to affirm his conviction of public
  disorderly conduct.Â  Specifically, he argues the magistrate court erred in
  refusing to direct a verdict in his favor and in improperly excluding relevant
  evidence.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On April 14, 2005, Officer Albert B. Phillips
  of the Cherokee County Metro Narcotics Unit observed a car swerving repeatedly.Â 
  Officer Phillips was prepared that day to work undercover, wearing a Fila
  tee-shirt, a black jacket, and a skull cap. Â After observing the swerving car,
  Officer Phillips initiated a traffic stop in his undercover vehicle, a black
  Pontiac Trans Am with tinted windows. Â He placed a flashing blue light on the
  front dash of his undercover vehicle to initiate the stop. Â The driver, Gault, an
  owner of an automotive repair store, drove several hundred yards and pulled
  over at his place of business. Â While Phillips remained in the car to call in
  the stop to the dispatcher, Gault exited his vehicle and approached the
  officer.Â  Gaultâ€™s demeanor was loud and belligerent according to Phillips, and
  he insisted that Phillips was not an officer even after seeing a badge. Â A
  uniformed officer arrived twelve minutes after Phillips made the initial stop.Â 
  He testified to Gaultâ€™s continued belligerence and yelling. Â 
Gault was charged with reckless driving and public disorderly
  conduct. Â The jury found Gault not guilty of reckless driving and guilty of
  public disorderly conduct. Â He appealed to the circuit court arguing the same
  issues that he presents today. The circuit court affirmed the magistrate court.
  Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  Thus, an appellate
  court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gault
  first argues the circuit court erred in affirming the magistrate courtâ€™s
  decision to deny his motion for directed verdict. Â We disagree. 
When ruling on a
  motion for directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or
  nonexistence of evidence, not its weight. State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279,
  292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006).Â  In reviewing a motion for directed verdict,
  the appellate court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the
  light most favorable to the State. Â Id.
In the present
  case, evidence exists to support a verdict of public disorderly conduct. Â The
  pertinent part of the public disorderly conduct statute provides that it is a
  misdemeanor for a person to â€œbe found on any highway or at any public place or
  public gathering . . . Â otherwise conducting himself in a disorderly or
  boisterous manner,â€ or to, â€œuse obscene or profane language on any highway or
  at any public place or gathering . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-530 (2003). Â Officer Phillips testified that after Gault pulled into his place of
  business, Gault jumped out of his car and screamed, â€œI donâ€™t know you.Â 
  Somebody is going to kill you for this.â€Â  He testified that Gault was loudly using
  profanity and repeatedly saying that he looked like a hoodlum.Â  Phillips further
  testified that upon identifying himself as an officer and showing Gault his
  badge, Gault grabbed his badge and pulled Phillips close, saying â€œI donâ€™t know
  you.â€Â  An officer who arrived at the scene shortly thereafter also testified to
  Gaultâ€™s continued belligerent, threatening, and disorderly behavior. Â Because evidence
  exists to support a charge against Gault for public disorderly conduct, the
  magistrate court judge did not err in refusing to direct a verdict. Â 
On appeal to the
  circuit court, Gault also argued that his speech when confronting the officers could
  not constitute public disorderly conduct because it did not rise to the level
  of â€œfighting words,â€ and was therefore protected by the First Amendment
  pursuant to State v. Perkins, 306 S.C. 353, 355, 412 S.E.2d 385, 386
  (1991) (â€œ[A]ppellants cannot be punished under Â§ 16-17-530(a) for voicing their
  objections to sheriffâ€™s officers where the record indicates no use of fighting
  words.â€). Â Gault also advances this argument in his appeal, however, because the
  issue was not raised before the magistrate, it is not preserved for our review.
  Â 
In Gaultâ€™s motion
  for a directed verdict, he made no mention of the First Amendment, Perkins,
  or the â€œfighting wordsâ€ exception. Â Rather, he argued there was no
  evidence that Gault â€œthreatenedâ€ Officer Phillips, and that Gault was rightfully
  agitated because he initially thought Phillips was not a policeman. Â See State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 134, 620 S.E.2d 737, 741 (2005)
  (holding an issue not preserved when one ground is raised to the trial court
  and another ground is raised on appeal); See In re Care and Treatment
    of Corley, 365 S.C. 252, 258, 616 S.E.2d 441, 444 (Ct. App. 2005) (explaining
  that constitutional issues, like most others, must be raised to and ruled upon
  by the trial court to be preserved for appeal). Â 
Gault next argues the
  circuit court erred in affirming the magistrate courtâ€™s denial of the admission
  of photographs illustrating the dark tint on Officer Phillipsâ€™ windows.Â  We
  disagree.
The admission of
  evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion. Â State
    v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 208, 631
  S.E.2d 262, 265 (2006).Â  An abuse of
  discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack
  evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law. Â Id.Â  Furthermore, for an error of law to warrant reversal
  based on admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the
  error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., that there is a
  reasonable probability the verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or
  the lack thereof. Â Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26,
  609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).
First, it is
  unclear to this court how the tint on the officerâ€™s window is relevant.Â  Gault elicited
  testimony regarding Officer Phillipsâ€™ vehicle and attire to show that Gault was
  reasonable in not believing Phillips was a law enforcement officer. Â However, a
  belief that a person is or is not a police officer is not an element of the
  charge of public disorderly conduct. Â Therefore, we find the window-tint
  evidence was properly excluded.
Further, Gault had
  already testified that the windows were tinted, so the photographs would have
  only served as cumulative evidence.Â  Because the jury was already informed of
  the tinted windows, the exclusion of the photographs showing the tint was not
  prejudicial to Gault.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court was correct in affirming
  the magistrate courtâ€™s exclusion of the evidence. Â See Rule 403, SCRE (allowing
  evidence to be excluded if its probative value is outweighed by considerations
  of needless presentation of cumulative evidence); State v. Hess, 279
  S.C. 14, 18-19, 301 S.E.2d 547, 550 (1983) (finding no abuse of discretion
  where the excluded testimony is merely cumulative of other evidence proffered
  to the jury).
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the order of the circuit court is hereby
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

title: Walton v. Mazda
description: The court affirms the circuit judge's determination that the magistrate had authority to grant summary judgment and did not abuse his discretion in doing so where plaintiff was unable to establish successor liability.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Bobby R.
      Walton, Appellant,
				v.
				Mazda of Rock Hill, Mazda USA, Lee Faile, Ken McManus, Eric Sigmon, and C.A.R.S., Defendants,
				of whom:
				Ken McManus and
      Eric Sigmon are the Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4306
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 19, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Mitchell K. Byrd, Sr., of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
				
				Lucy London McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.:Â  Bobby Walton filed this action alleging, inter alia, breach
  of contract arising from his purchase of an automobile.Â  The magistrate granted
  summary judgment to two of the defendants, Ken McManus and Eric Sigmon.Â  On
  appeal, the circuit court affirmed and we affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS
On August 31, 2002, Walton purchased a
  vehicle, and a warranty contract issued by C.A.R.S., from Mazda of Rock Hill,
  a.k.a. Faile Enterprises, Inc. Â On December 19, 2002, Faile Enterprises entered
  into an asset purchase agreement with McManus and Sigmon.Â  In January 2003,
  Walton brought the vehicle to the dealership for repairs.Â  At that time, Walton
  was informed of the sale, and McManus and Sigmon refused to honor Waltonâ€™s
  contract or warranty.Â  Walton contacted C.A.R.S. expecting it to honor the
  warranty contract.Â  C.A.R.S. notified Walton it never received the paperwork or
  payment from Mazda of Rock Hill.Â   
The
  sale and transfer of the dealership assets closed on March 27, 2003.Â  On March
  28, 2003, McManus and Sigmon assigned the asset purchase agreement to
  McManus-Sigmon, Inc., a.k.a. Team Mazda.Â   
By complaint dated
  April 2, 2003, Walton sued Mazda of Rock Hill, Mazda USA, Lee Faile, McManus,
  Sigmon, and C.A.R.S., alleging breach of contract, unfair trade practices, and
  willful and malicious conduct.Â  The magistrate granted McManusâ€™ and Sigmonâ€™s
  motion for summary judgment.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This courtâ€™s
  standard of review of a circuit courtâ€™s decision on an appeal from magistrateâ€™s
  court is limited to the correction of errors of law and this court will affirm
  the circuit court if there are any facts supporting its decision.Â  See Bowers
    v. Thomas, 373 S.C. 240, 244-45, 644 S.E.2d 751, 753 (Ct. App. 2007).[2] Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Summary Judgment
Walton
  first argues a magistrate does not have the authority to rule on a motion for
  summary judgment.Â  We disagree.

	Rule 81, SCRCP,
  provides:
	
		These
  rules [SCRCP], or any of them, shall apply to every trial court of civil
  jurisdiction within this state, within the limits of the jurisdiction and
  powers of the court provided by law, and the procedure therein shall conform to
  these rules insofar as practicable. Â They shall apply insofar as practicable in
  magistrateâ€™s courts, probate courts, and family courts to the extent they are
  not inconsistent with the statutes and rules governing those courts.
	

See Rule 1, SCRCP (defining the scope of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure) and Rule 56, SCRCP
  (providing the authority to grant summary judgment).  

	Additionally,
  Rule 2, SCRMC, provides:
	
		(a) If no
  procedure is provided by these rules, the court shall proceed in a manner
  consistent with the statutory law applicable to magistrates and with circuit
  court practice in like situations but not inconsistent with these rules.
		(b) Each
  magistrate may promulgate rules for the conduct of proceedings in his court
  which are not inconsistent with these rules and the South Carolina Code of
  Laws.
	

Although there is no law within the South Carolina Rules of
  Magistrate Court specifically addressing summary judgment, the South
    Carolina Bench Book for Magistrates and Municipal Court Judges discusses
  summary judgment, explaining:

	After
  the filing of a civil case and prior to the actual trial, you may occasionally
  receive a motion for summary judgment . . . . Â Rule 56, SCRCP, which is made
  applicable to magistrateâ€™s court by Rule 81, SCRCP, allows the plaintiff or defendant . . . [to] move with or without supporting affidavits for a summary
  judgment . . . . Â Summary judgment is proper when, after reviewing the motion,
  supporting affidavits, and the pleadings, there is no genuine issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.
  . . . Â If, after a hearing, the court determines the summary judgment is
  appropriate, an order to that effect ending the case should be issued. Â 

South Carolina Bench Book for Magistrates and Municipal Court
  Judges, II-19 to II-20 (2d
  ed. 1984), available at http://www.sccourts.org/trial/magistrate/benchbook/HTML/CivilC.htm#C15 (emphasis in original).Â  
 
Therefore, we find
  Rule 56, SCRCP, applies to magistrates as members of the South Carolina court
  system.Â  The circuit court did not err in affirming the magistrateâ€™s grant of
  summary judgment because the grant of summary judgment does not exceed the
  magistrateâ€™s authority.
II.  Successor Liability
Walton
  next contends genuine issues of material fact exist as to successor liability
  and therefore the magistrate erred in granting summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
In
  the absence of a statute, a successor company is not ordinarily liable for the
  debts of a predecessor company under a theory of successor liability unless: (a)
  there was an agreement to assume such debts; (b) the circumstances surrounding
  the transaction indicate a consolidation of the two corporations; (c) the successor
  company was a mere continuation of the predecessor company; or (d) the transaction
  was fraudulently entered into for the purpose of wrongfully denying creditor
  claims.Â  Simmons v. Mark Lift Indus., 366 S.C. 308, 312, 622 S.E.2d 213,
  215 (2005) (citing Brown v. American Ry. Express Co., 128 S.C. 428, 123
  S.E. 97 (1924)).
(a)  Agreement to
  Assume Obligations Exception
Walton
  alleges an issue of material fact is present regarding whether McManus and
  Sigmon agreed to assume Mazda of Rock Hillâ€™s debts or obligations.Â  We
  disagree.
â€œWhen
  a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions according to the
  terms the parties used, understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Oates, 356 S.C. 378, 381, 588 S.E.2d
  643, 645 (Ct. App. 2003).Â   
The
  Asset Purchase Agreement states that McManus and Sigmon purchased the assets
  â€œfree and clear of any liens, encumbrances, restrictions, charges, and equities
  of any kind whatsoever.â€Â  Further, the Asset Purchase Agreement states: Â â€œPurchaser
  is not assuming any liabilities of Seller.â€Â  Walton focuses on language in the
  Asset Purchase Agreement that obliges McManus and Sigmon to purchase, at cost, all
  repair work in progress.Â  Under this provision, McManus and Sigmon were to
  finish customer repair work, and the proceeds were to be divided equally between
  the parties. Â We agree with the magistrate and circuit court that this
  provision, in light of the other provisions in the contract, does not convert
  the agreement from solely an asset sale to a sale of assets and liabilities.Â 
  Therefore, Waltonâ€™s reliance on this provision is misplaced and the magistrate
  did not err in finding no genuine issues of material fact exist regarding this
  exception.
(b)  Consolidation
  Exception
Walton
  argues there is a material issue of fact whether the sale between Mazda of Rock
  Hill and McManus and Sigmon was simply a consolidation.Â  We disagree.
As
  the circuit court properly determined, there is no evidence in the record
  indicating the transaction between Mazda of Rock Hill and McManus and Sigmon amounted
  to a consolidation. Â Both McManus and Sigmon signed affidavits swearing they
  have never had any interest in Mazda of Rock Hill.Â  The asset purchase agreement
  clearly establishes a sale between Faile Enterprises and McManus and Sigmon.Â 
  The agreement was also subject to a consultant and non-compete agreement, in
  which Faile promised not to associate with any Mazda dealership within twenty
  miles of the sold dealership and to work as a consultant for McManus and Sigmon
  for almost two years.Â  Accordingly, no factual issue prevents summary judgment based
  on this exception.  
(c)  Mere Continuation Exception
Walton
  asserts a material issue of fact exists as to whether McManus and Sigmon merely
  continued Mazda of Rock Hill.Â  We disagree.
In Simmons
  v. Mark Lift Industries, Inc., the South Carolina Supreme Court declined to
  extend the mere continuation exception to situations where there is no
  commonality between officers, directors, and shareholders of the seller and
  purchaser.Â  366 S.C. 308, 312 n.1, 622 S.E.2d 213, 215 n.1 (2005). Â As
  discussed, McManus and Sigmon did not have any relationship with Mazda of Rock
  Hill except for the purchase of the assets of the dealership.Â  Additionally,
  Faile only served McManusâ€™ and Sigmonâ€™s new organization, Team Mazda, as a
  consultant for a limited time period.Â  Therefore, we find evidence to support
  the circuit courtâ€™s finding that there was no material issue of fact supporting
  Waltonâ€™s claim of a mere continuation.Â   
(d)  Fraud
  Exception
Finally, Walton
  contends there is an issue of material fact regarding whether the asset sale
  was fraudulent.Â  To meet the fraud exception to successor liability, the
  general rule is that a successor must knowingly participate in a fraudulent
  asset transfer.Â  Richard L. Cupp, Jr., Redesigning Successor Liability,
  1999 U.Ill.L.Rev. 845, 875-76 (1999).Â  Proving such knowledge is difficult, and
  a few courts have advocated expanding the fraud section to include reviewing
  the successorâ€™s actual or constructive knowledge.Â  Id. at 888-89
  (generally discussing the fraud exception in product liability actions alleging
  successor liability).Â  Under either interpretation of the fraud exception to
  successor liability, we find no genuine issue of material fact.Â  Walton
  provides no theory supporting a claim of fraud.Â  For instance, there is no
  evidence of inadequate consideration and no indication that McManus and Sigmon
  were not bona fide purchasers for value.Â  A party opposing summary judgment
  must do more than rely on mere allegations.Â  Dyer v. Moss, 284 S.C. 208,
  211, 325 S.E.2d 69, 70 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  We find no error by the trial court in
  affirming the magistrateâ€™s grant of summary judgment on the fraud exception.Â  
 
Based on the
  foregoing, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the masterâ€™s
  grant of summary judgment in favor of McManus and Sigmon.
AFFIRMED. 
WILLIAMS,
  J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  The circuit courtâ€™s standard of review of a magistrateâ€™s order is not at
  issue in this case.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§18-7-170 (1985) (prescribing
  the circuit courtâ€™s standard of review of magistratesâ€™ orders).
