description: In this criminal case Miller appeals his conviction for conspiracy to traffic methamphetamine, arguing the trial judge erred by:  (1) admitting incriminating oral and written statements, which he claims were given as the result of promises of leniency; and (2) denying his motion to enforce an alleged eight-to-twelve-year plea agreement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Marshall
      Miller, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Abbeville County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4307
Heard October 10, 2007 â€“ Filed October 19,
  2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Chief, State Grand Jury, Jennifer D. Evans, and Assistant
  Attorney General, State Grand Jury, DeWayne Pearson, all of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.: Â  Marshall Miller (â€œMillerâ€) appeals
  his conviction for conspiracy to traffic methamphetamine, arguing the trial
  judge erred by:Â  (1) admitting incriminating oral and written statements, which
  he claims were given as the result of promises of leniency; and (2) denying his
  motion to enforce an alleged eight-to-twelve-year plea agreement.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
In November 1999, local authorities began
  investigating a large methamphetamine conspiracy, referred to as â€œCrankdown.â€Â  The
  State Law Enforcement Division (â€œSLEDâ€) began its investigation in 2002.Â 
 
On September 10, 2002, the statewide grand jury indicted Miller and
  fourteen other individuals for conspiracy to traffic more than 100 grams of
  methamphetamine.Â  Miller was arrested on September 24, 2002.Â  Subsequently, Frank
  Oâ€™Neil, a SLED agent, attempted to obtain a statement from Miller.Â  Oâ€™Neil declared
  the attempt was not fruitful because Miller only informed the agent about other
  people involved, not Millerâ€™s own involvement.Â   
Oâ€™Neil averred defense attorney Kim Varner
  said Miller was willing to cooperate fully.Â  As a result, Oâ€™Neil arranged for
  Miller to be interviewed by SLED agents Chester Bragg and Constance Sonnefeld.Â 
  Bragg and Sonnefeld conducted three interviews with Miller.Â  The first debriefing
  occurred on February 13, 2003, at the Laurens City Police Department.Â  Bragg established
  that Miller was advised of his rights.Â  He was coherent and not threatened in
  any way.Â  Both agents professed that no plea agreements or promises of leniency
  were made during the meeting.Â   
The second and third interviews between Marshall and SLED officers
  were conducted on February 25, 2003, and March 4, 2003.Â  During all three
  sessions, Miller orally provided information concerning the methamphetamine
  conspiracy.Â  At trial, Bragg confirmed Miller admitted using, â€œcooking,â€
  (making methamphetamine), and distributing methamphetamine.Â  Additionally,
  Miller voluntarily provided Bragg with a handwritten, thirty-six page document
  prior to the second interview.Â  This
  document listed names of various â€œcooks,â€ locations where methamphetamine could
  be purchased, â€œcookâ€ sites, people who assisted in â€œcookingâ€ methamphetamine, charges
  of police misconduct, an illegal poker house, and various other related and
  non-related information.Â  Â Â 
Prior to trial, the court conducted a hearing pursuant to Jackson
  v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964), to determine the voluntariness and
  admissibility of Millerâ€™s oral and written statements.Â  The following colloquy
  occurred during the cross-examination of agent Oâ€™Neil at the Denno hearing:

	Q:Â  When you initially sat down with Mr. Miller, not saying there
  was an agreement or anything, but was there a general discussion with Mr.
  Miller that if he would admit his involvement and fully cooperate that it was a
  possibility, not an agreement, that he could get a sentence of approximately
  fifteen years?
	A:Â  No.
	Q: Okay.Â  Was there any discussion of fifteen years at that point
  in time? Iâ€™m not saying an agreement, but a general discussion?
	A:Â  I told Mr. Miller that all he could do by cooperating was help
  himself, it was not going to hurt him.Â  I did not refer to a particular time or
  to a sentence that he could possibly receive.Â  I repeated several times, as I
  always do, that itâ€™s up to the judge that handles the case. 

Varner testified on Millerâ€™s behalf during the Denno hearing
  and claimed Assistant Attorney General Jennifer Evans orally promised a plea
  deal of eight to twelve years in exchange for Millerâ€™s guilty plea and full
  cooperation with the investigation.Â  However, Varner admitted he never memorialized
  the promise in writing.Â  Varner contended Miller gave statements to authorities
  in reliance on the alleged eight-to-twelve-year deal.Â  Although Varner averred he
  communicated the details of the agreement to Miller in front of Bragg and
  Sonnefeld, neither agent recalled the number of years being mentioned.Â  The
  following colloquy occurred during the cross-examination of Bragg at the Denno hearing:

	Q:Â  And whether I misunderstood it or whether it was correct or
  not, do you recall me telling Marshall Miller, â€œMarshall, I just got off the
  phone with Jennifer [Evans].Â  If you testify or you give your cooperation,â€
  that, â€œyou are in the eight to twelve range and expect twelve . . . you donâ€™t
  have to do this, this is your choice, youâ€™re freely and voluntarily entering
  into this, this is going to be your decision if you will take that range,â€
  whether I misunderstood my statement with [Evans] or whether that was correct
  or even if that was a lie, do you recall me making the statement to [Miller] to
  that effect?
	A:Â  I do not recall any numbers being mentioned at all.

To the same line
  of questioning, Sonnefeld responded, â€œI donâ€™t remember numbers.Â  I remember
  that if he cooperated it would be taken into consideration.â€Â   
Evans explained the only offer she extended was a formal, written
  plea agreement with a fifteen-year sentence.Â  She denied offering a plea with a
  sentence in the range of eight to twelve years.Â  In contrariety, Varner asserted
  Miller would not have provided information for a fifteen-year deal. Â â€œ[Miller] has been in jail a couple of times, this
  gentleman is very jailhouse smart, he does know how to handle himself in that
  respect, heâ€™s very familiar with the system, so to speak . . . .â€Â  The following colloquy occurred during the
  direct examination of Evans:

	A:Â  The only time we ever make plea offers is when we send out
  formal written plea offers.Â  What we do, we explain to them what we expect with
  cooperation, which is full cooperation, full debriefing, cooperation throughout
  the investigation, and at that point there is nothing promised except for the
  fact that we will take that cooperation into account.Â  Mr. Miller was indicted
  for a 25 year offense . . . we do explain to them there is really no way you
  can hurt yourself at this point, that we take the cooperation into account in
  determining a sentence, but I donâ€™t discuss sentencing and I donâ€™t discuss what
  they would be, because I donâ€™t know at that point what they know and if they
  are going to be fully honest with us.
	Q:Â  So, it would be safe to say, then, you have to get all the information
  from the defendant before you can even determine what offer you want to make
  them?
	A:Â  That is certainly the course of action that we do in all of
  our Grand Jury cases. 
	Q:Â  And is this particular instance did you make a written plea
  offer?
	A: Â Yes, I did.

The
  written plea offer was sent to Miller on April 29, 2003, in which the State
  offered a recommendation of fifteen years for him to plead guilty and fully
  cooperate.Â  Miller had two opportunities to plead guilty but declined to do
  so.Â   
Miller moved to enforce the purported eight-to-twelve-year plea
  agreement.Â  The trial judge found Millerâ€™s statements were voluntary and denied
  his motion to enforce the plea agreement.Â  Miller failed to appear for trial
  and was tried in his absence.Â  The jury found him guilty and the trial
  judge imposed a twenty-five-year sentence.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases,
  the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Baccus,
  367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  Thus, an appellate court is bound
  by the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.; State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The appellate courts are â€œbound by fact findings in response to motions
  preliminary to trial when the findings are supported by the evidence and not
  clearly wrong or controlled by error of law.â€Â  Reed v. Becka, 333 S.C.
  676, 685, 511 S.E.2d 396, 401 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing State v. Amerson,
  311 S.C. 316, 320, 428 S.E.2d 871, 873 (1993)).Â   
The
  trial judge determines the admissibility of a statement upon proof of its
  voluntariness by a preponderance of the evidence. Â State v. Washington, 296 S.C. 54, 55, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988); State v. Smith, 268 S.C. 349, 354, 234 S.E.2d 19, 21
  (1977).Â  The jury must determine whether the statement was freely and
  voluntarily given beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Washington, 296 S.C. at 55-56, 370 S.E.2d at 612.Â  On appeal, the conclusion of the trial judge as to the
  voluntariness of a statement will not be reversed unless so erroneous as to
  show an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 242,
  471 S.E.2d 689, 695 (1996).Â  When
  reviewing a trial judgeâ€™s ruling concerning voluntariness, the appellate court
  does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of
  the evidence, but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is
  supported by any evidence.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551
  S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Miller argues his
  statements made to law enforcement were given in reliance upon the promise of
  leniency, and therefore, were involuntary and inadmissible.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
I.  Voluntariness of
  Statements to SLED Agents
The process for determining whether a
  statement is voluntary, and thus admissible, is bifurcated; it involves
  determinations by both the judge and the jury.Â  First, the trial judge must
  conduct an evidentiary hearing, outside the presence of the jury, where the
  State must show the statement was voluntarily made by a preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Jackson
    v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 376 (1964).Â  If the
  statement is found to have been given voluntarily, it is then submitted to the
  jury, where its voluntariness must be established beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State
    v. Washington, 296 S.C. 54, 56, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988).
a.  Admissibility of
  Statements
A statement
  obtained as a result of custodial interrogation is inadmissible unless the
  suspect was advised of and voluntarily waived his rights.Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 498-500 (1966); State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551
  S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001). Â If a suspect was advised of his Miranda rights
  but made a statement, the â€œburden is on the State to prove by a preponderance
  of the evidence that his rights were voluntarily waived.â€Â  Saltz, 346 at
  135, 551 S.E.2d at 252; State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391
  S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990); State v. Washington, 296 S.C. 54, 55, 370 S.E.2d
  611, 612 (1988). Â A statement is not admissible unless it was voluntarily
  made.Â  State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 243, 471 S.E.2d 689, 694
  (1996); State v. Compton, 366 S.C. 671, 680, 623 S.E.2d 661, 666 (Ct.
  App. 2005); see also State v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 475, 385
  S.E.2d 839, 842 (1989) (â€œThe test of admissibility of a statement is voluntariness.â€).Â  This voluntariness requirement is in addition to the
  intelligent waiver mandate of Miranda.Â  See State v. Middleton,
  288 S.C. 21, 25, 339 S.E.2d 692, 694 (1986) (â€œIn order to secure the admission
  of a defendantâ€™s statement, the State must affirmatively show the statement was
  voluntary and taken in compliance with Miranda.â€) (citations
  omitted).Â  â€œIt is now axiomatic . . . that a defendant in a criminal case is
  deprived of due process of law if his conviction is founded, in whole or in
  part, upon an involuntary [statement], without regard for the truth or falsity
  of the [statement] . . . even though there is ample evidence aside from the
  [statement] to support the conviction.â€Â  Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 376 (1964).
The requirement
  that only voluntary statements be admitted is based on the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s
  right against self-incrimination, and was incorporated and made applicable to
  the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.Â  See Malloy v. Hogan,
  378 U.S. 1, 6 (1964) (â€œWe hold today that the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s exception from
  compulsory self-incrimination is also protected by the Fourteenth Amendment
  against abridgment by the States.â€).Â  In State v. Hook, this Court
  explained:

	The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, in
  relevant part, that no person â€œshall be compelled in any criminal case to be a
  witness against himself.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. V. This provision governs state
  as well as federal criminal proceedings.Â  Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1 (1964).Â  Article 1, Section 12, of the South Carolina Constitution contains a
  similar provision.Â  S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 12 (â€œ. . . nor shall any person be
  compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.â€).
	The Fifth Amendment does not, of course, operate as a blanket
  prohibition against the taking of any and all statements made by criminal
  defendants to law enforcement officials.Â  Volunteered statements, whether
  exculpatory or inculpatory, stemming from custodial interrogation or
  spontaneously offered up, are not barred by the Fifth Amendment.Â  State v.
    Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 307, 479 S.E.2d 838, 844 (Ct. App. 1996) (citing 
	Miranda
      v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966)).

State
  v. Hook, 348 S.C. 401, 409-10, 559 S.E.2d 856,
  860 (Ct. App. 2001), affâ€™d as modified, 356 S.C. 421, 590 S.E.2d 25
  (2003).Â  We
  observed that the â€œconcept that the privilege against self-incrimination
  encompasses the right to be free from being penalized for its exercise is well
  established.â€Â  Id. at 411, 559 S.E.2d at 861 (quoting Lefkowitz v.
    Cunningham, 431 U.S. 801 (1977) (â€œ[W]hen a State compels testimony by
  threatening to inflict potent
  sanctions unless the constitutional privilege is surrendered, that testimony is
  obtained in violation of the Fifth Amendment and cannot be used against the
  declarant in a subsequent criminal prosecution. . . . Â Similarly, our cases
  have established that a State may not impose substantial penalties because a
  witness elects to exercise his Fifth Amendment right not to give incriminating
  testimony against himself.â€)). Â The United States Supreme Court, in Jackson
    v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964), elucidated the rationales behind the
  prohibition against involuntary statements:

	It
  is now inescapably clear that the Fourteenth Amendment forbids the use of
  involuntary [statements] not only because of the probable unreliability of [statements]
  that are obtained in a manner deemed coercive, but also because of the
  â€˜strongly felt attitude of our society that important human values are
  sacrificed where an agency of the government, in the course of securing a
  conviction, wrings a [statement] out of an accused against his will,â€™ and
  because of â€˜the deep-rooted feeling that the police must obey the law while
  enforcing the law; that in the end life and liberty can be as much endangered from
  illegal methods used to convict those thought to be criminals as from the
  actual criminals themselves.â€™ 

378
  U.S. at 385-86 (citations omitted).
b. Voluntariness
  Determination
Under Jackson v. Denno, a defendant is entitled to a â€œreliable determination
  as to the voluntariness of his [statement] by a tribunal other than the jury
  charged with deciding his guilt or innocence.â€Â  State v. Fortner, 266
  S.C. 223, 226, 222 S.E.2d 508, 510 (1976).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, the judge makes
  this initial determination of voluntariness required by Jackson v. Denno[.]â€Â  Id. Â 
â€œA
  defendant in a criminal case is entitled to an independent evidentiary hearing
  to determine the voluntariness of statements made by the defendant prior to the
  submission of such statements to the jury.â€ Â State v. Salisbury, 330
  S.C. 250, 271, 498 S.E.2d 655, 666 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d as modified,
  343 S.C. 520, 541 S.E.2d 247 (2001); see also State v. Creech,
  314 S.C. 76, 84, 441 S.E.2d 635, 639 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œWhenever evidence is
  introduced that was allegedly obtained by conduct violative of a defendantâ€™s
  constitutional rights, the defendant is entitled to have the trial judge
  conduct an evidentiary hearing outside of the presence of the jury at the
  threshold point to establish circumstances under which it was gained.â€).Â  The
  trial judge must determine if under the totality of the circumstances a
  statement was knowingly, intelligibly, and voluntarily made.Â  State v. Saltz,
  346 S.C. 114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001); State v. Rochester, 301
  S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990); State v. Howard, 296 S.C.
  481, 488, 374 S.E.2d 284, 288 (1988); State v. Linnen, 278 S.C. 175,
  179, 293 S.E.2d 851, 853-54 (1982); State v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 462,
  272 S.E.2d 634, 636 (1980).Â   
The
  State bears the burden of showing the statement was voluntary.Â  State v. Von
    Dohlen,
  322 S.C. 234, 243, 471 S.E.2d 689, 695 (1996); State v.
    Washington,
  296 S.C. 54, 55, 370 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1988); State v. Neeley, 271 S.C.
  33, 244 S.E.2d 522 (1978); see also State v. Middleton, 288 S.C. 21,
  24, 339 S.E.2d 692, 694 (1986) (â€œIn order to secure the admission of a defendantâ€™s
  statement, the State must affirmatively show the statement was voluntary and taken in compliance with Miranda.â€).
In Washington, our supreme court addressed the standard of proof applicable to the Jackson
  v. Denno hearing:

	â€œ[T]he
  burden is on the State to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that
  his rights were voluntarily waived.â€Â  State v. Neeley, 271 S.C. 33, 40,
  244 S.E.2d 522, 526 (1978) (Emphasis supplied).
	â€œ[T]he
  prosecution must prove . . . by a preponderance of the evidence that the
  [statement] was voluntary.â€Â  Lego v. Twomey, 404 U.S. 477, 489 (1972) (Emphasis supplied).
	See
      also Colorado v. Connelly, 479
  U.S. 157 (1986); State v. Middleton, 295 S.C. 318, 368 S.E.2d 457
  (1988); In re Christopher W., 285 S.C. 329, 329 S.E.2d 769 (Ct. App.
  1985).

296 S.C. at 55, 370 S.E.2d
  612.Â  Accord State v. Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 479 S.E.2d
  838 (Ct. App. 1996).
During
  the Jackson v. Denno hearing, the trial judge must examine the totality
  of the circumstances surrounding the statement and determine whether the State
  has carried its burden of showing the statement was made voluntarily.Â  State
    v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 475, 385 S.E.2d 839, 842 (1989); State v. Doby,
  273 S.C. 704, 708, 258 S.E.2d 896, 899 (1979) (citing Schneckloth v.
    Bustamonte, 412 U.S. 218 (1973)). â€œWhere there is conflicting
  evidence as to whether [a] defendantâ€™s statement is voluntary, it is, in the
  first instance the province of the trial court to determine this factual issue
  by the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Howard, 296 S.C. at 493, 374
  S.E.2d at 290; Washington, 296 S.C. at 56, 370 S.E.2d at 612;  
Once
  the trial judge determines that the statement is admissible, it is up to the
  jury to ultimately determine, beyond a reasonable doubt, whether the statement
  was voluntarily made.Â  Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. at 243, 471 S.E.2d at 695; State
    v. Callahan, 263 S.C. 35, 41, 208 S.E.2d 284, 286 (1974) (â€œA [statement] is
  not admissible unless voluntary, and it [is] for the jury to say in the last
  analysis whether the [statement] [is] or [is] not voluntary.â€); State v.
    Clinkscales, 231 S.C. 650, 653, 99 S.E.2d 663, 664 (1957) (â€œAlthough all
  the evidence may be to the effect that a [statement] made while under arrest
  was a voluntary one, the jury may not be so convinced; and it is the jury who,
  in the final analysis, must determine the factual issue of voluntariness.â€); State
    v. Brown, 212 S.C. 237, 246, 47 S.E.2d 521, 525 (1948).Â   

	Nothing
  in [Jackson v. Denno] questioned the province or capacity of juries to
  assess the truthfulness of [statements].Â  Nothing in that opinion took from the
  jury any evidence relating to the accuracy or weight of [statements] admitted
  into evidence.Â  A defendant has been as free since Jackson as he was before to familiarize a jury with circumstances that attend the
  taking of his [statement], including facts bearing upon its weight and
  voluntariness.

Lego v. Twomey, 404 U.S. 477, 485-86 (1972).Â  Thus, the jury is
  entitled to consider the totality of the circumstances surrounding the statement
  to determine whether the statement was made voluntarily.Â  State v. Vang,
  353 S.C. 78, 84, 577 S.E.2d 225, 227-28 (Ct. App. 2003).  

	[Statements], even
  those that have been found to be voluntary, are not conclusive of guilt. . . .Â 
  Indeed, stripped of the power to describe to the jury the circumstances that
  prompted his [statement], the defendant is effectively disabled from answering
  the one question every rational juror needs answered: If the defendant is
  innocent, why did he previously admit his guilt?Â  Accordingly, regardless of
  whether the defendant marshaled the same evidence earlier in support of an
  unsuccessful motion to suppress, and entirely independent of any question of
  voluntariness, a defendantâ€™s case may stand or fall on his ability to convince
  the jury that the manner in which the [statement] was obtained casts doubt on
  its credibility. 

Crane v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 683, 689 (1986) (citations omitted).
c.  Totality
  of the Circumstances Test
The
  test of voluntariness is â€œâ€˜whether a defendantâ€™s will was overborneâ€™ by the
  circumstances surrounding the given [statement].Â  The due process test takes
  into consideration â€˜the totality of all the surrounding circumstancesâ€”both the
  characteristics of the accused and the details of the interrogation.â€™â€Â  Dickerson
    v. United States, 530 U.S. 428, 434 (2000) (citations omitted); State v.
      Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 30, 538 S.E.2d 248, 253 (2000); State v. Linnen,
  278 S.C. 175, 179, 293 S.E.2d 851, 853 (1982); State
    v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 558, 602
  S.E.2d 62, 76 (Ct. App. 2004); see also State
    v. Myers, 359 S.C. 40, 47, 596 S.E.2d 488, 492 (2004) (â€œA determination
  whether a statement was â€˜given voluntarily requires an examination of the
  totality of the circumstances.â€™â€) (citation omitted); State v. Compton,
  366 S.C. 671, 680, 623 S.E.2d 661, 666 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe test for
  determining the admissibility of a statement is whether it was knowingly,
  intelligently, and voluntarily given under the totality of the circumstances.â€)Â 
  (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).Â  â€œâ€˜The trial judgeâ€™s determination of the voluntariness of a
  statement must be made on the basis of the totality of the circumstances,
  including the background, experience and conduct of the accused.â€™â€Â  State v.
    Ledford, 351 S.C. 83, 87, 567 S.E.2d 904, 906 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting State
      v. Franklin, 299 S.C. 133, 138, 382 S.E.2d 911, 914 (1989)); accord State
        v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 475, 385 S.E.2d 839, 842 (1989); State v. Corns,
  310 S.C. 546, 552, 426 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1992). Â â€œA jury must consider the totality of the
  circumstances under which a statement was given to determine whether it was
  voluntarily made.â€Â  State v. Vang, 353 S.C. 78, 84, 577 S.E.2d 225,
  227-28 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing State
    v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 52,
  406 S.E.2d 315, 319 (1991) (â€œ[T]he jury should be instructed that they must
  find beyond reasonable doubt that the statement was freely and voluntarily
  given under the totality of the circumstances before the [statement] may be
  considered.â€)).Â   
The Supreme Court, in Withrow v. Williams, 507 U.S. 680
  (1993), set forth a non-exclusive list of factors which may be considered in
  the totality-of-the-circumstances analysis:

	Under
  the due process approach . . . courts look to the totality of circumstances to
  determine whether a statement was voluntary.Â  Those potential circumstances
  include not only the crucial element of police coercion, Colorado v.
    Connelly, 479 U.S. 157, 167(1986); the length of the interrogation, Ashcraft
      v. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143, 153-154(1944); its location, see Reck v.
        Pate, 367 U.S. 433, 441 (1961); its continuity, Leyra v. Denno, 347
  U.S. 556, 561 (1954); the defendantâ€™s maturity, Haley v. Ohio, 332 U.S.
  596, 599-601 (1948) (opinion of Douglas, J.); education, Clewis v. Texas,
  386 U.S. 707, 712 (1967); physical condition, Greenwald v. Wisconsin,
  390 U.S. 519, 520-521 (1968) (per curiam); and mental health, Fikes
    v. Alabama, 352 U.S. 191, 196 (1957).Â  They also include the failure of
  police to advise the defendant of his rights to remain silent and to have
  counsel present during custodial interrogation.Â  Haynes v. Washington,
  373 U.S. 503, 516-517 (1963)[.]Â  

507 U.S. at 693-94.Â   
Appellate entities
  in South Carolina have recognized that appropriate factors to consider in the
  totality-of-circumstances analysis include: background, experience, and conduct
  of the accused; age; length of custody; police misrepresentations; isolation of
  a minor from his or her parent; threats of violence; and promises of leniency.Â  See Childs, 299
  S.C. at 475, 385 S.E.2d at 842 (background, experience, and conduct of the accused); In
    re Williams, 265 S.C. 295, 217 S.E.2d 719 (1975) (age); State v.
      Jennings, 280 S.C. 62, 309 S.E.2d 759 (1983) (length of custody); State
        v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 461, 272 S.E.2d 634, 635 (1980) (police
  misrepresentations); State v. Smith, 268 S.C. 349, 355, 234 S.E.2d 19,
  21 (1977) (isolation of minor); State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200,
  391 S.E.2d 244, 246 (1990) (threats of violence and promises of leniency). 
 
Coercive
  police activity is a necessary predicate to finding a statement is not
  voluntary.Â  Colorado v. Connelly, 479 U.S. 157 (1986); Linnen,
  278 S.C. 175, 293 S.E.2d 851.Â  Coercion is determined from the perspective of
  the suspect.Â  Illinois v. Perkins, 496 U.S. 292 (1990).Â   
A
  statement may not be â€œextracted by any sort of threats or violence, [or]
  obtained by any direct or implied promises, however slight, [or] obtained by
  the exertion of improper influence.â€Â  Rochester, 301 S.C. at 200, 391
  S.E.2d at 247 (citing Hutto v. Ross, 429 U.S. 28 (1976)).Â  A statement
  â€œinduced by a promise of leniency is involuntary only if so connected with the
  inducement as to be a consequence of the promise.â€Â  Compton, 366 S.C. at
  680, 623 S.E.2d at 679; see also State v. Saltz, 346 S.C.
  114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001); Rochester, 301 S.C. at 200, 391
  S.E.2d at 247; State v. Peake, 291 S.C. 138, 139, 352 S.E.2d 487, 488
  (1987).Â   
In Peake,
  our state supreme court held a defendantâ€™s statements made to an investigating
  officer were induced by a promise of leniency because the officer told the
  defendant the State would not seek the death penalty if he made a statement.Â 
  291 S.C. at 139, 352 S.E.2d at 488.Â  However, in Rochester, the supreme
  court found a statement made by a polygraph examiner was not an inducement by
  the promise of leniency.Â  The examinerâ€™s statement simply conveyed that it
  would be in the defendantâ€™s best interest to tell the truth.Â  301 S.C. at 201,
  391 S.E.2d at 247.Â  The Rochester court further noted, â€œ[S]tanding
  alone, the polygraph examinerâ€™s comment did not constitute the kind of hope or
  reward or benefit condemned by this Court in Peake.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
In the case sub judice, Miller maintains his statements were not freely and voluntarily given
  because they were induced by a promise of an eight to twelve year sentence.Â 
  However, Miller was not present to testify, and the only person who testified
  at the Denno hearing that the promise existed was Varner, Millerâ€™s
  attorney.Â  Unlike the circumstances in Peake, in this instance three
  officers and Assistant Attorney General Evans denied any promise of leniency in
  exchange for Millerâ€™s statements.Â  Although the officers and Evans told Miller
  it was in his best interest to cooperate, no one made any direct or implied
  promise of leniency.Â  As a result, Millerâ€™s statements were made in the â€œhopeâ€
  of leniency rather than as a consequence of a â€œpromise.â€Â  Â 
In ruling on the
  admissibility of Millerâ€™s statements, the trial judge had the opportunity in
  the Denno hearing to listen to the testimony, assess the demeanor and
  credibility of all witnesses, and weigh the evidence accordingly.Â  In
  determining Miller knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily made the statements
  the trial judge ruled:Â   

	[T]he
  [c]ourt cannot conclude that the statements to Agents Bragg and Sonnefeld were
  not freely voluntarily given after Mr. Miller was afforded all of his rights,
  warning and safeguards pursuant to the case law in such cases made and
  provided, or that the handwritten statement was not freely and voluntarily
  given.
	Furthermore, the
  court instructed the jury to
	carefully
  scrutinize all the surrounding circumstances about and concerning such
  statement or statements before you give any weight to any alleged statement of
  statements.Â  You must be satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that the statement
  was made by the accused person uninfluenced by promise of reward, threats of
  injury or diminution of his rights. 

The trial judge analyzed
  the voluntariness of Millerâ€™s statements in compliance with the due process
  requirements. Â Luculently, the admission of Millerâ€™s statements at trial was
  not an abuse of discretion.  
II.  Enforceability of
  Plea Offer
Miller next contends
  the promise of an eight-to-twelve-year sentence should have been enforced.Â  Specifically,
  Miller claims the Stateâ€™s oral promise of eight-to-twelve years was binding
  because he detrimentally relied on it by disclosing the information the State
  wanted.Â  We disagree.Â   
â€œ[I]t is the
  prerogative of any person to waive his rights, confess, and plead guilty, under
  judicially defined safeguards, which are adequately enforced.â€Â  Reed v.
    Becka, 333 S.C. 676, 685, 511 S.E.2d 396, 401 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Armstrong, 263 S.C. 594, 597, 211 S.E.2d 889, 890 (1975).Â 
  However, a defendant has no constitutional right to plea bargain.Â  Reed,
  333 S.C. at 685, 511 S.E.2d at 401.Â  Furthermore, the trial judge is not
  required to accept a plea.Â  Id.; see also Santabello v.
    New York, 404 U.S. 257, 262 (1971) (stating defendant has no absolute
  right to have a guilty plea accepted).Â  However, once a defendant enters a
  guilty plea and the plea is accepted by the court, due process requires the
  plea bargain be honored.Â  Reed, 333 S.C. at 686, 511 S.E.2d at 401.Â  
 
While
  plea agreements are a matter of criminal jurisprudence, most courts have held
  they are subject to contract principles.Â  See, eg, Â Reed v.
    Becka, 333 S.C. 676, 686, 511 S.E.2d 396, 401 (Ct. App. 1999); United
      States v. Ringling, 988 F.2d 504, 505 (4th Cir. 1993); United States v.
        Harvey, 791 F.2d 294, 300 (4th Cir. 1986) (â€œ[I]n the process of determining
  whether disputed plea agreements have been formed or performed, courts have
  necessarily drawn on the most relevant body of developed rules and principles
  of private law, those pertaining to the formation and interpretation of
  commercial contracts.â€).Â  Unless intended by both parties, terms or conditions
  should not be read into a plea agreement.Â  State v. Compton, 366 S.C.
  671, 678, 623 S.E.2d 661, 665 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Until performance occurs,
  parties are free to withdraw their offers.Â  Reed, 333 S.C. at 687, 511
  S.E.2d at 402.Â   
A
  plea agreement is only an â€œofferâ€ until the defendant enters a court-approved guilty
  plea.Â  Id. at 688, 511 S.E.2d at 403.Â  A defendant accepts the â€œofferâ€
  by pleading guilty.Â  Id.Â  Until formal acceptance has occurred, the plea
  is not binding on the defendant, the State, or the court.Â  Id.Â  This
  general rule is subject to a detrimental reliance exception.Â  Custodio v.
    State, 373 S.C. 4, 11, 644 S.E.2d 36, 39 (2007); Reed, 333 S.C. at
  688, 511 S.E.2d at 403.Â  The fact that an agreement was oral does not prevent
  possible enforcement.Â  Id.Â  Absent a plea of guilt, a defendant may
  enforce an oral plea agreement upon a showing of detrimental reliance.Â  Id.Â  Even if the agreement has not been finalized by the court, a defendantâ€™s
  detrimental reliance on a promise in plea-bargaining may make a plea binding.Â  Id.Â  A defendant who provides beneficial information to law enforcement can be said
  to have relied to his detriment.Â  Id.
State prosecutors
  are obligated to fulfill the promises they make to defendants when those
  promises serve as inducements to defendants to plead guilty.Â  Santabello v. New York, 404 U.S. 257, 262 (1971).Â  South Carolina has recognized the principles set
  forth in Santabello; when an accused pleads guilty upon the promise of a
  prosecutor, the agreement must be fulfilled.Â  See Sprouse v. State, 355
  S.C. 335, 338, 585 S.E.2d 278, 280 (2003); State v. Thrift, 312 S.C.
  282, 292, 440 S.E.2d 341, 347 (1994); see also State v. Mathis,
  287 S.C. 589, 592, 340 S.E.2d 538, 540 (1986) (â€œThe public interest of
  encouraging settlement of criminal cases without necessity of trial favors
  permitting an accused to plead guilty to the offense charged without
  prejudicing his position if it is later withdrawn.â€) (quoting State v.
    Wright, 436 P.2d 601, 604-05 (1968)).
However, a
  defendant may not attempt to create a firm commitment out of plea
  negotiations.Â  State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 49, 476 S.E.2d 683, 687
  (2007).Â  The State is not bound to accept a defendantâ€™s terms simply because a
  defendant reveals otherwise undiscoverable facts in the hope of securing a
  favorable plea agreement.Â  Id.; State v. Thompson, 278 S.C. 1,
  292 S.E.2d 581 (1982), cert. denied, 456 U.S. 938 (1982) (holding
  solicitorâ€™s plea negotiations to consider life sentence did not prevent State
  from seeking death penalty) overruled in part on other grounds by State
    v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â   
In Whipple,
  the court concluded no plea agreement was reached when a solicitor told Whipple
  he would consider, not promise, a life sentence if substantial mitigating
  evidence was demonstrated.Â  324 S.C. at 48, 476 S.E.2d at 686.Â  Contrastively,
  in Custodio, all of the evidence presented conclusively showed that an
  agreement between the defendant and solicitor existed.Â  373 S.C. at 10, 644
  S.E.2d at 38.Â  The court ruled Custodio fully cooperated by providing helpful
  information in reliance on the solicitorâ€™s assurances of a fifteen-year
  sentence cap and was therefore entitled to have the agreement enforced.Â  Id. at 12, 644 S.E.2d at 39.
In
  the present case, the evidence indicates the communications between Evans and
  Varner about an eight-to-twelve-year sentence never reached the level of a
  promise or agreement. Â Evans testified the protocol in grand jury cases was to formally,
  in writing, extend a plea offer after the defendant was debriefed and the
  desired information obtained. Â In accordance with that practice, the only offer
  Evans ever made Miller was a written plea agreement for fifteen years.Â   
Discussions
  between Evans and Varner about a range of potential sentences prior to Millerâ€™s
  debriefing were plea negotiations and cannot be construed as an â€œoffer.â€Â  Nothing
  in the testimony indicates Evans ever intended to agree to an eight-to-twelve-year
  plea. Â Miller was not present at trial and never expressed his understanding of
  the terms of the alleged â€œdeal.â€Â  Furthermore, Miller never accepted a plea offer
  by entering a guilty plea.Â  Admittedly, Miller revealed information in the hope
  of securing a favorable plea.Â  Nevertheless, without an affirmative promise or
  plea offer from the State of eight to twelve years, Millerâ€™s cooperation did
  not bind the State to accept his terms. Â 
Accordingly, we
  find the trial judge did not err in declining to enforce the alleged
  eight-to-twelve-year agreement.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold the trial court did not err in admitting Millerâ€™s oral and written
  statements at trial, because they were knowingly, intelligently, and
  voluntarily made.Â  We rule the evidentiary record does NOT contain an
  enforceable plea agreement.Â  The conviction and sentence of Miller are  
AFFIRMED. 
THOMAS,
  J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

title: Hutto v. State
description: Tommy Hutto appeals the trial court's deniel of PCR from his conviction for burglary, criminal sexual conduct and armed robbery claiming the trial court erred in not finding his trial counsel was ineffective. We affirmed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Tommy Hutto, Petitioner
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent
			
		
	


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4308
Heard September 12, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  26, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of Columbia, for
  Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Lance S. Boozer, Assistant Attorney General Paula Magargle,
  and John Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.: Â Tommy Hutto was convicted of first-degree burglary, first-degree criminal
  sexual conduct, and armed robbery. The trial court sentenced Hutto to 30 years
  each for the first-degree criminal sexual conduct and armed robbery charges and
  life imprisonment for the burglary charge. The post-conviction relief (PCR)
  court denied Huttoâ€™s request for relief and we granted certiorari.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In
  the early morning hours of July 16, 1998, Victim, a 90-year-old woman, awoke to
  the sound of someone breaking the glass in her door.Â Â  Victim saw a man enter
  her home. The intruder accidentally cut himself while attempting to gain entry
  into Victimâ€™s home. Victim grabbed a loaded rifle in order to confront the
  intruder, but the intruder wrestled it away from her. Victimâ€™s assailant robbed,
  sexually assaulted her, and burglarized her home before leaving.  
On August 1, 1998, Huttoâ€™s
  probation agent, accompanied by probation agent James Harris, visited Hutto on
  a routine visit to verify Huttoâ€™s address.Â During the home visit, Harris
  noticed lacerations on Huttoâ€™s arms and hands.Â   
Hubert
  Nimau, the police investigator handling Victimâ€™s case, issued a â€œbe on the
  lookoutâ€ notice requesting information regarding suspects fitting the following
  profile: Caucasian male, approximately 24 to 25 years old, 5â€™8â€ tall, weighing 130
  pounds, short dark hair, and has fresh cuts or lacerations to his arms and
  hands. Believing Hutto could fit the description, Harris disclosed his
  observations of Huttoâ€™s lacerations to Nimau.Â  Â Nimau, utilizing information
  from Harris as well as other information independently received in response to a
  crime watchers news article, prepared a lineup which included Huttoâ€™s picture. Victim
  identified Hutto as her assailant by selecting his picture out of the lineup.
 
Based
  on this identification, Nimau obtained a search warrant for Huttoâ€™s blood.
  Nimau executed the search warrant and a nurse obtained Huttoâ€™s blood for
  testing pursuant to the warrant.Â  A forensic DNA analyst at the South Carolina
  Law Enforcement Division, compared Huttoâ€™s DNA with DNA samples taken from the crime
  scene at Victimâ€™s house. The DNA samples taken from the crime scene, including
  cuttings taken from Victimâ€™s pajama bottoms, matched Huttoâ€™s DNA.[1]Â   
Hutto
  was indicted for armed robbery, criminal sexual conduct in the first degree,
  and burglary in the first degree.Â  On November 3, 1999, a jury found Hutto
  guilty of all three charges. The trial judge sentenced Hutto to thirty years
  imprisonment for the armed robbery charge, thirty years imprisonment for
  criminal sexual conduct, and life imprisonment for the burglary charge, with
  the sentences set to run concurrently. Hutto appealed his convictions to our
  court and we affirmed in an unpublished opinion.Â  See State v. Hutto, Op. No. 2002-UP-395 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 4, 2002).Â  
 
Hutto
  applied for PCR and, after a hearing, the PCR judge denied Huttoâ€™s request for
  relief. Â Hutto appeals.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
â€œTo
  establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must
  prove: (1) that counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance under
  prevailing professional norms; and (2) that the deficient performance
  prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case.â€Â  Custodio v. State, 373 S.C. 4, 9, 644
  S.E.2d 36, 38 (2007).Â  â€œJudicial scrutiny of counselâ€™s performance is highly
  deferential and the court must â€˜indulge a strong presumption that counselâ€™s
  conduct falls within the wide range of reasonable professional assistance . . .
  .â€™ â€ Simpson v. Moore, 367 S.C. 587, 598, 627 S.E.2d 701, 707 (2006)
  (quoting Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 445, 334 S.E.2d 813, 816
  (1985)).
â€œThis
  Court will sustain the PCR judgeâ€™s factual findings and conclusions regarding
  ineffective assistance of counsel if there is any probative evidence to support
  those findings.â€Â  Jackson v. State, 329 S.C. 345, 348, 495 S.E.2d
  768, 769 (1998).Â  â€œHowever, if there is no probative evidence to support the
  PCR judgeâ€™s findings, the findings will not be upheld.â€Â  Id.Â  In
  addition, our court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision if it is controlled
  by an error of law.Â  Suber
    v. State, 371 S.C. 554, 558-59, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
DISCUSSION
We
  granted certiorari to address whether Huttoâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective for
  not moving to suppress the evidence presented against Hutto on the basis of an improper
  disclosure by a probation agent.

	Section
  24-21-290 of the South Carolina Code provides as follows:
	
		Information received by probation agents privileged.
		All
  information and data obtained in the discharge of his official duty by a
  probation agent is privileged information, is not receivable as evidence in a
  court, and may not be disclosed directly or indirectly to anyone other than the
  judge or others entitled under this chapter to receive reports unless ordered
  by the court or the director.
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  24-21-290 (2007).
On appeal, Hutto argues Harris disclosed privileged observations
  made in the discharge of his official duties as a probation agent without
  having obtained proper authorization pursuant to section 24-21-290 to disclose
  that information. In addition, Hutto complains that Harris improperly testified
  about his observations in violation of the statute.Â  Furthermore, Hutto reasons
  that the evidence gained as a result of the unauthorized disclosure,
  specifically Victimâ€™s identification of Hutto from the line-up and the DNA
  evidence obtained as a result of the identification, should be excluded as
  fruits of the poisonous tree.

  failing to object to the admission of this evidence pursuant to section
